revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-70.185.185.31-20100720024117]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-70.185.185.31-20100720024117]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsoniu...
revision.text: Honestly, I feel like the top is a red herring.Whether the top falls or will fall is irrelevant to whether or not he is in a dream/limbo. If he is in a dream and wills the top to keep spinning, it will keep spinning. If he is in a dream and spins the top and wills it (consciously or unconsciously) to fall it will. By looking at the top, he can never know 100% that he is in a dream or not. What he does know is whether he is in his dream or whether he is in another's for extraction/inception. This is what leads me to believe that he and his wife are still asleep experimenting with nested dreams.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-76.164.114.5-20100720041031]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-76.164.114.5-20100720041031]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsonius]...
revision.text: ...well, if the totem was to wobble at all, then it was bound to fall, thus he is most likely in reality. As for his kids having the same clothes and appearing not to have aged, the clothes thing could be coincidence, and all the events that have happened to Cobb throughout the whole movie( ever since he was in limbo with his wife ) could have all been within a year. Thus his children not appearing to age much. But either way, if he was still in limbo, he'll still have to wake up, lol.

revision.text:
question
if their target was saito like when they were inside a train then why would Mal appear on saito's dream? remember Mal double crossed cobb right by telling saito that cobb was there to steal something from him. so if it's saito's dream then why would mal appear in it?
it also happened inside fischer's dream. their target was fischer but why would Mal appear in it?

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-99.69.48.125-20100720054343]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-99.69.48.125-20100720054343]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsonius]...
revision.text: Also, think about the name "Ariadne" - in Greek mythology, she was the goddess who took it upon herself to help Theseus navigate the Labyrinth and defeat the Minotaur. Isn't this a tidy little metaphor for what Cobb is mentally going through throughout the film? Definitely supports the "it all took place in Cobb's dream" theory.

yep and the phrase take a leap of faith..
cobb's subconscious is telling himself through Mal and saito to wake up from his dream

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-DEADP0OL-20100720073332]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-DEADP0OL-20100720073332]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsonius]]" to "[...
revision.text:
my initial reaction after the scene blacked out was cobb came back to the real world because the top wobbled coz we saw how the top spin in the dream world it keeps spinning indefinitely. and for it to wobble it would mean it will eventually stop spinning..
but then i forgot to consider that the totem (top) belonged to his wife. remember cobb told ariadne that you need to have your own totem and you must not show it to anyone else. having your own totem would determine whether you are inside a dream or you are back in the real world because you know how your totem behaves. now because the totem belonged to Mal, i think cobb spinning the top to know whether he is in a dream state or back in the real world would have no bearing at all because he does not own the totem in the first place. he stole it from mal right? so if my theory is correct i think what we saw from start to finish of the film it was cobb's dream all along.
plus the children remained ageless and wore the same clothes as seen inside his dream.
and there were hints like "take a leap of faith" i believe Mal said it to cobb. saito also told cobb to take a leap of faith.. and since all of them were projections this would only mean that cobb is trying to convince himself to wake up but just can't because he perceives his own dream as a reality.
and why would Mal appear in everyone's dream. we saw her appear when the target was saito, we saw her inside fischer's dream right so i think these were all cobb's projection.

revision.text: Mal appears in all of the dreams because she is a projection of Dom's subconscious guilt for inadvertently causing her death. Dom is in all of the dreams, ergo Mal is in all of the dreams. His guilt is such a part of him that she appears almost an alter ego of him.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-82.33.144.128-20100720124956]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-82.33.144.128-20100720124956]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsoniu...
revision.text:
Hang on, a top that spins forever is completely impossible, and everyone in the world would assume such behaviour of a spinning top by default.
The only time we ever hear mention of a top that 'spins forever' is when Cobb is explaining his totem to Ariadne (or have I forgotten something else/misremembered that dialogue?). Is it not feasible that this is a deliberate lie that Cobb tells anyone who knows about his totem so that he'll know that he's in someone else's dream if it ever does spin for an unusually long time? (I say unusually long because one would never wait around 'forever'.)
To me, the fact that the top wobbled was proof enough that he was at the very least in his own dream - presuming everyone else who knew about his totem actually believed that it could spin forever. If he were in anyone else's dream, it would remain in a perfect spin at all times, surely.
Perhaps I'm way off, but it would seem to me that the spinning top is not Cobb's way of determining whether he's dreaming or awake, but simply whether or not he's in his own dream.
In any case, it's a brilliant film and I'm going to interpret it as a happy ending. [:
James

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-99.66.223.0-20100720173700]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-99.66.223.0-20100720173700]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsonius]]"...
revision.text:
I think there is another possibility for "Getting into the Dream World." It's possible that when Ken, Dom, Robert, and Ariadne enter limbo, they are never able to get out. Although it is shown that different characters either use death or a kick to escape limbo, would this not defeat the purpose of limbo in the movie? If limbo is as easily exited as a dream, then there is no reason to fear it. None the less, each of the characters are easily able to exit limbo as soon as they wish. While Ken may have had trouble without a totem, there was no reason why Dom and Mal, trained professionals, should have to spend 50 years in limbo when they could have simply killed themselves at any time.
This would mean that the last scene is still part of limbo, from waking up on the plane on.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-99.66.223.0-20100720174540]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-99.66.223.0-20100720174540]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsonius]]"...
revision.text:
Also to Anonymous user, James:
I think you're misinterpreting the use of the totem, but you are onto something I was thinking as well. The reason the totem is kept secret is so that no dreamer can replicate it's characteristics in the real world. In this case, an architect would want to make sure that the top falls over in their dream instead of spinning indefinitely.
The thought you bring up though is the unoriginality of Dom's totem, and how little he protects it. Unlike Arthur who has a truly unique totem whose characteristics he keeps secret, Dom's totem is rather simple. Anyone who is aware of it could easily create a dream where the top topples over instead.
So we must ask, why does Dom choose this totem, or why does Nolan choose it for him?

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-99.66.223.0-20100720174934]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-99.66.223.0-20100720174934]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsonius]]"...
revision.text:
There's no such thing as coincidence in a movie. Everything that happened was chosen to happen by Christopher Nolan for a specific reason. He didn't just forget that the children were wearing the same clothes at the end that they were all through out the movie. This was a conscious decision of his.
That said, now we have to think what Nolan is trying to imply.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-99.66.223.0-20100720175451]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-99.66.223.0-20100720175451]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsonius]]"...
revision.text: There was a real good point made about totems. There's a bit of a logical fallacy here. The totem only tells the user when they're in someone else's dream. There is no way to know you're in your own dream, because your subconscious would be able to replicate the totem perfectly.

revision.comment: moved [[Talk:Inception Reviews/@comment-70.42.129.157-20100720203442]] to [[User blog comment:Bastian964/Inception Reviews/@comment-70.42.129.157-20100720203442]]: This needs comments to be worth it
revision.text: I found Inception thought-provoking, interesting and visually beautiful. I was at the edge of my seat throughout the duration of the movie, and I was so incredibly focused, trying to take everything in. I'll definitely see it again.

revision.comment: moved [[Talk:Inception Reviews/@comment-Samsonius-20100720205517]] to [[User blog comment:Bastian964/Inception Reviews/@comment-Samsonius-20100720205517]]: This needs comments to be worth it
revision.text: Easily the best film I've seen or will see in 2010. Very intelligent, deep, and thought provoking. Right now, it's tied with Avatar as the best film of the past 10 years, and I'll definitely go see it again (maybe more than once). The film's definitely deserving of a few Academy Awards, let's just hope we don't have to witness another travesty like the one last year where the underdog takes the award that it doesn't deserve... :P

revision.text: There are two reasons why I believe that the end of the movie is not Cobb's dream. First in the dream Cobb's totem spun undisturbed for as long as he left it. It did not shake or show any unstable movement. Another reason is that he came from the world in the beginning, before entering a dream. This is recognizable because the totem tips over multiple times throughout he course of the movie. In any case I thought that this was an amazing movie. Thanks!

revision.comment: Created page with 'I have a little black notebook that I carry with me everywhere, just for writing down ideas, interesting phrases. I've decided that it will be my totem and in the vein of Cobb's …'
revision.text: I have a little black notebook that I carry with me everywhere, just for writing down ideas, interesting phrases. I've decided that it will be my totem and in the vein of Cobb's top, I've come up with a test: if I flip through the pages and reach the end of the book, I know I'm awake. But if I am able to flip through the pages infinitely, then I know i'm dreaming.

{{Infobox item |image=PASIV_Device_Infobox.png |imagesize=250px |name=PASIV Device |height= |weight= |usedby=[[Dominic Cobb|Dom Cobb's]] [[The Team|team]] |manufactured= |usage=Administering Somnacin doses to dreamers |construction=Metal briefcase shell, IV tubing, various electronic monitoring devices |firstseen=''[[Inception (2010 film)|Inception]]'' }} The '''Portable Automated Somnacin IntraVenous Device''', abbreviated '''PASIV Device''', is a device used for administering the drug [[Somnacin]] to dreamers in the field. [[Instruction Manual MV-235A]] provides instructions on the proper usage of this machine.
==Features== The PASIV device, as well as providing meticulous control over the dosage of Somnacin to subjects in the field, also has the following features: *A central button called the Infusion Trigger that can activate all IV lines at once. *Configurable control settings for the accurate monitoring and adjustment of Somnacin levels. *12 foot (4 meter) IV lines for versatile in the field set-up. *LED display with atomized timer for monitoring precise flow rates. *Synchronization monitoring chip for flow check monitoring and automated adjustment to optimize output flow. *Lithium iodide batteries with life of 200 hours. *Additional vial storage for multiple doses in the field. *Case lock for prevention of system tampering. *Memory backup for retention of infusion output data. *Easy access to fuses and batteries for replacement. [[Category:Technology]]

[[File:Pasiv manual.png|right|250px|thumb|Cover of the instruction manual]] [[Instruction Manual MV-235A]] is an instruction manual for the [[Portable Automated Somnacin IntraVenous Device]]. It can be found online [http://www.pasivdevice.org/ here].
The manual has a labeling error on page 4, accidentally switching the labels of Figure 4a-1 and Figure 4a-2.
==References== <references/> [[Category:Stub]] [[Category:Technology]]

{{Youmay|the shared dreaming tactic|[[Inception (2010 film)|the 2010 film]]}} {{Quote|...It's not just about depth you know, you need the simplest version of the idea in order for it to grow naturally in a subject's mind; it's a very subtle art.|||-[[Eames]]}} '''Inception''' is the allegedly impossible task of implanting an idea in someone's mind via [[Dream-Sharing|dream-sharing]] and making them think it is their own. However, as the movie progresses, it is proven that Inception is not impossible and has, in fact, been done successfully twice (both times by [[Dom Cobb]]). This method is believed to be the inverse of "[[Extraction]]". Nonetheless, inception is a very difficult process. It requires dreamers to plant the idea in a dangerously deep layer of the Subject. This becomes the first difficulty of inception, as descending into a level so deep (three layers or more) creates highly unstable dream level. A way to solve the problem with unstable dreams is to use highly powerful sedatives, but such a powerful sedative makes escape by death in a dream impossible. Instead, death drops the dreamer in Limbo. Another necessary component in inception is to have the Subject accept the idea with as little involvement from the dreamers as possible in presenting the idea to ensure the Subject cannot trace the origin of the idea. Part of this is to make the idea as simple as possible to ensure the idea remains. ==References== {{stub}} [[es:Origen]] [[Category:Dream Mechanics]] [[Category:Article stubs]] [[Category:Stub]]

Saito

[[File:Dream sharing.png|right|thumb|400px|[[Arthur]] and [[Ariadne]] sharing a dream]] '''Dream-Sharing''' is the practice of manufacturing a [[The Dreams|dream]] and bringing one or more people into that new dream world. While dream-sharing, the [[Dreamer]] creates and controls the world, while the [[Subject]] populates it with both [[projections|people]] and information.
To initiate dream-sharing, special medication is needed and is facilitated by the [[Portable Automated Somnacin IntraVenous Device|PASIV Device]]. [[Somnacin]] is one of the drugs used for this purpose. When dreaming on only one level, a timer mechanism on the PASIV device can be used to wake up dreamers. Multiple dream levels requires a method known a [[kick]] to awaken from a dream on a deeper level.
Dream-sharing was first utilized by the military to provide a realistic training method for soldiers, in [[Project Somnacin]]. It can also be used to commit [[Extraction]] by stealing information and [[Inception (tactic)|Inception]] by planting information in the form of an idea into the mind of the subject and making the subject think that the idea is their own. [[Miles]] brought [[Dominick Cobb|Dom]] and the others into dream-sharing to prove to them that their creativity was limitless.
Overexposure to dream-sharing can cause an individual to be unable to dream naturally. Many people who can no longer dream must use a PASIV Device if they wish to dream while they sleep.
==References== <references/> [[Category:Dream Mechanics]]

revision.text: At the beginning of the movie saito says everything first hand when they're at the table. At the end, cobb talks over him and says saito's words first as though he knew exactly what he was going to say. This may mean that the first scene and the last scene were separate events - interesting to see if the wedding ring is present in both.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-Accendrez-20100721164017]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-Accendrez-20100721164017]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsonius]]" to ...
revision.text:
Anonymous user at 8:13 brings up another one of those little hints. I almost feel like the only reason we weren't actually shown the "it was all a dream" ending is because people would be furious with a M. Night-esque ending. Instead we're left to think about it. In fact, it's possible Nolan himself didn't decide which ending to go with, so instead left it up to the imagination of the audience. I guess we'll find out if/when there is a sequel.
Also, if what Anonymous 15:39 is right, that's another big event. There are way to many of these to assume they were accidental.
Also for reference I'm also Anonymous 17:37, 17:45, 17:49, and 17:54. lol, I got a little too into it after I saw the movie.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-170.252.248.205-20100721233844]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-170.252.248.205-20100721233844]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Sams...
revision.text:
I have my own thoughts to add. I think the entire movie happened, up to the point that Cobb decides to stay in the dream to go find Saito.
From that point on whether or not, he came out is never fully explained.
After Cobb is shown to wakeup in the plane, the POV from that point on is from Cobb's perspective. We never get to see what the other colleagues are thinking or doing. We see it all from his perspective, as if he is building the dream. We never see, the colleagues leaving the rainy city world either. They may have woken up after the 10 hours are elasped, but I dont think that view is shown.
Further evidence:
Not only have the kids not aged and wearing the same clothes, even the father-in-law is wearing the same codes. There is not much dialogue after the wakeup, except whatever Cobb could imagine up. All the characters minus the kids and the father-in-law act and walk like Cobb's projections. The entire view is kept very surreal, and fast paced as if it was a dream.
Saito and Cobb both might be lost in the limbo, inventing people and objects as seem fit.
How do we know who's father Miles is? It's never specified, is it? There are hints he could be either Ma's dad or Dom's.
I meant Mal's, not Ma's!
Since he's Dom's father-in-law, it would make sense that he's Mal's father.

revision.text:
i still believe that this was all cobb's dream and everything in it including saito, ariadne and the rest of his team are his projections..
it's like they are telling cobb to wake up from his dream

Also tells us that Cobb's been left for 2 years

{{Infobox_actor |name = Johnathan Geare |born = 2007 |nationality = American |gender = Male |hair = Blond |yearsactive = 2010-present |inceptionrole = 3 year old [[James Cobb]] }} {{stub}} Johnathan Geare is an American child actor. He plays the role of the three-year-old [[James Cobb]] in the [[Christopher Nolan]] film [[Inception (2010 film)|Inception]]. He also is a younger brother to [[Taylor Geare]] and [[Claire Geare]], who play the older and younger [[Phillipa Cobb]]. [[Category:Actors]] [[Category:Production]] [[Category:Stub]]

revision.text:
When Dom spins the top on the sink, the top falls over very quickly.
The Children's voices on the phone. While Dom is talking to his kids on the phone it sounds like there are two voices that fade in and out. The voice of a young child and that of a teenager. Also it seemed to me that Cobb was hearing what the wanted to hear, them as kids.
Also where was the grandmother that was watching after the kids?

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-68.196.225.150-20100723025105]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-68.196.225.150-20100723025105]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samson...
revision.text:
Cobb may have had Mal's Totem, but what if his Totem was his wedding ring itself? I mean, it appears everytime he's in the dream world. He's probably unable to take it off if dreaming and at the final scene, it's gone.
So, to me, it's not about the top but the wedding ring. The fact it's not on Cobb's finger hints that he is, in fact, in reality. And about the children? Maybe it as laundry day? And the timespan is not actually specified either. It could have only been a couple of months since time in Dreams is different than time in reality. But to make my asnwer clear, I think," The Top Stopped Spinnging."

revision.comment: moved [[Talk:Inception Reviews/@comment-Ozzyjalo94-20100723064820]] to [[User blog comment:Bastian964/Inception Reviews/@comment-Ozzyjalo94-20100723064820]]: This needs comments to be worth it
revision.text: Inception is by far the best movie I've seen in a year or two. The acting, I thought, was a highlight, and it's good to see a script and cast come together so well. The originality of the film was staggering and the complexity of the plot was a welcome break (if that's the right word) from the dull plots of movies that have come out in these past few months. I'd go see it again, but I'm broke...

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-119.92.114.42-20100723141953]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-119.92.114.42-20100723141953]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsoniu...
revision.text: according to cobb if you are inside your dream it will spin forever.. but if you're in reality of course physics would tell you that it is impossible..

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-58.173.112.177-20100723153555]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-58.173.112.177-20100723153555]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samson...
revision.text: Yes, I know that. I'm asking for YOU. How long does it take for the top to keep spinning to convince YOU it will never fall down? 5 seconds? 20 seconds? An hour? Couldn't you say, after an hour of spinning, that it could still fall down in the next second? What I'm saying is that no matter how long they show the top spinning, you could still say that it would fall over after they cut it.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-121.217.34.17-20100723163750]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-121.217.34.17-20100723163750]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsoniu...
revision.text:
Yep... Dom is projecting mal thats why the girl was brought along because she knew his secret! She was able to manipulate the dreams of Doms during the test - turning the cities upside etc and thats why the projections of the people around started attacking her because they were looking for the dreamers - at least thats how i saw it. e.g how adriane and arthur kissed didn't deter the people.
The point of that then leads to the top, the top appears to wobble at the end and in the dream its always told that it will continue to spin. it's cut off just in time! Also after the incident in the US, he said at the beginning there weren't many jobs for his line of work after what happened. The children were still questioning what happened to mum. He was going to lay low because of the dodgy dealings and failure to get the info out of saito.
I believe he woke up but they did the ending in a very surreal way in a way that would make you believe that he finally came to terms with it all and that is probably why people believe it to still be a dream and he allows "his totem" to waver.
The kids in the same clothes react to turn the same way as the Mal calls to them before Dom turns away which gave me the reason to think it was a dream he just could be bear to let himself believe it was until the ending - to let it all go, very vanilla sky there ;)
but all in all, i like the happier ending as I believe in either circumstances the Mal is dead and much rather have leo out of limbo with his kids.

revision.comment: moved [[Talk:Inception Reviews/@comment-Jetfire606-20100723180249]] to [[User blog comment:Bastian964/Inception Reviews/@comment-Jetfire606-20100723180249]]: This needs comments to be worth it
revision.text: Inception is an Oscar movie. I loved the performances by Leonardo DiCaprio, Ellen Page, Tom Hardy, Cillian Murphy, and Joseph Gordon-Levitt. I think that Cotillard should win an Oscar for Best Supporting Actress. I wish I could watch it again, but I'm also broke and I'm heading to D.C. today...and I have this mental thing about watching a movie twice. If this does'nt get the win, I'm gonna pack my things, fly to the Academy, and slap them real hard in the face. That's how far I'd go for a great film. Best tracks: Dreams Are Collapsing, Time, and Mombasa. At the end of the film, I heard "Time", and then I saw that top spinning. That got me teary, but I held it in for some reason. Four Stars.

[[File:inception team.png|thumb|right|350px|Cobb, Ariadne, Eames, Arthur, Yusuf, and Saito]] {{Quote|''Assemble your team, Mr. Cobb. And choose your people more wisely.''|||[[Saito]]}}
The Team consists of the group assembled by [[Dominick Cobb]] when he is employed by [[Saito]] to perform an [[Inception (tactic)|inception]] on [[Robert Fischer]]. The members of the group were chosen by Cobb for their exceptional ability, particularly given the difficult and almost unprecedented act of inception.
==Members== * [[Dominick Cobb]] is the best [[Extractor]] in the game, as he is hired by corporations to steal secrets they would otherwise never have access to. His level of expertise is such that he is very well-known in the black market of individuals who are able to infiltrate people’s minds and extract information.
*[[Arthur]] is the team's Point Man. While Cobb plans and provides the direction of each job, Arthur's task focuses on the execution of the job, which includes researching the details behind upcoming missions and ensuring that all team members know their roles. In the field, Arthur's role also includes improvising and adjusting the plan to protect other team members and ensure the team's success.
* [[Ariadne]] is an [[Architect]] who designs the mazes that the dreams will use as their foundation, taking the opportunity offered by Cobb to create and build places that cannot exist in reality. While in single level dreams, the Architect usually acts as the dreamer, Cobb intends for Ariadne only to design the mazes and only allows her to join the team in the field in order to watch Cobb in case his subconscious threatens the safety of the team or the mission.
*[[Eames]] is known as a [[Forger]] because of his ability to physically impersonate anyone ("forging" their identity) when inside a dream. His skill is vital to the success of the mission, as he can convince the Mark that he is anyone that the team needs him to be. To make the illusion convincing enough, Eames studies the traits, mannerisms, and characteristics of the people he is tasked with impersonating.
*[[Yusuf]] is the team's [[Chemist]]. He creates the drugs (most notably customized [[Somnacin]]) that are used to sedate the sleepers and [[Dream-Sharing|share dreams]].
*[[Saito]] is the team's employer for their latest mission. He is referred to as a "Tourist" because, although he accompanies the team on their mission, he is (for the most part) an observer, making sure that his intentions are carried out correctly.
==Gallery== <gallery> the team in city dream.png|The team testing [[The City (Dream)|Yusuf's dream]] The Team Planning.jpg|The team planning in the warehouse </gallery>
==External Links== * [http://www.inceptionteam.com/ Official Inception "Assemble Your Team" Game]
==References== <references/> [[Category:The Team]]

revision.comment: moved [[Talk:Inception Reviews/@comment-98.213.132.187-20100724003333]] to [[User blog comment:Bastian964/Inception Reviews/@comment-98.213.132.187-20100724003333]]: This needs comments to be worth it
revision.text: While comparisons with other movies can be made (Minority Report, Memento, In Her Majesty's Secret Service and the Ocean's series just to name some) Inception's level of originality is what seperates it from the majority. In a story where ideas play a key role, Christopher Nolan's concept of shared dreamspace stands out as being unique in cinema. The direction in excellent. The writing is facinating. The acting is engaging and balanced. As if that were not enough, the action sequences keep you on the edge of your seat! I do not consider most modern movies to be worth the price of a ticket, but I would gladly pay five times the admission rate to see this film for the first time again. Bottom line; see this movie... and then see it again.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-206.81.151.235-20100724184239]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-206.81.151.235-20100724184239]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samson...
revision.text: I personally think he's in reality, because 1) He remembered how he got there. Plane>Immigration>Meets up with his dad>House. It shows the sequence leading up to meeting his kids. In a dream, he wouldn't have remembered how he got there. 2) Wedding ring. 3) He sees the faces of his children. 4) If you look at IMDb, you will see that the children were double-cast. It shows that there is a 3-year-old Phillipa and a 5-year-old Phillipa, as well as a 1-year-old James and a 3-year-old James. So, although they do look quite a bit the same, they are in fact older.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-68.111.69.222-20100725021851]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-68.111.69.222-20100725021851]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsoniu...
revision.text:
I am thinking more and more that the end is in the dream world:
Dom uses Mal's totem and a totem can only detect if you are in your own dream. Therefore, I don't think we can infer a lot about the top telling us anything about reality. It's properties are also know to Ariadne and quite possibly Saito (who walks into Dom using it on the sink). Saito also uses the top in Limbo at the end.
Other thoughts: Dom's father very clearly tells him that 'he needs to get back to reality' when he seeks a new architect.
The old guy in Yusuf's office mentions that the people who use the sedative in the cellar come "to be woken up" ... and that "Dom of all people should know about that" (or something to that effect).
I also feel he cannot look at his children because of his guilt for Mal's death. As he cannot create a dream version of her that fully captures her "with all her perfection and imperfection" he maybe chooses the only reality he can create ... the one with his children, who are still growing up and haven't fully developed, yet.
Generally, I felt there was quite a strong connection between Saito and Mal. Mal shows up in the first 'dream within a dream' ... Saito's test dream ... literally standing next to Saito and making him aware of being inside a dream. Both Mal and Saito talk a lot about 'a leap of faith'. The phrase is used first by Saito when he convinces Dom to take the job. Mal uses it when she jumps and if I remember correctly Dom mentions it a few times as well.

revision.text: Inception is Christopher Nolan's masterpiece. The acting was phenomenal, the characters were complex, the special effects were top notch, the story was sound and original, and the soundtrack fully completed this epic. For once, I have no complaints about a movie.

Yesterday, I watched this movie of [[Inception]] in the theater located in near my home. I watched it with my wife. My wife told me that it is very funny and fantastic, which I agree perfectly.
Is there any oriental person who watched this movie? In fact, oriental people consider a dream as important as the real day life. He has so many words and stories about dreams. One of the words is that dream is nothing after we wake up regardless how it is important in the dream.
After I saw this movie, I realize that dream makes time longer than real life because dream is belonging to a unconsciousness area. [[Category:Blog posts]]

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-166.70.55.244-20100725051451]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-166.70.55.244-20100725051451]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsoniu...
revision.text:
What about this possibility. Dom said to his father that he was only doing what he, his father, had taught him to do--manipulate peoples' minds, implying that Dad had some skills of his own. Then Dad introduces him to Ariadne, who, though a newcomer, becomes strangely and rapidly close, one might say intimate, with Dom. What if Dad is practicing an inception of his own through Ariadne, who is functioning as a "Mr. Charles," if you will.
Oddly, Dad greets him at the airport--wait a minute--where did Dom meet with Dad in the first place? Dad couldn't have been in the US because Dom couldn't go there. And yet, out of nowhere, Dad appears at the US airport to welcome Dom home.
Dom's still dreaming--and there's a sequel coming.

Does anyone else agree that we don't need this category?[[User:Ozzyjalo94|Ozzyjalo94]] 09:33, July 25, 2010 (UTC)

revision.comment: Undo revision 9772 by [[Special:Contributions/66.54.118.89|66.54.118.89]] ([[User talk:66.54.118.89|talk]]) Please don't add speculation to articles
revision.text:
{{stub}} '''Cobol Engineering''' is the company that hired [[Dominic Cobb|Dom]], [[Arthur]], and [[Nash]] to [[Extraction|extract]] [[Proclus Global|Proclus Global's]] expansion plan from first [[Mr. Kaneda|Mr. Kaneda's]] and then [[Saito|Saito's]] mind. When that fails, they put a large bounty on Cobb's head and send thugs after him when he comes to Mombasa. Cobol Engineering has so much power in Mombasa that [[Eames]] says "they pretty much own <nowiki>[it]</nowiki>."
[[es:Ingeniería Cobol]] [[Category:Companies]] [[Category:Stub]]

{{stub}} '''Proclus Global''' is a major energy company. It is headed by Mr. [[Mr. Saito|Saito]] , and its chief engineer is [[Mr. Kaneda|Mr. Kaneda.]] Its only competitor is [[Fischer Morrow|Fischer Morrow]], headed now by [[Robert Fischer]]. Its head enlists [[Dom Cobb|Dom Cobb's]] [[The Team|team]] to perform [[inception]] on Fischer to make sure he will divide his [[Maurice Fischer|father]]'s empire to prevent his company from becoming another "superpower".
[[es:Proclus Global]] [[Category:Companies]] [[Category:Stub]]

Hi to you all, my name is '''RoyboyX'''. You may call me in short form by my real name '''Roy''' or my initials '''RBX'''.

revision.comment: Created page with 'He did survive; you can see him in the background queuing up for immigrations when Cobb is getting his passport checked.'
revision.text: He did survive; you can see him in the background queuing up for immigrations when Cobb is getting his passport checked.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-112.198.78.112-20100726075619]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-112.198.78.112-20100726075619]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samson...
revision.text:
The kids didn't have the same clothing at the end scene. After looking closely, Philippa was only wearing a plain pink dress in his memories and James wearing sandals. At the end scene Philippa had a white tshirt under her pink dress, her hair is a little different too. James had white shoes on instead of sandals and his hair is longer than in his memories.
I think i'll go with him being in reality in the end. i dont think that it matters if the top fell or not. the end scene was kind of like a trap for the audience, it's not actually an open end.

revision.comment: moved [[Talk:Inception Reviews/@comment-Zeypher-20100726094405]] to [[User blog comment:Bastian964/Inception Reviews/@comment-Zeypher-20100726094405]]: This needs comments to be worth it
revision.text: Simply Epic! It gave such an open ended "ending" so it could really go both ways. Thus making me and my wife want to watch it again to see if we missed anything. Great movie! I'm surpraised it still didn't gross over it's budget yet... (according to Wikipedia) but I'm still it will! It has to!

revision.comment: moved [[Talk:Inception Reviews/@comment-Skxwang-20100726110247]] to [[User blog comment:Bastian964/Inception Reviews/@comment-Skxwang-20100726110247]]: This needs comments to be worth it
revision.text: Give Inception a little time. Even Avatar didn't gross over its budget in a day.

revision.comment: moved [[Talk:Inception Reviews/@comment-Ozzyjalo94-20100726110713]] to [[User blog comment:Bastian964/Inception Reviews/@comment-Ozzyjalo94-20100726110713]]: This needs comments to be worth it
revision.text: It's grossed $227 million internationally according to Wikipedia, so it's officially a box-office success!

revision.comment: moved [[Talk:Inception Reviews/@comment-Skxwang-20100726111655]] to [[User blog comment:Bastian964/Inception Reviews/@comment-Skxwang-20100726111655]]: This needs comments to be worth it
revision.text: The US budget was only 200 million, so it beat it by a fair chunk. Awesome job!

revision.comment: Created page with 'He misses his carpet.'
revision.text: He misses his carpet.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-119.92.125.193-20100726164632]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-119.92.125.193-20100726164632]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samson...
revision.text:
okay this is my final verdict: i believe he is back in reality
no more complicated theories like ageless kids, mal being the right one..
i saw the pics of cobb he is wearing his wedding ring inside the dream. he wears a wedding ring where they infiltrated saito's dream. but in the chase scene where he is to meet the forger he wasn't wearing his ring.
inside the plane he isn't wearing his wedding ring.. after the team went inside fischer's dream he is wearing his wedding ring again
in the last scene where he is going to meet his children there's no sign of him wearing his ring..

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-76.102.4.20-20100726180151]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-76.102.4.20-20100726180151]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsonius]]"...
revision.text: the movie is titled Inception, and that is what it is. the entire movie is Mal planting an inception in Cobb. This is why she is in every dream. They are stil on the floor asleep.

revision.text: furthermore, this can explain the inaccuracy of the totem test.

revision.text: 99% of the movie is a dream. Cobb is only in reality once he wakes up on the plane at the end. He was probably off on a business trip, on a plane ride home and fell asleep. His subconsious put everyone on the plane in his dream, etc. That's just my theory

revision.text: The entire movie couldnt be a dream. If you want to believe that, think of when he takes here into his dream. If the whole movie was a dream, she would be his projection so when he takes her into his dream the projections would have no reason to attack her but they did and he wouldnt will the things to attack her so she was not part of him at all and not a projection. Now we can assume that he was not in a dream the whole movie and his wife is really dead

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-24.125.52.38-20100727030609]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-24.125.52.38-20100727030609]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsonius]...
revision.text:
The top could be an indicator of Cobb's mental perception of his very existence; if he knows that he is in a dream (such as when he descends to the second, third, and fourth layers of his dreams), the top will never fall. If he believes that he is in reality, then the top will fall. For the one and only scene where the top does fall, he is absolutely sure that he is in reality. But the end scene would suggest that he is unsure that seeing his children is real; therefore, the top does not waiver. Only till the very end does the top seem to wobble before the credits roll, signifying he may be slowly accepting the reunion with his children as reality. I think the above metaphor would more likely support that it is all a dream. Even the reality of the top that indicates whether he's dreaming or not may be a figment of his subconscious, placed within the realm of his existence as how he is perceiving the world in which he resides.
I am privied to believe that it is a dream, based on other user's input supporting such a theory (Cobb stealing the totem from Mal, the children never aging, etc.). Cobb accepting the reality that people can share dreams seems like a wild construct that could never exist in real life, which infers that he is likely in a dream the whole movie.

revision.comment: Created page with 'I don't understand how Eames is in Fischer's office observing Browning to begin with. Is this a dream? If not how could (presumably) Saito maneuver him into position in a matter …'
revision.text: I don't understand how Eames is in Fischer's office observing Browning to begin with. Is this a dream? If not how could (presumably) Saito maneuver him into position in a matter of days? The possibility that he was conveniently already positioned high in the company ranks is far too... convenient. The last point in the movie where we see Cobb's totem spin and then come to rest is just after Cobb's dream with Ariadne where she is stabbed by Mal. Is everything beginning with the Mombasa scene all dream? Is Eames a complete fabrication (projection)?

revision.text: Another bit of evidence supporting Cobb still being in a dream at the end: The kids were not only in the same clothes, but also in the same position that he kept seeing them in the whole movie.

revision.text:
basically the ending symbolizes that Cobb has accepted this as his reality regardless of wheather its true or not. he spins the top and walks away letting go of his totem and the fight to figure reality out.
another view is that it is in fact a dream but the wobble at the end is actully his dream becoming reality. we saw all of the men in the Chemists basement who's "dreams have come their reality" that would explain the totem starting to fail

revision.comment: Created page with 'Best character of the film who is part of one of the best fight sceens of all time. How many characters have kicked a guys ass on the wall the celling then while floating? He sho…'
revision.text: Best character of the film who is part of one of the best fight sceens of all time. How many characters have kicked a guys ass on the wall the celling then while floating? He shows his humorous flirty side when he asks the architect (ellen page) to kiss him and she says something like "there still looking." He then replies with a great line of "it was worth a try." Genius. What a guy. 10/10 all round the board for this film it well and truly is a masterpiece.

revision.comment: moved [[Talk:Inception Reviews/@comment-92.16.10.217-20100727194626]] to [[User blog comment:Bastian964/Inception Reviews/@comment-92.16.10.217-20100727194626]]: This needs comments to be worth it
revision.text: Before this movie was released i was split in opinion on this film. Would it be a huge success and a nolan masterpiece along side the dark knight or would it be a disapointment like avatar? As I was sat in the cinema watching the opening moments I was confussed and moments later I understud everything and the film had griped me I couldnt look away. The story, the action, the characters, acting and effects was great and I loved it. And the the soundtrack, what a job by Hanz Zimmer. I liked Avatar at first then I opened my eyes and realised it lacked anythingits a very simple film, a family or muck about film unlike inception which is a deep, emotional experience only the dark knight and the lord of the rings can compaire. See this film DONT MISS THE END FOR THE LOVE OF GOD DONT MISS THE END! 10/10 Favorite film by far. ps. Download the track time by Hanz Zimmer if you have seen the last film you should fing this emotionaly gripping

revision.text:
In response to the first part of supporting evidence
"The top wobbles. At the very end, right before the cut to black, the top can be seen and heard wobbling slightly. This points to the top falling over right after the cut, and would mean that Cobb's reality test worked -- he's in real life. "
The top was on a crack in the table. Please comment if you saw the same thing. To me this was done so that no one can truly tell if it is reality or not.

revision.text: I believe he did get out. The wedding ring missing from his hand and the different clothes on the children are clues to this. If I remember correctly, the kids are wearing different clothes during the ending. In his memories, Philipa is wearing a dress with shoulder straps, but in the ending she has a white top under the dress. Also James looks like his shirt has a slight variation flannel pattern, as well as different shoes. Christopher Nolan likely kept it almost the same, so as to make you question if Cobb is still in the dream. The ending itself is "inception" performed on the whole audience, planting the notion that Cobb may still be in the dream world =p

page.title: User blog:Red Dog31/The Dark Knight vs Inception

revision.comment: Created First Blog: The Dark Knight vs Inception
revision.text:
Well, for my very first blog, I decided to talk about which film is better: The Dark Knight or our very own Inception. Well, to start off, let's see the plots/genre of each film. Inception is a Sci-Fi Thriller and tells the story of Dom Cobb, a thief who specializes in the art of Extraction (stealing ideas from the sub-conscious). Dom is then offered a chance at redemption, gaining his old life back, if he does one last job that involves the art of Inception (planting of ideas).
The Dark Knight, on the other hand, is a superhero thriller, and continues the story from Batman Begins. In it, a new menace known as the Joker, is planning on throwing Gotham City into Anarchy and it is up to Batman to stop him.
Now, both films were directed and written by Christopher Nolan, so it's no wonder that it's a tough decision to decide which movie is better. Well, after careful consideration, I'm going to have to go with the Dark Knight. I personally found the story a little more interesting than that of Inception, plus I doubt Inception will be as successful. Another point is that NO ONE can beat Heath Ledger's acting as The Joker.[[User:Red Dog31|Red Dog31]] 16:06, July 28, 2010 (UTC) [[Category:Blog posts]]

revision.text: If you remember the beginning of the movie, where Cobb was inside Saito's dream within a dream. When they wake up from the dream within the dream Saito doesn't wake up from the dream within the dream in the place that he fell asleep originally. He also doesn't realize that he is in the dream until he goes on the carpet. Therefore if Cobb were to wake up from the dream within the dream within the dream within the dream which all of the kicks allowed him to do, he would wake up in a foreign place and not the place of which he fell asleep in. This theory would put him into the real world and the top would fall over. Unless, of coarse the whole time he was in the dream world/limbo.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-97.92.57.130-20100728203755]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-97.92.57.130-20100728203755]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsonius]...
revision.text: When he spins it and it falls down, it doesn't necessarily mean that he is out of the dream world. He said that the top would stop SPINNING when he is out of the dream world. When he spins the top, it fall off the sink. That might cause the stopping of the spinning. He could still be in the dream world when it fell.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-72.144.234.133-20100728204736]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-72.144.234.133-20100728204736]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samson...
revision.text: I personaly think that it doesnt matter if he was or wasnt in the dream at the end because he was happy. he came to terms with his wife his whole mission had been finished in my opinion this was like a lunar oposite to the end of shutter island (another Movie Di Caprio was in that had a simalar end in which the whole time he was in a personal fanstasy that he lived out in real life) i say that if he was dreaming he would be happy and if he was in reality then he would still be happy for the rest of his life so in my opinion it was a happy ending (unless you think of him waking up and Saito not keeping his promise and Cobb going to prison a better ending)

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-132.234.251.211-20100729003324]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-132.234.251.211-20100729003324]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Sams...
revision.text: I believe the at least the end scene (if not the entire movie) was a dream. I think the top may have wobbled because Cobb finally managed to see his kid’s faces, being content with the reality presented to him he believed it to be the real world which allowed the top to behave somewhat normally. Also if dreams within a dream are substantially less stable and normalised then the level above, then the level above what the characters normally interpret as a dream should be the most stable.

page.title: User blog comment:Red Dog31/The Dark Knight vs Inception/@comment-Ozzyjalo94-20100729010414

revision.comment: Created page with 'I agree about Heath Ledgers performance (go Aussie! RIP, mate) and about the box office success, but I think that Inception's plot was marginally better than the Dark Knights (th…'
revision.text: I agree about Heath Ledgers performance (go Aussie! RIP, mate) and about the box office success, but I think that Inception's plot was marginally better than the Dark Knights (they are both brilliant though). I think that they are similar in many ways, I watched The Dark Knight again yesterday, and both movies have a similar feel. The score... well, I liked Inception's better, but I don't think that either of the film's scores are particularly good, at least by Zimmer's normal standards. But hey, we're pretty lucky to have someone like Nolan out there, keeping cinema originality alive.

revision.comment: moved [[Talk:Inception Reviews/@comment-209.129.16.5-20100729205946]] to [[User blog comment:Bastian964/Inception Reviews/@comment-209.129.16.5-20100729205946]]: This needs comments to be worth it
revision.text: Good movie. Great? Sure. But can someone please tell me why - for all the complexity of the movie throughout - the Asian guy's character was never developed? He holds all the power, supposedly, and yet we never can appreciate who he is and where he came from. Major fault of the movie, IMHO. To cloak it in mystery is a insulting to the audience member's intelligence. Otherwise, I agree with the good reviews.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-98.226.131.113-20100729234425]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-98.226.131.113-20100729234425]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samson...
revision.text:
I believe thats Dom's totem only symbolizes whether or not Dom believes that what he is experiencing is reality. He only spun his totem when he was proving or making sure he was , where he was. Like when he was explaing to Ari how the totem worked he believed that he was in reality so it fell. But when he entered a dream he spun it to make sure he was in a dream therefor it never stopped. I believe the totem is actually a distraction to allow us to use this as a connection to whether or not we are seeing a dream or reality. I believe the entire more is actually preforming inception on us. Then again I could easily be wrong.
-Zack

{{Infobox_actor |name = Taylor Geare |birthname = Taylor Grace Geare |born = September 19, 2001 |nationality = American |gender = Female |eye = Hazel |hair = Blonde |height = 3 feet 11 in. |yearsactive = 2007-present |inceptionrole = [[Phillipa Cobb]] |image = Taylor Geare.png |imagesize = 200px}} {{stub}} '''Taylor Geare''' is an American child actress. She plays the role of the older [[Phillipa Cobb]] in the [[Christopher Nolan]] film [[Inception (2010 film)|Inception]]. She is also the sister of [[Claire Geare]], who plays the younger Phillipa, and [[Johnathan Geare]], who plays the older [[James Cobb]]. revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-99.32.40.115-20100731045219]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-99.32.40.115-20100731045219]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsonius]...
revision.text:
Here's an idea, the first scene is the end of the first iteration of a sequence of a cycle of dreams and then we see the sequence starting over again. Now, the first few scenes with Saito are "real" (ie. they are literal memories). Think about after they are captured by Saito (or possibly when Saito realized he was dreaming don't recall which), but doesn't Saito tell them that they'll regret what they've done. AND we know that Saito knows about dreaming which we saw in the scene of them trying to have him as a mark.
So, what if the entire thing is Saito setting up Cobb up into a dream world and forcing him into limbo as a punishment for Saito being targeted at the beginning. And thus it's really like limbo, Cobb has to live in a seeming eternity (years pass in limbo for every minute in reality) without living or dying and having to question everything he believes. At which point all of the other theories given about how Mal etc are trying to get him to wake up would make sense and fall into place. But at the end, he'd still be in the dream, because remember we see Saito agreeing to wake up together, but unlike every other time that someone is kicked out of the dream we don't actually see the two of them kicked out of the dream. They just arrive back on the plane.
The first scene when he comes up on the beach is slightly different than the last one because each time he goes through the sequence of events his mind tries slightly different outcomes and scenarios, but the main events stay similar since he sub-consciously realizes that he's in a dream that started with his encounter with Saito.
Even if he does someday break free of the cycle, think of the psychological repercussions. As happened with his wife (possibly a memory), he'd lose all sense of what is real and what is not.

page.title: User blog comment:Red Dog31/The Dark Knight vs Inception/@comment-97.120.42.152-20100801003444

revision.comment: Created page with 'I prefer "Inception" because the character development in "The Dark Knight" felt unbalanced. In the latter film, Batman was clearly the main character because he had the most scr…'
revision.text: I prefer "Inception" because the character development in "The Dark Knight" felt unbalanced. In the latter film, Batman was clearly the main character because he had the most screentime. Yet Nolan was clearly more interested in the Joker; in fact, it seems that the only thing Batman does is react to that cackling menace. He's not a distinctive character in himself. By contrast, "Inception" is thoroughly invested in the lead character of Dom Cobb, who is a compelling figure, wracked with guilt (over what happened to Mal) and desire (to be with his children).

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-67.60.203.51-20100801102503]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-67.60.203.51-20100801102503]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsonius]...
revision.text:
For everyone asking about Mal being in so many peoples' dreams:
She is a projection of Cobb's subconscious, so ANY dream that Cobb is in, whether it's his or someone else's, at least has the potential to have her in it - remember, the subject populates the dream.
For example, when Ariadne is stabbed by Mal, it is Ariadne's dream, but Cobb is the subject. In the Chemist's dream (the raining van level) Cobb's subconscious brings in the train, and Fischer's subconscious brings in a security fore to defend his mind - multiple subjects, multiple subconsciousnesses, and multiple projections all from different people.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-90.203.188.112-20100801163446]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-90.203.188.112-20100801163446]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samson...
revision.text:
All arguments seem interesting and logical here.
Just a quick thought though - what I find interesting is how Cobb spins "his totem" in the end on the table and walks off to be with his father-in-law and children WITHOUT stopping to wait and see/going back to check on the totem's outcome.
Could this mean that he has either
1) - Accepted limbo as his new reality, as all he ever wanted to do was end the inception mission he told Saito in the helicopter was possible and achieve his "freedom"
2) Definitely entered an infinite loop of his projections (father in law, kids) but is unaware of it and will stay there
3) Is in fact in reality (No ring, changes in kids)
Those are the three things to decipher it seems :S.
- But I think the fact that Cobb spins the top and walks off without looking is crucial for some reason.
What's the source?

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-71.54.105.148-20100801200403]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-71.54.105.148-20100801200403]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsoniu...
revision.text:
Could it be that Nolan left just enough in the movie to support multiple theories? Quotes from Nolan's "The Prestige":
Cutter: Now you're looking for the secret. But you wont find it because of course, you're not really looking. You don't really want to work it out. You want to be, fooled
Robert Angier: You never understood, why we did this. The audience knows the truth: the world is simple. It's miserable, solid all the way through. But if you could fool them, even for a second, then you can make them wonder, and then you... then you got to see something really special... you really don't know?... it was... it was the look on their faces...
Just a thought -Beeker

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-128.103.221.1-20100801231930]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-128.103.221.1-20100801231930]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsoniu...
revision.text:
A couple questions:
1. Why does Ariadne's character go from limbo to the 3rd dream level when she kills herself in limbo, when Cobb went back to "reality" when he killed himself on the train tracks in limbo and later again when Cobb and Saito supposedly kill themselves?
2. How could Fischer's subconscious create an army to defend itself, while none of the other highly-trained extractors (Cobb, Arthur, etc.) create any army to defend themselves?
Something seems amiss to me.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-12.70.120.167-20100802010106]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-12.70.120.167-20100802010106]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsoniu...
revision.text:
I didn't read everything here... but has anyone touched on the idea that the inception in the whole movie is not for the person you think it is? Its actually for Cobb to believe the world he is in is a dream or something of that nature?
Also the movie makes a special point with infinity... the spinning top, the mirrors... After all, the only way to see if a top spins forever is to wait forever... So its essentially impossible. Not to mention that it isn't even his totem. So who knows if he really knows how it works. The fact that he doesn't have a totem could also mean he is lost.
Also, everyone entered Limbo very easily... seems like it wouldn't be easy to get there.
Counltess references also seem to point to the idea that as someone put it... Cobb needs to "wake up to reality." This is backed up by the idea that everyone almost seems as if they are there to save Cobb.
Also, when he goes to get the "Forger" he is attacked much like he is in a dream and the defenses are trying to get him.
I also found it weird his father was waiting for him at the airport.
Perhaps the only way out of limbo is through suicide...
I guess the point I am trying to make is that it almost seems like the whole movie is limbo... stuck in infinity. And maybe the totem at the end finally works correctly because his projection sees it for what it is... that is... if he looks at it/wants to accept its reality because now his "dreams have come true" of going home and being with his kids and moving on in his life.
This is a category for pages on how the dream world works. [[Category:Technology]]

revision.comment: Created page with 'Thank you, Bastian964. Finally, an appropriate use of article comments! Yea! By the way, you are doing a great job!'
revision.text: Thank you, Bastian964. Finally, an appropriate use of article comments! Yea! By the way, you are doing a great job!

[[File:Secondkick.jpg|thumb|400px|Cobb's team is woken by being driven into a river.]] {{Quote|''It's that feeling of falling you get that jolts you awake. It snaps you out of a dream.''|||[[Cobb]]}}
One method used to awaken from a dream within a dream is called a "'''kick'''", which is the sensation of falling, hitting water, or a sharp jolt that can startle the [[Sleeper|sleeper]] awake.
A kick is usually performed on one's sleeping body, not one's body in the dream within the dream. However, in order to wake a sleeper when using a sedative that allows [[Dream-Sharing|shared dreaming]] within multiple-level [[The Dreams|dreams]], only synchronized kicks can create enough impact to wake a sleeper. When dreaming three or four levels deep, synchronized kicks require the sleeper to experience a kick on their bodies within the innermost dream, and on all dream levels where their body is sleeping. Thus it becomes increasingly difficult to synchronize kicks and requires significant planning. Due to the time-dilation caused by dreaming multiple levels deep, a kick that occurs instantaneously in a higher level will last longer in a lower level, thereby making it easier to synchronize a kick.
Playing a musical cue in the ears of a sleeper is an effective way to warn one of an incoming kick and coordinate multiple kicks.

[[File:dreamer.png|thumb|right|300px|[[Arthur]] is the dreamer of the [[The Hotel (dream)|Hotel dream]]]] {{Quote|''Remember, you are the dreamer, you build this world.''|||[[Cobb]]}} Within a [[Dream-Sharing|shared dream]] one person must take on the role of the '''Dreamer'''.
The dreamer's role is to construct and maintain a [[The Dreams|dream space]]. Often the dreamer will add personal touches to his or her own dreams. A dreamer's base desires, like the need to go to the bathroom, can unconsciously affect the dream.
The dreamer constructs a space that the [[subject]] can then populate with their subconscious in the form of [[projections]]. If the subject's subconscious ever suspects that he or she is in a dream controlled by outside forces, then the projections will seek out and kill the dreamer and any other foreign presence.
While [[Sleepers|other sleepers]] can manipulate reality in a dream to some degree, only the dreamer can adjust the architecture of the dream.
==Dreamers in the Film== * [[Dominic Cobb|Dom Cobb]] - [[Dom's Memories (Dream)|Dom's Memories]], Possibly other scenes in the film * [[Arthur]] - [[The Palace (Dream)|The Palace]], [[Penrose Stairs (Dream)|Penrose Stairs]], [[The Hotel (Dream)|The Hotel]] * [[Ariadne]] - [[Paris Streets (Dream)|Paris Streets]], [[Paris Cafe (Dream)|Paris Cafe]] * [[Eames]] - [[The Mountain (Dream)|The Mountain]] * [[Yusuf]] - [[The City (Dream)|The City]] * [[Nash]] - [[The Apartment (Dream)|The Apartment]]
==References== <references/> [[Category:Dream Mechanics]]

{{Quote|''I am the subject, my mind populates it. You can literally talk to my subconscious.''|||[[Cobb]]}}
Within a [[Dream-Sharing|shared dream]] one person must take on the role of the "'''subject'''."
The subject's role is to populate the [[The Dreams|dream space]] created by the [[dreamer]] with [[Projections|projections]] of his or her own subconscious. If the subject feels that he or she is being manipulated in any way, the projections will seek out and kill the dreamer. The subject subconsciously fills in details that would be impossible for the dreamer to construct.
The method of [[Extraction]] takes full advantage of the fact that the subject's mind fills in these details. Oftentimes the subject will try to hide secrets within the dream space that an extractor can then discover and steal.
One can be trained to defend against extraction, this training usually manifests itself in the form of militarized projections. ==Subjects in the Film== *[[Robert Fischer]] - [[The City (Dream)|The City]], [[The Hotel (Dream)|The Hotel]], [[The Mountain (Dream)|The Mountain]] *[[Saito]] - [[The Apartment (Dream)|The Apartment]], [[The Palace (Dream)|The Palace]] *[[Ariadne]] - [[Penrose Stairs (Dream)|Penrose Stairs]] *[[Dominic Cobb|Dom Cobb]] - [[Paris Streets (Dream)|Paris Streets]]

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-122.2.81.136-20100802160817]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-122.2.81.136-20100802160817]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsonius]...
revision.text:
The thing is, the top is not Cobb's totem originally, it's Mal's. So it made me wonder what Cobb's totem is before when Mal was still alive.
I watched the movie again and again, then it made me realize what Cobb's totem really is (or I'd like to think so.) Its his wedding ring.
Every time Cobbs is in a dream, you'll see a ring on his hand, and every time he's in the real world, the ring isn't there.
In the final scene, Cobbs spun the top on the table, you'll see that there is no ring on his finger. so my case in point is, he's in the real world, everything worked out.
The ring actually had substantial amount of screen time in the movie so maybe Nolan wants the viewers to realize this.

revision.text:
if we think about it Cobbs always ask "how did you get here" at end it shows cobs getting off the plane to picking up his bags to showing the passport.. this tells me that he is back in reality...
also i do like the idea that his "father in law" may have made the inception on his son to get Cobbs to get over his wifes death and come home to the kids. If you think about it his father in law introduced him to the new architect that actually help Cobbs get over his wife. It was weird that he was being chased by an unnamed group of people. Just a theory anyways.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-121.223.19.104-20100803014034]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-121.223.19.104-20100803014034]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samson...
revision.text: Cobb was wanted for the murder of his wife in the US, but I never thought that sufficiently explained why there was a small army of guys after him when he went to get the "forger" in a foreign country. I think the over the top chase scene when he almost gets stuck between the narrow space between two buildings is a clue that he is not in reality. His wife also confronts him in limbo about his paranoia about people chasing him.

revision.comment: Created page with 'DiCaprio may be the official star of the movie, but Arthur is easily the most entertaining, likeable, badass character of them all. And Joseph Gordon-Levitt is absolutely stunnin…'
revision.text: DiCaprio may be the official star of the movie, but Arthur is easily the most entertaining, likeable, badass character of them all. And Joseph Gordon-Levitt is absolutely stunning in his performance, highlighting the subtleties of the character so that we know exactly who he is, even though Arthur never actually gives anything away about himself.
