[[File:lucid dreaming.png|thumb|right|325px|[[Ariadne]] realizes she is dreaming]] "'''Lucid Dreaming'''" is when a [[Sleeper|sleeper]] realizes that they are in a [[The Dreams|dream]]. It is possible for a sleeper to attain lucidity within a dream by having their attention drawn to the strangeness of the dream (the [[Mr. Charles (tactic)|Mr. Charles]] tactic is an example of this) or already knowing that they are [[Dream-Sharing]]. One method for checking the artificiality of a dream is through the use of a [[Totem|totem]].
While lucid dreaming in a normal dream it is possible to control the dream. A [[Dreamer]] can control a dream while Dream-Sharing whether they are lucid or not, but being lucid allows them to control a dream consciously.
It is also possible for one to lose their lucidity by becoming "lost" within a dream. This can happen through several methods including by dying within a dream and waking in [[Limbo]] with no bearing for reality, or by inserting memories into one's dream, and mistaking them for reality.
[[es:Sueño lúcido]] [[Category:Dream Mechanics]]

revision.comment: Created page with "While I was editing other wikis I discovered an interesting function called toggling. It can be use for things like switching between pictures of a character from different sourc…"
revision.text: While I was editing other wikis I discovered an interesting function called toggling. It can be use for things like switching between pictures of a character from different sources (Cobol Job, The Big Under, or Inception), hiding text, hiding pictures, or switching what text is displayed. This would allow us to include pictures from different sources in an infobox. Various improved versions of a toggle template can be found [http://onepiece.wikia.com/wiki/Template:Toggle here] though the base template originally came from [http://openwetware.org/wiki/Template:Toggle here]. An example of its use in infoboxes can be found [http://onepiece.wikia.com/wiki/Hawkins here]. [[Category:Blog posts]]

revision.comment: Created page with "I agee with the comments stating that the spinning top was not Cobb's totem. I don't recall a ring, maybe on second viewing I will, but the top was Mal's, and I recall Cobb ment…"
revision.text: I agee with the comments stating that the spinning top was not Cobb's totem. I don't recall a ring, maybe on second viewing I will, but the top was Mal's, and I recall Cobb mentioning no one else can touch your totem. Make's me wonder if the whole thing was Mal's dream and if Cobb was the constructed subconscious (or whatever they referred to as the actors in someone's dream) especially since the other family characters were from her side of the family. What a great movie - so many interpretations! Christy in TX

My question is if the ring was Dom's totem then why did he always have to question if he was in reality? All he'd have to do is look at his hand. Not trying alter everyone's interp, but some of these have holes in their logic...

revision.comment: Created page with "They told me that they did. They obviously didn't but they were able to get rid of the badges. Oh, and the toggle system is already in effect on the Avatar wiki, I implemented th…"
revision.text: They told me that they did. They obviously didn't but they were able to get rid of the badges. Oh, and the toggle system is already in effect on the Avatar wiki, I implemented them on the [http://james-camerons-avatar.wikia.com/wiki/Jake_Sully Jake Sully], [http://james-camerons-avatar.wikia.com/wiki/Dr._Grace_Augustine Grace Augustine], and [http://james-camerons-avatar.wikia.com/wiki/Norm_Spellman Norm Spellman] character pages. They work very well in this context since these characters are seen in two forms in the film. I think it could work on this wiki as well, so I'll be implementing the toggle feature into the templates soon.

revision.text:
THE CHILDREN DID AGE PEOPLE!.
First of all, they are NOT wearing the exact same clothes, the girls has white sleeves on her dress at the end, and the kids have different shoes. During the credits, they have FOUR actors playing his kids. The first set says something like 3 years(girl), 20 months(boy). The second set says 5 years(girl), 3 years(boy). They age TWO years.
In the dreams, the top spins smoothly. At the end, it starts to wobble.
And Cobb KNOWS how he got to his house.

revision.text: The Totem itself is problematic at best. When Cobb talks about the making and using of a totem, he clearly states how important it is that NO ONE ever touches YOUR totom. This is a problem because the top isn't even Cobb's totem...it's his wife's
FInally :)

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-Bastian964-20100814010554]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-Bastian964-20100814010554]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsonius]]" t...
revision.text: His wife is dead so that isn't a problem. A totem works the way it does because people who don't know it well are unable to give it the right weight or balance. Thus it only has the right balance in the real world, the dreams of anyone who knows it well, and Limbo (since in Limbo all sleepers are dreamers). The reason you don't want anyone to touch your totem is that while it is easy to tell if you are in your own dream or Limbo since both allow you to manipulate the dream, telling if your in someone else's dream is only possible if they make a blatant mistake or they don't know your totem. Thus it doesn't matter that Mal touched the totem previously because she is now dead and thus can't dream.

I would love help and anyone who wants to edit can. Please be warned that there will be major '''spoilers''' on those pages since we're working from [http://inceptionmovie.warnerbros.com/deviantart/thebigunder.pdf the script]. ==Inception: The Big Under Additions to Pre-existing Articles. Spoiler Alert==
This is an area for the creation of additions to pre-existing articles relating to [[Inception: The Big Under]] before the comic itself is release. Be warned that since these are created from [http://inceptionmovie.warnerbros.com/deviantart/thebigunder.pdf the script] this page contains major spoilers. Read at your own risk. Anyone may edit these if they so wish but please treat these respectfully. While these are not full articles, coming up with additions still should be a relatively serious task. Comments should be left in the designated section. Note, the [[Inception: The Big Under]] article is actually listed under [[User:Bastian964/Sandbox/Big Under Articles|Big Under Articles]] since the current one is basically a place holder. :'''Tadashi'''

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-74.192.103.95-20100815031741]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-74.192.103.95-20100815031741]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsoniu...
revision.text: There is enough doubt, but assuming the top doesn't fall he has been dreaming all along. When he left limbo he never left the dream world. The idea of stages only work when you are using different people for each level, and death awakenings you to the previous level. The Architect constructs the levels for the dreamers to use. Cobb and Mal simply went deeper and deeper within their own subconscious, presumably without such measures. As Cobb is the best and Mal invented the idea of totems, this is not implausible. If we cannot know just how deep limbo is situated in relation to reality, other than the bottom, there is no sure way to say that they awoke to reality, instead of just a higher level of the dream. Assuming this, one can make claim that the teams inception into Fisher is simply a clever Inception by Cobb's own subconscious as a way of ridding itself of Cobb's guilt. "You have to forgive yourself" "You have to confront her" "Let her go" His own mind is effectively tricking him into staying in the dream state, but he is no longer miserable (Everyone craves catharsis). There are other points to support this theory as well.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-122.107.94.147-20100815095709]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-122.107.94.147-20100815095709]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samson...
revision.text:
there are so many interesting facets of this film as whether he is still dreaming or in fact returned to reality.
i've only seen the film once and i intend to extensively dissect it when it comes out on dvd. which is why i choose not to draw a conclusion, because there's so much evidence for both sides.
but with regards to totems, i don't think anyone has considered that Doms children could be his totems, because the top is Mal's and the wedding ring theory. because we see the children weaving throughout the levels and eventually into limbo and then at the end of the film we find that they've aged and stuff, which could be why he disregards the top and assume's that he is in reality because his children are different from what Dom's subconscious tells him.
i'm loving all these theories! christopher nolan is a genius, i think that's a conclusion we can draw upon. - ana

revision.text:
wait, i just realised realised how my theory above couldn't work. well maybe it can. hm .. maybe all the symbols of the top, wedding ring and children contribute...
this film is so post-modernist, my brain is going to explode.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-122.107.94.147-20100815120915]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-122.107.94.147-20100815120915]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samson...
revision.text:
i'm the same user that's posted the last 2. so with my time i've spent i've made a massive graph and i'm proposing another theory. i don't necessarily believe it, but i think it's just interesting.
1. the dreamer can be led to believe that his dreams are in fact a reality. 2. some users above state that ones subconscious can will the outcome of ones totem, so reality is relative. 3. in the film, cobb discusses how he and mal were exploring. but couldn't they only go 2 dreams deep because it was only two of them? therefore that's how they got to 'limbo' so quickly. 4. once returning from 'limbo'. after being incepted by cobb, mal refuses to believe that their present 'reality' is infact a 'reality' which is why she commits suicide, whilst cobb remains in that 'reality'.
so with these factors in mind this theory is if we revert back to Mal + Dom the sequence would be somewhat like this: Dream 1 -> Mal's Dream where Mal accepts this reality and awaits Dom Dream 2 -> where Dom is stuck in dream 2 because his subconscious decieves him to believe that it is his reality. then 'Limbo' where they escaped via death, after sharing 50 years together.
So dream 2, is thus where the rest of the film takes place. because without Mal, Dom goes into the 'extracting' business and all the other main characters are manifestations of his subconscious.
but there are so many arguments that can be made against this theory. which is why i love this movie. haha
-ana

I looked at IMDB for mention or Paulson and Josh McFarland in Inception and couldn't find either. I didn't see mention of him on the Wikipedia site either. Where does he come from? <font face="Papyrus" style="Background:#8300A3" size=3>'''[[User:Skxwang|<font color="00AAFF">S</font><font color="teal">k</font><font color="00AAFF">x</font>]][[User talk:Skxwang|<font color="teal">w</font><font color="00AAFF">a</font><font color="teal">n</font><font color="00AAFF">g</font>]]'''</font> 12:38, August 15, 2010 (UTC)
No idea, I don't recall anyone called Paulson from the movie, I couldn't find any mention of his or McFarland anywhere, it's like he doesn't exist. When I see the movie again I'll sit through the credits and see if he's there. [[User:Ozzyjalo94|Ozzyjalo94]] 03:03, August 16, 2010 (UTC)
Neither of them is listed [http://www.fanpix.net/credits/2964129/inception-cast-and-crew.html on this Inception Cast and Crew list]. I vote delete. [[User:Bastian964|Bastian]][[User_talk:Bastian964|9]][[Special:Contributions/Bastian964|6]][[Special:Editcount/Bastian964|4]] 04:20, August 17, 2010 (UTC)
Same here. <font face="Calibri" size=3>'''[[User:Ozzyjalo94|<font color="#BF0000">OZ</font>]][[User talk:Ozzyjalo94|<font color="#BF0000">ZY</font>]]'''</font> 05:53, August 17, 2010 (UTC)

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-115.147.229.215-20100815133117]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-115.147.229.215-20100815133117]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Sams...
revision.text: the truth is quite simple actually. the movie "Inception" is an autobiographical film which merely reiterates to the audience how Chrisopher Nolan came up with this enjoyable flick. None of whatever happens in the movie is real. Its all merely a by-product of Nolan's imagination [or capacity to plagiarize if you know what im talking about.(Unca Scrooge anyone?)]

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-115.147.203.245-20100815134545]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-115.147.203.245-20100815134545]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Sams...
revision.text:
As for the supposed ending. I'd like to think that there really isnt any definite answer. Its impossible to know for sure what has (or rather has not) really transpired towards the end. Evidence towards both outcomes are solid.
My solid guess is this movie has the objective for unmasking our personalities/desires/outlooks on life.(optimist/pessimist basically). IMO though there really isnt what we can call a "bad" or "sad" ending. It doesnt really matter whether Dom's fulfillment of his desires can be considered under the realm of reality, as long as he perceives his current favorable predicament "reality" then there should be no problem. this is after all his story (well maybe the wife too, but whether she lives or dies as a result of her jumping off the building midway through the film shouldnt really affect her disposition towards Dom's status at the movies end) -Anonymous user 13:31, August 15, 2010

revision.text: If the top falls, that doesn't necessarily mean he's awake. He knows the properties of the top, so it would fall the same way in his own dream as if he were in real life. If the top falls, that just means he's not in someone else's dream, but then it's still a 50/50 chance that he's either in his own dream or in reality. (if the interpretation of the totem on this website is true)

revision.text:
Not sure if this has already been pointed out but the children arent the same age at the end. To the point that they are played by different actors in the two stages (i.e. Phillipa age 3 and Phillipa age 5).
If Cobb was on run for 2 years they wouldnt have changed radically. The similar/same clothing was merely symbolistic and an artistic decision.
The top falls :)

revision.text: my issue with the totems is that you only see Cobb use his totem. he tells the others to make their own, and they do, but we only witness Cobb using his. what's up with that?

revision.text: The lack of scenes depicting the use of other Totems adds to the mystery of the whole Totem concept. As we know so little about them, we are likely to debate about them and make our opinions known (as has happened here), and people will be more inclined to watch the movie again to see if they can spot anything that they might have missed about the Totems, resulting in more money being made by the moviemakers.

revision.text:
honestly u guys? no human being is intelligent enough to create a script for a movie like this, with the idea in mind that the whole thing is a dream, or soem other silly theory like that. by coming up with all these theories, you are ruining this movie for yourselves.
the ending is jsut an ending. if the movie ended simply with cob seeing his kids again-thats not intresting. and its not a good sumary to the movie. the whole film is about dreams and reality, and not knowing which one ur in-thats wat the ending did for us. it almost puts us in the characters mindset. a movie is a process. dont ruin the process by thinking so much about 'whats really going on'.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-75.82.60.32-20100818100506]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-75.82.60.32-20100818100506]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsonius]]"...
revision.text: Just because it wasn't Cobb's totem originally doesn't mean it is a dream. The reason you keep your totem to yourself is because someone else can dream it up if they know it. However, if you are in their dream, they won't know the way that totem is special (the top falls, the dice are weighted, etc.) THAT'S why you have to have your own totem; so no one else can replicate it and you will always know if you're in a dream.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-193.188.105.20-20100818173753]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-193.188.105.20-20100818173753]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samson...
revision.text:
Here's my theory:
It doesn’t matter whether Cobb was in the real world or still dreaming. That wasn’t the point of the director's ending; the point was to make us question reality. Make u...s question whether he was still dreaming or not – to plant a seed of doubt in every audience member’s mind as to whether to﻿ believe or not. He successfully planted that idea in everyone’s mind, and achieved .. exactly what his movie is about: inception. The entire message of the movie, culminated, proven, in a final scene.
What I'm trying to say, is the director did inception on us. The ending wasn't supposed to matter, whether he was dreaming or not.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-72.94.198.56-20100819021512]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-72.94.198.56-20100819021512]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsonius]...
revision.text: A refutation of 'the end is real' end theory. If Cobb is in reality - then he would have had to have dreamed the future because he see his children in his dreams in the same positions as they are in reality. Its not just that he sees them - it's that if that is reality he would have had to have dreamed the future.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-72.94.198.56-20100819021803]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-72.94.198.56-20100819021803]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsonius]...
revision.text: In support of the 'it is a dream at the end' theory. Another interpretation of them all being in a dream at the end of the movie is that the entire thing was a dream sequence architected by Miles, perpetrated by Ariadne intended to incept the idea into Cobb's mind that he should forgive himself for his wife's death. And that they will all wake up shortly into reality. It is not necassary that just because the entire movie is a dream that Cobb stays in limbo. Miles incepted Cobb and will wake him up shortly to real reality.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-F0rg3r-20100819210301]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-F0rg3r-20100819210301]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsonius]]" to "[[Use...
revision.text: About the weding ring, you wear it on the wedding finger on your left hand, right? I just got back from seeing the film again for the fourth time tonight, I looked for it and I couldn't see his left hand at all as he rests it on the back of the chair before I could look for the ring. Therefore, I think it's reality.

revision.comment: Created page with "==A complete and utter lack of sourcing== This material will be on the talk page until such time that there is proof that it isn't the fanfic material it reads like. Anyone may…"
revision.text:
==A complete and utter lack of sourcing== This material will be on the talk page until such time that there is proof that it isn't the fanfic material it reads like. Anyone may modify the text in blockqoutes as long as they leave a message in this thread saying that they changed it. [[User:Bastian964|Bastian]][[User_talk:Bastian964|9]][[Special:Contributions/Bastian964|6]][[Special:Editcount/Bastian964|4]] 02:59, August 20, 2010 (UTC)
When Arthur was 2 years old, his father committed suicide and his mother died of cancer when he was 10. His mother never told him the truth about his father, and only told him that he had left them when Arthur was young. He lived with his grandpartents until he turned 18. Although Arthur was too young to remember his father's suicide, he would find himself having dreams of a strange man walking up to his room, and then hearing a gun go off. These dreams of his father's suicide are what motivated Arthur to become extremely interested in the dream world. Years later he found a man experienced in dream-sharing to help him confront this memory. Together the two adventured in Arthur's subconscious and found the truth about his father. Extremely touched and amazed by the dream sharing abilities, Arthur made himself available in the underground dream-sharing world. Arthur met Cobb 3 years before the events of the film take place. They met in Tokyo when Cobb was looking for a job. He came across a man who had helped Arthur with the dream of his father, and the man recommended Arthur to Cobb. Cobb had to look very hard for Arthur and when he did Arthur was very hostile. The two ended up engaging in a fight, because Arthur had though Cobb was sent by a corporation to kill him. When Cobb explained who he was, the two joined forces, and have been a team ever since.

revision.text: I think the end ties in with the beginning somehow. Remember at the beginning when Cobb washed up on shore and met up with Saito. Well the same thing happened at the end of the movie, so maybe in the beginning when they all get out of the dream world and end up in the train back in the real world means they all (including Cobb and Saito) made it out of the dream world and back to the real world.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-92.4.115.9-20100823081158]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-92.4.115.9-20100823081158]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsonius]]" t...
revision.text:
I think that it's reality, though if the WHOLE film was a dream then the character's development and journey has been explored. The thing is, if it's all a dream, the whole story becomes pointless. Back in 2009 when half of you probably didn't know about Inception, Christopher Nolan kept insisting that it was about Cobb's emotional journey and he never hinted that he wanted to make it a dream. Just because you don't see the top fall, it doesn't mean that it doesn't.
You've been Incepted.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-Empireparadox-20100823134607]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-Empireparadox-20100823134607]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsoniu...
revision.text: I think that Miles was behind the whole thing, I think he asked Adriane to keep him in a dream so that he could recover from his guilt. This is suggested because he asks "when is this going to stop?" and without much hesitation he immediately chooses Adriane. She picks up on it very quickly and ensures she joins him in his dream, she purposely puts Mal in the dream to send him to Limbo or a 4th dream state. He doesn't show how he gets from the dream to the plane but does for the other characters, suggesting they could be in reality but Cobb could be stuck in Limbo. Miles then joins the dream.

He can also help you spruce up your talk page by visiting his [[User_talk:Samsonius|talk page]]. * '''[[User:Matias_arana_10|Matias]]''' is the other co-founder of the wiki, and can be contacted for any type of help. * '''[[User:Skxwang|Skxwang]]''' is an admin of the wiki, and can help you with editing, grammar, and the like. |- | align="center" |[[File:Enjoy_Your_Stay_Text.png|link=]] |} == The Allegory of the Cave == Why did you copy paste the beginning section of the Allegory of the Cave article from Wikipedia to this Wikia? Firstly, that article has literally nothing to do with the movie that I can think of. Secondly, even if it was mentioned in the movie, it's still not really worthy of being in this wikia since for all we know the Allegory of the Cave in the Inceptionverse is completely different. Thirdly, if we were going to include it, we would make an article from an in universe perspective and not copy paste from Wikipedia. revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-64.229.222.80-20100827020359]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-64.229.222.80-20100827020359]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsoniu...
revision.text:
Adriane pulls the classic psychologist act and knows many things she shouldn't. Cobb says he's never met anyone who "picked it up so fast" and he's right. Adriane was never new to this. She also shows almost no character development and seems to be always nudging at Cobb to forgive himself/face Mal.
Why else would she do this? She's just supposed to be an intern curious about dream building.
This quote examplifies my point: Cobb: "Because building a dream from your memory is the easiest way of losing your grasp of what's real and what is a dream" Adriane: "Is that what happened to you?"

{{Infobox character |image=tadashi.png |imagesize=250px |name=Tadashi |born= |died= |lives= |gender=Male |status=Alive |eye= |family= |occupation=Unknown |loyalties= |portrayed=[[Tai-Li Lee]] |first=''[[Inception (2010 film)|Inception]]'' |last= }}
'''Tadashi''' was the 18 year old Japanese teenager who was employed by [[Arthur]] to help him, [[Nash]], and [[Dom]] with the attempted [[extraction]] on [[Saito]]'s mind. Before the extraction began, he was assigned to tail Saito in order to ascertain his movements and any other information about him.
On the bullet train to Tokyo, Saito is sedated to allow the extractors to enter his dreams. During the extraction, Tadashi is order to stand guard over their sleeping forms and operate the [[PASIV Device]]. About 30 seconds before they were due to wake up, Tadashi put headphones on Nash and played "Non, Je ne regrette rien" to alert him to the time. The three extractors woke up shortly afterward, and began arguing as the job was a failure. Cobb threw Tadashi some money and told them it was every man for himself, as he rushed to leave the train. Nash and Arthur exited the cabin afterward, leaving Saito to wake up and see only Tadashi reading his comic.
==External links== *[http://www.fanpix.net/credits/2964129/inception-cast-and-crew.html A list of the cast]
==References== <references/> [[Category:Characters]]

[[File:bullet train.jpg|thumb|right|250px|The Bullet Train]] '''The Bullet Train (real)''' is the location where [[Cobb]], [[Arthur]], and [[Nash]], with assistance from [[Tadashi]], attempted the [[The Saito Extraction Job|heist]] on [[Saito]]'s mind.
==Gallery== <gallery> Saito extraction.jpg|Arthur, Cobb, and Saito aboard the bullet train. </gallery> [[Category:Places]]

[[File:Saito extraction.jpg|thumb|300px|right|The Saito Extraction Job]] '''The Saito Extraction Job''' was the job undertaken by [[Dominic Cobb|Dom]], [[Arthur]], and [[Nash]] after the failure of [[The Kaneda Extraction Job]]. This job was in progress at the start of the movie with Nash in level 1 and Arthur, Dom, and [[Saito]], the subject, in level 2.
The job was mostly a failure, because Saito was already aware of the concept of extraction and had his subconscious militarized, in combination with a minor error by the architect. Saito allowed the job to continue, because he wanted to test Dom for a future job. Saito was impressed by the attempt, even though it failed, and asked him if he could perform inception and offered him [[The Fischer Inception Job|the Fischer Inception Job]], the primary job of the movie.
==Dreams== * Level 1 - [[The Dilapidated Hotel Room (dream)|The Dilapidated Hotel Room]] * Level 2 - [[The Japanese Castle (dream)|The Japanese Castle]] [[Category:Jobs]]

[[File:kaneda extraction job.png|thumb|300px|right|"Explosions don't hurt."]] '''The Kaneda Extraction Job''' was a job undertaken by [[Dominic Cobb|Cobb]], [[Nash]], [[Arthur]], and several [[Cobol Engineering]] henchmen in an attempt to [[Extraction|extract]] [[Proclus Global]]'s expansion plans from the mind of [[Mr. Kaneda]]. [[Category:Jobs]]

=='''THE DREAM IS REAL'''== Hello there,
I commonly go by either "champagne." or "hellotherenicole" on the internet, so feel free to call me one or the other (or both?).
That's about it.
Oh yeah, I'm co-admining an RPG based on ''Inception'', if you'd like to check it out, [http://s7.invisionfree.com/_TDIR CLICK HERE]. (Free advertising, ftw.)
Oh yeah (x 2) I love Eames. And Arthur. Together! So cute. ♥

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-67.159.45.52-20100902091939]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-67.159.45.52-20100902091939]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsonius]...
revision.text: There is one VERY big factor that I think is significant...... When Fischer, Ariadne and Cobb were in Limbo, there was a significant lack of projections (Unlike the other dreams, Fischer's private army was nowhere to be seen)....... So where did Mal come from? Furthermore, if the dreamer can bend the laws of physics (as Ariadne did after her recruitment), then it could be that if he wants the laws of physics to hold true and the top to fall, then that happens, but if he begins to doubt reality, or if he isn't concentrating on the totem (like at the end) then the top never stops until he begins to concentrate. The theory about Professor Miles is entirely speculative. We don't even know that he knew the truth behind her death.

{{Infobox actor |image= |imagesize=250px |name=Jordan Goldberg |died= |gender=Male |eye=Brown |hair=Brown |yearsactive=2006-present |inceptionrole=Co-producer }} Jordan Goldberg is an anime writer and was co-producer on [[Inception (2010 film)|Inception]]. He is best known for his work writing the prequel comic books [[Inception: The Cobol Job]] and [[Inception: The Big Under]].
===Work with Christopher Nolan===
Goldberg first worked with [[Christopher Nolan]] during Batman Begins. He was credited as "Assistant to Mr. Nolan". He later worked as associate producer of The Prestige and later The Dark Knight. He also worked on the interquel Batman: Gotham Knight, contributing to the screenplay of each of these animated features. Goldberg became a co-producer on Inception and is currently unsigned to any of Christopher Nolan's future projects.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-Voxtrace-20100911042154]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-Voxtrace-20100911042154]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsonius]]" to "[...
revision.text:
I have only seen the movie once but i’ve thought about it a bit and i’d like to share some thoughts.
Perhaps Cobb was dreaming the entire movie.
throughout the film there is a tinge of the fantastic, or surreal. the Jack Bower/SplinterCell knowledge and execution of sophisticated tactical maneuvers captains of industry that seem to have endless resources at a whim (e.g. buying an airliner) the apparent “happily ever-after” ending Being on the run from Cobol Corporation "At one point he tells himself this, through the voice of Mal, who is a projection of his own subconscious. She asks him how real he thinks his world is, where he's being chased across the globe by faceless corporate goons" (http://www.chud.com/articles/articles/24477/1/NEVER-WAKE-UP-THE-MEANING-AND-SECRET-OF-INCEPTION/Page1.html)
Perhaps the ending scene “Reality” is actually a dream in which Cobb will remain indefinitely. [train and plane and the ending reality are the base level of his dream (what is presented as “reality”)]
the idea that one can live lifetimes in deep level dreams was mentioned in the movie the scene with the room full of beds and people sleeping displayed assisted sleeping "you of all people should know what that is like" -perhaps referring to assisted sleeping (that Cobb is in the entire movie?)
On Totems
A Totem is an object that is used to test if oneself is in one’s own reality (dream or non-dream) and not in another person’s dream. A Totem has a specially modified weight, balance, or feel in the real world but in a dream of someone who does not know it well, the characteristics of the totem will very likely be off. In order to protect its integrity, only the totem’s owner should ever handle it. That way, the owner is able to tell whether or not they are in someone else’s dream. In the owner’s own dream world, the totem will feel correct. (http://inception.wikia.com/wiki/Totem) the top totem is suspect
it was mal’s Saito touched and spun the top perhaps that means that Saito can create a dream that Cobb can not be distinguish from his own
Possible assumptions:
The inception on Robert Fischer was real and as payment Saito supplies the happily ever-after reality in which Cobb chooses to remain. Saito perhaps has the resources allow Cobb to remain in a suspended dreamstate. The inception was performed on Cobb- to rid his self conscious of Mal and Saito supplies the happily ever-after reality in which Cobb chooses to remain. It was a double inception on Robert Fischer and Cobb and as payment Saito supplies the happily ever-after reality in which Cobb chooses to remain. Loose ends and foggy ideas and observations
The guilt of an old man is referenced multiple times. When Cobb washes up on the shore (Saito’s limbo?) he was carrying two things the top and a gun maybe the gun is Cobb’s totem If the entire thing is a dream are each member of the “dreamteam” projections of himself or others? The killing of Mal seemed to be the execution of the inception of the idea “Kill Mal because she is preventing you from completing your tasks…” or “… going home” Mal means bad In the “sleeping room” i believe the lines were “people come here to wake up- you of all people should know what that is like” perhaps referring to the idea that people wake up from dreams within dreams or to waking up and entering created realities. -Thanks that was cathartic

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-114.93.99.65-20100831200443/@comment-Voxtrace-20100911043800]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-114.93.99.65-20100831200443/@comment-Voxtrace-20100911043800]]: Automatical...
revision.text: Saito holds and spins the top as an old man in limbo. It is possible that Cobb is a dream provided by Saito in the end.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-64.229.222.80-20100827020359/@comment-Voxtrace-20100911044005]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-64.229.222.80-20100827020359/@comment-Voxtrace-20100911044005]]: Automatic...

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-92.4.115.9-20100823081158/@comment-Voxtrace-20100911044527]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-92.4.115.9-20100823081158/@comment-Voxtrace-20100911044527]]: Automatically m...
revision.text: Can it all be a dream and it not be pointless? Can it all be a dream but the inception be real? Maybe its all a dream, maybe the inception was real and his reward is that he doesn't wake up and is allowed to remains in the dream.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-72.94.198.56-20100819021803/@comment-Voxtrace-20100911045116]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-72.94.198.56-20100819021803/@comment-Voxtrace-20100911045116]]: Automatical...
revision.text: interesting... with this understanding Cobb will wake up shortly after the film concludes. I like the idea of Cobb being the subject of the inception. The line "i'm an old man full of regrets" that is repeated in the picture become more telling

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-68.174.18.219-20100818043142/@comment-Voxtrace-20100911050714]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-68.174.18.219-20100818043142/@comment-Voxtrace-20100911050714]]: Automatic...
revision.text: I like to this of this movie as more interactive than that. It is fun for me to think about 'what really going on', and to me, provides lasting entertainment not just the time spent in the movie theater. This is the reason why i found this website, isn't that the reason why we all here?

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-72.94.198.56-20100819021512/@comment-Voxtrace-20100911051144]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-72.94.198.56-20100819021512/@comment-Voxtrace-20100911051144]]: Automatical...
revision.text: could Cobb perhaps be in someone else's dream? Saito did hold and spin Cobb's top totem, perhaps he is in a dream provided by Saito; and if so his totem would not help Cobb determine if he was in a dream or not.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-24.19.66.30-20100817064119/@comment-Voxtrace-20100911051917]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-24.19.66.30-20100817064119/@comment-Voxtrace-20100911051917]]: Automatically...
revision.text: it was in a very deep dream-level... hmmm but why wouldn't matter? Does that mean that totems don't work in dreams? That doesn't make sense perhaps because it is in a deep dream-level then it only works for the owner? In any case it wasn't his totem. when he lands on the shore in the beginning of the film (Saito's Limo?) he was said to only have two items, the top and the gun, perhaps the gun his Cobb's real totem?

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-98.168.144.123-20100816053118/@comment-Voxtrace-20100911052025]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-98.168.144.123-20100816053118/@comment-Voxtrace-20100911052025]]: Automat...
revision.text: Maybe the whole thing is a dream?

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-98.183.131.52-20100815210855/@comment-Voxtrace-20100911052419]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-98.183.131.52-20100815210855/@comment-Voxtrace-20100911052419]]: Automatic...
revision.text: or a dream provided by Saito, he held Cobb's totem, albeit in limbo.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-122.107.94.147-20100815120915/@comment-Voxtrace-20100911053503]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-122.107.94.147-20100815120915/@comment-Voxtrace-20100911053503]]: Automat...
revision.text: I Like it! a lot. But to clarify when you say "reality is relative", it is because one can will the outcome of the totem, you mean within a dream right? So one can be in a dream and will the totem to act as you wish therefore convincing oneself to be in reality when in fact you are in the dream world. hmmm... So the entire film is in the dreamworld... . But with this understanding the entire inception mission was not real? Did the projection of Miles help Cobb incept himself to rid his mind of Mal?

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-122.107.94.147-20100815095709/@comment-Voxtrace-20100911053822]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-122.107.94.147-20100815095709/@comment-Voxtrace-20100911053822]]: Automat...
revision.text: so it is the faces of his children which in fact prevents others from creating a dreamworld that Cobb can't distinguish from "reality". hmmm interesting

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-74.192.103.95-20100815031741/@comment-Voxtrace-20100911054302]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-74.192.103.95-20100815031741/@comment-Voxtrace-20100911054302]]: Automatic...
revision.text: "Assuming this, one can make claim that the teams inception into Fisher is simply a clever Inception by Cobb's own subconscious as a way of ridding itself of Cobb's guilt. "You have to forgive yourself" "You have to confront her" "Let her go" His own mind is effectively tricking him into staying in the dream state" I like it- perhaps the inception was on cobb to rid his mind of mal or the guilt that she represents

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-Bastian964-20100814010554/@comment-Voxtrace-20100911054712]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-Bastian964-20100814010554/@comment-Voxtrace-20100911054712]]: Automatically m...
revision.text: What about Saito, I believe he held and spun the top as an old man. Perhaps Cobb is in a dream provided by Saito? If Saito used the knowledge of Cobb's totem in a dream would the top help cobb determine if he was in a dream?

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-82.131.32.5-20100812181915/@comment-Voxtrace-20100911073825]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-82.131.32.5-20100812181915/@comment-Voxtrace-20100911073825]]: Automatically...
revision.text: How about 100% of the film is a dream? That could explain the people staring at him, although i have not check the official website to seek how the prologue prevents the movie from being a 99% dream.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-186.45.25.131-20100812172255/@comment-Voxtrace-20100911074403]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-186.45.25.131-20100812172255/@comment-Voxtrace-20100911074403]]: Automatic...

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-186.45.25.131-20100812171235/@comment-Voxtrace-20100911074749]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-186.45.25.131-20100812171235/@comment-Voxtrace-20100911074749]]: Automatic...

==split==
I've been thinking that maybe we should split this into Mallorie Cobb (Real) and Mallorie Cobb (Projection) articles since Cobb even emphasizes at the end of the movie that they aren't the same person. I need to think about this more before I do it. In the meantime does anyone have a thought or comment on the split?[[User:Bastian964|Bastian]][[User_talk:Bastian964|9]][[Special:Contributions/Bastian964|6]][[Special:Editcount/Bastian964|4]] 11:49, September 13, 2010 (UTC)

revision.comment: Created page with "I like lots of moments of this awesome film, but I would say my favorites are the Palace Destruction at the beginning, and the Limbo Collapse at the end. The "Mombasa scene" is a…"
revision.text: I like lots of moments of this awesome film, but I would say my favorites are the Palace Destruction at the beginning, and the Limbo Collapse at the end. The "Mombasa scene" is also very fun to watch.

revision.comment: Created page with "I loved the soundtrack Zimmer composed for ''Inception''. While it's not a masterpiece, I think it was more than just good for the film. If you ask me, I would say my favorite so…"
revision.text: I loved the soundtrack Zimmer composed for ''Inception''. While it's not a masterpiece, I think it was more than just good for the film. If you ask me, I would say my favorite songs are "Dream is Collapsing", and "528491". I like "Don't think about Elephants", as well. And I would say as a joke response "What about giraffes?" revision.comment: Created page with "I'd have to say a couple of my favorite moments from Inception were when Dom shoots Mal in the snow fortress because it must have taken serious commitment to shoot his wife, even…"
revision.text: I'd have to say a couple of my favorite moments from Inception were when Dom shoots Mal in the snow fortress because it must have taken serious commitment to shoot his wife, even if it was just a projection. Then another is when Mal is dying in Dom's arms in limbo and he just closes his eyes dramatically, very sad and well-executed on both their parts.

==Theory== Something doesn't quite feel fight. And what I mean by that is the different methods of going into Limbo. I seem to have a problem with the time dilation. Indeed, Yusef did say that it was impossible to go into three dream layers, but they pulled it off in the movie under sedation. Obviously it is possible. That wasn't why he said it wasn't. The reason he said it was impossible was because the dreams would be so unstable that they were susceptable to collapse. You could actually get to three levels, you just couldn't stay there for long. So entering manually through regular layering is ruled out. I have no problems with Saito or Cobb entering Limbo together, as they both died on Level 1. The one that is the concern at the moment is how they enter through Fischer. Now, as opposed to Saito (who dies of both a gunshot wound to the lung and drowning on top of that) - who dies in a way where he can't possibly be brought back, Fischer is able to be revived by a defibrilator. Due to this state, the fact he wasn't quite dead, this would account for the normal time dilation. He was borderlining on Limbo, but wasn't quite past the point on no return (like Saito was.) (The your mind makes it real aspect certainly attibutes to this, though passing the body as actually aslepp doesn't quite expain hwo they pronounced him dead.) This is also why Cobb and Ariadne generated Limbo when they entered the dream, because it was Fischer's dream. But Fischer is "dead", so we have instant Limbo. Ariadne and Cobb still alive in the upper layers at this point, so time dilation is at a normal 20x. And did Cobb necessarily stay in Limbo for 50 years? Seems kind of off as well, as he would have more than likely found Saito in that time with that method. Backtrack to level 1, where Saito is dead and Cobb is alive. Him going in after would also explain the age difference between the two. My theory is that Cobb stayed in the Limbo-esqe level after Ariadne and Fischer left. Saito might have been there, but was too far away. Because he entered before Saito did, it is now his dream. So when he is kicked, the Limbo-city becomes his own level 2. Then he is kicked like he was with the bathtub at the beginning (the water would drown him in Limbo). However, he doesn't have enough time to escape (and he doesn't want to - he has to go get Saito), so he dies on level 1. Note (again) this is after Saito's death, so what is moments for Cobb is a lifetime for Saito. Now for something different. I had a bit of a problem with manually entering Limbo with going down levels. Let's say that level 3 is the absolute limit you can go down. It is a fact that Cobb and mal stayed in Limbo for 50 years, and it is also fact that 20x is the standard for time dilation. 50 years equals about 18260 days. A level up that would mean 912.5 days. Two levels up that's 45.625 days. And three levels up that is 2.28 days. That equals about 54 hours under. That means in Reality, they went 2 days without food, water, the need to go... you know. I don't think they would have done that, and their kids would have noticed if they were out for that long. And besides, that amount of time is nearly 7x the amount people spend sleeping, on average. And you don't spend all 8 hours dreaming. Granted, a PASIV device can have one dream for 8 hours. Also, that doesn't account for the infinite time dilation Limbo supposed to have. Yet the entire manually in the scenario in the article, and as a result the time dilation simply must be normal. I propose a theory for their experiments gone wrong, and this can be applied to shared dreams in general. I won't go into the details of my ziz-zag theory just yet (that itself is for another time, and is for a different dream mechanic anyways.), but it says that no person can be the dreamer (or host) of more than one dream at a time. This would explain why Nash doesn't go down into the castle with them (he is already dreaming the apartment), Authur doesn't go to the fortress with them (he is dreaming the hotel), or Yusef doesn't go under with them (he hosts the rainy city). What the theory stipulates is that if someone were to try to host more than one dream, the dream would instead change. You can't have more than one dream at once when alone, right? If done with multiple levels, a dream could potentially become the 1st and 3rd layer at the same time. If you kick yourself out of the 3rd layer and reach the second layer, no problem. Kick yourself from the second layer... you reach a dream that is both the first and third layer, again. Because there is a third layer under the second layer, the second layer cannot collapse. This makes exiting the dream entirely impossible. If the third and first layer were to hypothetically collapse, then the second layer would have to collapse. Or if the second layer collapsed, presumably the third layer would collapse, which would destroy the first layer as a result. But where would such a collapse generate from when there isn't even a way to put one in motion? Cobb and Mal, however, kept going forward. My theory is, that they pushed this paradox so far that the whole thing eventually collapsed and they wound up in an actual infinite time-dilation Limbo as they were supposed to be. Because it is already hard to believe they could get past 2 layers unaffected with just the two of them, because both would have to be a dream at some point (I am absolutely certain they never hooked up projections to the machine). If two is the limit, like Yusef said, then they couldn't have reached a place of infinite time dilation (or enough time dilation to account for the 50 years). But, if anything, these are my thoughts on the matter. Whether I'm right or I'm wrong is subjective at this point. I'll leave it to others to decide. EDIT: I just remembered why I started typing in the first place. Saito and Fischer both reach Limbo through death, but Saito ages way more considerably than Fischer does (at least, from what I can tell). This has inconsistant time dilation. That's all. [[Special:Contributions/68.60.225.106|68.60.225.106]] 03:00, September 30, 2010 (UTC) RK :Could you move this to your blog? This is really supposed to be a talk page about the content of the article itself. You're allowed to have it here but it would be nicer if it was in your blog and it would be easier for others to comment on it. [[User:Bastian964|Bastian]][[User_talk:Bastian964|9]][[Special:Contributions/Bastian964|6]][[Special:Editcount/Bastian964|4]] 22:46, September 30, 2010 (UTC) : :Yes, I've posted it on there. Just thought this would be the best place to put it, since it pretty much contests the information in the article. I dunno, should I keep it here? :(Also, When I posted an signed, I unknowingly signed it as as a name that is already in use on the wiki. I don't know if I should change it though...)
:[[User:RQK|RQK]] 23:02, September 30, 2010 (UTC) :::All you need to do is sign out than edit it. However changing it from RK to RQK is hardly necessary since people will know who you are since posted again in this discussion. The problem is that while you might think your argument refutes the article, what you have posted here is speculation, though mostly well thought out speculation. The article, however, relies only on what is seen in the movie, making as few assumptions as possible (if you see any major assumption in the article as it is now feel free to remove it or bring it up as a talking point for us to debate).[[User:Bastian964|Bastian]][[User_talk:Bastian964|9]][[Special:Contributions/Bastian964|6]][[Special:Editcount/Bastian964|4]] 23:12, September 30, 2010 (UTC) == Doesn't make sense == Although this is me picking holes in the film's plot, also the articles here don't make consistent sense. According to this article, Limbo is the deepest one can travel in the mind. Yet while in Limbo, Cobb performed [[Inception (tactic)|Inception]], which according to that article it's done by dream-sharing (ie, going deeper into someone's mind). How can you dream share in Limbo, if it's the deepest possible place to go?--[[User:Acer4666|Acer4666]] You don't need to go deeper into someone's mind to perform inception, you just need to go deep enough and Limbo is most certainly deep enough. [[User:Bastian964|Bastian]][[User_talk:Bastian964|9]][[Special:Contributions/Bastian964|6]][[Special:Editcount/Bastian964|4]] 12:09, January 3, 2012 (UTC) :So it's not done by dream-sharing when you're in limbo? That should be reflected in the [[Inception (tactic)]] page then? Or is it done by dream sharing? When you say "go deep enough", go deep enough where? Into whose mind? When both parties are in limbo, how does one perform inception on the other?--[[User:Acer4666|Acer4666]] ([[User talk:Acer4666|talk]]) 13:30, January 5, 2012 (UTC) ::1. No it was clearly done by just being in Limbo. ::2. Probably. ::3. Dreamsharing to get to a deep enough dream yes but Limbo is the deepest dream level so there is no need to dreamshare again nor is there way to while in Limbo. ::4. Into lower levels of dreams with Limbo being the lowest. ::5. The target's mind, though note that Limbo qualifies since it is the lowest level of everyone's mind. ::6. See last sentence. ::7. Cobb did it by going into a place that heavily represented Mal and messing with her totem to make her doubt the reality of her situation. How one tries to implant another idea while in Limbo is unknown. ::[[User:Bastian964|Bastian]][[User_talk:Bastian964|9]][[Special:Contributions/Bastian964|6]][[Special:Editcount/Bastian964|4]] 14:11, January 6, 2012 (UTC) :::Thanks for the answers - although I don't think it is ever explicitly stated that limbo is the deepest you can go. I always thought Dom and Mal grew to 80-year olds, then Dom did a dream share to a deeper level where they both projected themselves as young people, hence why we see a young Dom spinning the top in the safe, and a young couple with their heads on the train tracks. Then they woke up in their next level up as 80-year-olds, and did the same thing again (hence the shot of the two old hands on the train track), then got out of limbo. I may be wrong though - is limbo being the deepest level ever stated by the film or other media?--[[User:Acer4666|Acer4666]] ([[User talk:Acer4666|talk]]) 17:35, January 6, 2012 (UTC) :It is explicitly stated to be the deepest you can go in the film. Also note that you can control your appearance in the dream. They aged naturally becuase they wanted to and/or they believed they should, as soon as Cobb began to reject Limbo he changed his appearance to be young again. [[User:Bastian964|Bastian]][[User_talk:Bastian964|9]][[Special:Contributions/Bastian964|6]][[Special:Editcount/Bastian964|4]] 13:09, January 10, 2012 (UTC) ::I don't suppose you have the quote where it is stated? Having checked some of the scenes I can't find any explicit reference to it being the deepest one can go--[[User:Acer4666|Acer4666]] ([[User talk:Acer4666|talk]]) 15:04, January 15, 2012 (UTC) :::If you can't provide a quote if it being explicitly stated, then it's not explicitly stated and the information has to be removed--[[User:Acer4666|Acer4666]] ([[User talk:Acer4666|talk]]) 11:00, April 12, 2012 (UTC) I'm sorry but I'm not going to spend the effort to reread the entire script to find information that was long established by many other editors. At this point all I really do is curate the wiki to make sure no one messes it up. Unless you can provide proof that all the editors were wrong, it stays. [[User:Bastian964|Bastian]][[User_talk:Bastian964|9]][[Special:Contributions/Bastian964|6]][[Special:Editcount/Bastian964|4]] 13:23, April 12, 2012 (UTC) :All I'm suggesting is removing the information, pending a source, for when you do want to make the effort to prove what you are saying. I wouldn't say the editors were ''wrong'' per se, more that they made an easy to make assumption that wasn't actually stated and could have different interpretations. Check out some people's interpretations [http://dehahs.deviantart.com/art/Inception-Infographic-172424503 here], [http://www.inceptionending.com/theory/2010-inception-infographic-by-daniel-wang/ here] or [http://koenta.deviantart.com/art/Inception-infographic-188929814 here] that the city Cobb and Ariadne go to from the mountain is not the lowest level, rather another dream that can go deeper. This is because, having watched the film, I found no explicit reference to limbo being the deepest level, just that it was "unconstructed dreamspace". Curating a wiki is not just about preserving everything as it is, you may as well lock every page if you're not happy about content being changed.--[[User:Acer4666|Acer4666]] ([[User talk:Acer4666|talk]]) 13:41, April 12, 2012 (UTC) ::So, I've changed my mind. You were right, the information should be removed until a source can be found for it. Sorry for impeding you. I'm making the change now. [[User:Bastian964|Bastian]][[User_talk:Bastian964|9]][[Special:Contributions/Bastian964|6]][[Special:Editcount/Bastian964|4]] 23:45, April 16, 2012 (UTC) == Read Now! == LALALALALALALALALALALALAL LOLLIPOPS, OH GOD I CHOKED ON ONE, NOT HAHAHAHA GULLIBLE FOOLS

revision.comment: Created page with "This is something I originally posted on the discussion page for Limbo. I stated I had a few problems with the mechanics of the thing. Here is what I wrote: Something doesn't …"
revision.text:
This is something I originally posted on the discussion page for Limbo. I stated I had a few problems with the mechanics of the thing. Here is what I wrote:
Something doesn't quite feel fight.
And what I mean by that is the different methods of going into Limbo. I seem to have a problem with the time dilation.
Indeed, Yusef did say that it was impossible to go into three dream layers, but they pulled it off in the movie under sedation. Obviously it is possible. That wasn't why he said it wasn't. The reason he said it was impossible was because the dreams would be so unstable that they were susceptable to collapse. You could actually get to three levels, you just couldn't stay there for long. So entering manually through regular layering is ruled out.
I have no problems with Saito or Cobb entering Limbo together, as they both died on Level 1. The one that is the concern at the moment is how they enter through Fischer.
Now, as opposed to Saito (who dies of both a gunshot wound to the lung and drowning on top of that) - who dies in a way where he can't possibly be brought back, Fischer is able to be revived by a defibrilator. Due to this state, the fact he wasn't quite dead, this would account for the normal time dilation. He was borderlining on Limbo, but wasn't quite past the point on no return (like Saito was.) (The your mind makes it real aspect certainly attibutes to this, though passing the body as actually aslepp doesn't quite expain hwo they pronounced him dead.) This is also why Cobb and Ariadne generated Limbo when they entered the dream, because it was Fischer's dream. But Fischer is "dead", so we have instant Limbo. Ariadne and Cobb still alive in the upper layers at this point, so time dilation is at a normal 20x.
And did Cobb necessarily stay in Limbo for 50 years? Seems kind of off as well, as he would have more than likely found Saito in that time with that method. Backtrack to level 1, where Saito is dead and Cobb is alive. Him going in after would also explain the age difference between the two. My theory is that Cobb stayed in the Limbo-esqe level after Ariadne and Fischer left. Saito might have been there, but was too far away. Because he entered before Saito did, it is now his dream. So when he is kicked, the Limbo-city becomes his own level 2. Then he is kicked like he was with the bathtub at the beginning (the water would drown him in Limbo). However, he doesn't have enough time to escape (and he doesn't want to - he has to go get Saito), so he dies on level 1. Note (again) this is after Saito's death, so what is moments for Cobb is a lifetime for Saito.
Now for something different. I had a bit of a problem with manually entering Limbo with going down levels. Let's say that level 3 is the absolute limit you can go down. It is a fact that Cobb and mal stayed in Limbo for 50 years, and it is also fact that 20x is the standard for time dilation. 50 years equals about 18260 days. A level up that would mean 912.5 days. Two levels up that's 45.625 days. And three levels up that is 2.28 days. That equals about 54 hours under. That means in Reality, they went 2 days without food, water, the need to go... you know. I don't think they would have done that, and their kids would have noticed if they were out for that long. And besides, that amount of time is nearly 7x the amount people spend sleeping, on average. And you don't spend all 8 hours dreaming. Granted, a PASIV device can have one dream for 8 hours.
Also, that doesn't account for the infinite time dilation Limbo supposed to have. Yet the entire manually in the scenario in the article, and as a result the time dilation simply must be normal.
I propose a theory for their experiments gone wrong, and this can be applied to shared dreams in general. I won't go into the details of my ziz-zag theory just yet (that itself is for another time, and is for a different dream mechanic anyways.), but it says that no person can be the dreamer (or host) of more than one dream at a time. This would explain why Nash doesn't go down into the castle with them (he is already dreaming the apartment), Authur doesn't go to the fortress with them (he is dreaming the hotel), or Yusef doesn't go under with them (he hosts the rainy city).
What the theory stipulates is that if someone were to try to host more than one dream, the dream would instead change. You can't have more than one dream at once when alone, right? If done with multiple levels, a dream could potentially become the 1st and 3rd layer at the same time. If you kick yourself out of the 3rd layer and reach the second layer, no problem. Kick yourself from the second layer... you reach a dream that is both the first and third layer, again.
Because there is a third layer under the second layer, the second layer cannot collapse. This makes exiting the dream entirely impossible. If the third and first layer were to hypothetically collapse, then the second layer would have to collapse. Or if the second layer collapsed, presumably the third layer would collapse, which would destroy the first layer as a result. But where would such a collapse generate from when there isn't even a way to put one in motion?
Cobb and Mal, however, kept going forward. My theory is, that they pushed this paradox so far that the whole thing eventually collapsed and they wound up in an actual infinite time-dilation Limbo as they were supposed to be. Because it is already hard to believe they could get past 2 layers unaffected with just the two of them, because both would have to be a dream at some point (I am absolutely certain they never hooked up projections to the machine). If two is the limit, like Yusef said, then they couldn't have reached a place of infinite time dilation (or enough time dilation to account for the 50 years).
But, if anything, these are my thoughts on the matter. Whether I'm right or I'm wrong is subjective at this point. I'll leave it to others to decide.
EDIT: I just remembered why I started typing in the first place. Saito and Fischer both reach Limbo through death, but Saito ages way more considerably than Fischer does (at least, from what I can tell). This has inconsistant time dilation. That's all. [[Category:Blog posts]]

revision.comment: Created page with "You might want to change fight to right in the first sentence. Also it was shown in the movie that you can appear young and then old and then young again while in Limbo (this i…"
revision.text:
You might want to change fight to right in the first sentence.
Also it was shown in the movie that you can appear young and then old and then young again while in Limbo (this is shown in Mal and Dom's experience in Limbo). So it's not inconsistent time dilation so much as, like Eames, they can likely manipulate their appearances (though for Saito it was probably accidental).
Sure hold on.
http://multiplayerblog.mtv.com/2010/09/24/inception-video-game-on-christopher-nolans-to-do-list/

==Welcome== Hi, welcome to Inception Wiki. Thanks for your edit to the '''Mallorie Cobb''' page.
'''[[Special:Userlogin|Please sign in and create a user name]]'''. It's an easy way to keep track of your contributions and helps you communicate with the rest of the community.
Please leave a message on [[User talk:Bastian964|my talk page]] if I can help with anything! -- [[User:Bastian964|Bastian964]] ([[User_talk:Bastian964|Talk]]) 01:00, October 1, 2010

The thing is riddled with spelling and grammar errors, will fix them at some point.
The main point of the argument though was to point out the inconsistency not between Saito and Cobb, but between Saito and Fischer. Saito had to have been in Limbo for 50 years, or he certainly wouldn't have acted the way he did (unless he perceived himself as an old man from the very beginning, but that seems unlikely). Likewise, if Fischer had been there for 50 years (or even 30 years), he wouldn't have acted the way he did.
Although I will concede I don't quite remember the condition he was in when Ariadne found him on the porch; I think we did see his face though, and it showed no sign of age. And he can't manipulate that, because he's new to the whole lucid dreaming thing.
And I think if he had been in his own Limbo for a while, the changes would have shown when Cobb entered (probably the two limbos would mix together to form a complete unified Limbo). So I think he wasn't there for very long when Cobb arrived.
No wait, I'd like to return to something I just said. What if Saito actually did project himself as an old man? He could certainly believe he was there for a very long time, which would certainly account for his vivid recollection of the arrangement (he still knows exactly what number to dial upon awakening). Though that raises time dilation problems in regards to Mal/Cobb.
Also, I'd like the mention that Cobb was sort of lucid down in Limbo with Mal, and he says that they were there "something on the order of fifty years". Unless there were timeskips involved, though I think: he would have noticed them, those can't occur within dreams because that would conflict with other's perception of the dream, and plus timeskips would defeat the notion of time dilation.
If anything, I think the matter should be debated more, because I though of one of the current explanations to be contradictory. Saito seemed to be dead a lesser time on their respective dream levels before Cobb reached them (12 seconds for Saito, longer for Fischer), and yet Saito was there much longer than Fischer. Fischer was supposedly there for an hour, or perhaps a day, while Saito was there for half a century.

{{Infobox song | name = ''Half Remembered Dream'' | video = <!-- <youtube width="200" height="25">CspFuuWpZkY</youtube> --> | album = ''[[Inception: Music from the Motion Picture]]'' | artist = [[Hans Zimmer]] | length = 1:12 | producer = | last = | next = ''[[We Built Our Own World]]'' }} '''''[[Half Remembered Dream]]''''' is the first track on the album ''[[Inception: Music from the Motion Picture]]''. It runs for 1:12 minutes. At around 00:20 in the track, there is a series of low brass blasts. This section is derived from Edith Piaf's "Non, Je Ne Regrette Rien" (the music the team uses during kicks), slowed down. The title is a reference to a phrase said by the aged [[Saito]] when [[Cobb]] finds him in [[Limbo]]: "''You remind me of someone... a man I met in a half-remembered dream.''" [[Category:Music]]

{{Infobox song | name = ''We Built Our Own World'' | video = | album = ''[[Inception: Music from the Motion Picture]]'' | artist = [[Hans Zimmer]] | length = 1:55 | producer = | last = ''[[Half Remembered Dream]]'' | next = ''[[Dream Is Collapsing]]'' }} '''''[[We Built Our Own World]] '''''is the second track on the album ''[[Inception: Music from the Motion Picture]]''. It runs for 1:55 minutes. Its title is a phrase said by [[Dominic Cobb|Cobb]] when he is talking to [[Ariadne]] about his experience in [[Limbo]] with [[Mallorie Cobb|Mal]]:
"''We were working together, we were exploring the concept of a dream within a dream. I kept pushing things. I wanted to go deeper and deeper, I wanted to go… further. I just didn’t understand the concept that hours could turn into years down there. That we could get trapped so deep that when we wound up on the shore of our own subconscious we lost sight of what was real. We created, we built the world for ourselves. We did that for years. We built our own world.''"
[[Category:Music]]

{{Infobox song | name = ''Dream Is Collapsing'' | video = | album = ''[[Inception: Music from the Motion Picture]]'' | artist = [[Hans Zimmer]] | length = 2:28 | producer = | last = ''[[We Built Our Own World]]'' | next = ''[[Radical Notion]]'' }} '''''[[Dream Is Collapsing]]''''' is the third track on the album ''[[Inception: Music from the Motion Picture]]''. It runs for 2:28 minutes. The title is a phrase said by [[Arthur]] after waking up from the second dream level ([[Saito]]'s [[The Palace (Dream)|palace]]) during [[The Saito Extraction Job]].
[[Nash]]: "''What are you doing? It's too soon!''" Arthur: "''I know. The dream is collapsing. Try to keep Saito under a little bit longer, we're almost done.''"
[[Category:Music]]

{{Infobox song | name = ''Radical Notion'' | video = | album = ''[[Inception: Music from the Motion Picture]]'' | artist = [[Hans Zimmer]] | length = 3:43 | producer = | last = ''[[Dream Is Collapsing]]'' | next = ''[[Old Souls]]'' }} '''''[[Radical Notion]]''''' is the fourth track on the album ''[[Inception: Music from the Motion Picture]]''. It runs for 3:43 minutes. The title is a reference to what the old [[Saito]] said when he talked to [[Cobb]] in [[Limbo]]:
"''You remind me of someone... a man I met in a half-remembered dream. He was possessed of some radical notions.''"
This played when Cobb was sharing his second dream with [[Ariadne]] and she is stabbed by [[Mal]] at the end. [[Category:Music]]

{{Infobox song | name = ''Old Souls'' | video = | album = ''[[Inception: Music from the Motion Picture]]'' | artist = [[Hans Zimmer]] | length = 7:44 | producer = | last = ''[[Radical Notion]]'' | next = ''[[528491 (music)|528491]]'' }} '''''[[Old Souls]]''''' is the fifth track on the album ''[[Inception: Music from the Motion Picture]]''. It runs for 7:44 minutes. The title could be a reference to [[Dominic Cobb|Dom]] and [[Mallorie Cobb|Mal]] when they were in [[Limbo]], where they spent around 50 years. In the real world, their bodies were still young, but in [[Limbo]], their souls (or minds) became, as Dom says, "old souls". [[Category:Music]]

{{Infobox song | name = 528491 | video = | album = ''[[Inception: Music from the Motion Picture]]'' | artist = [[Hans Zimmer]] | length = 2:23 | producer = | last = ''[[Old Souls]]'' | next = ''[[Mombasa]]'' }} '''''528491''''' is the sixth track on the album ''[[Inception: Music from the Motion Picture]]''. It runs for 2:23 minutes. The title is the [[528491 (number)|random series of numbers]] that [[Robert Fischer]] was forced to give to the disguised [[Cobb]] and [[Arthur]], in the [[The City (Dream)|first dream level]] of [[The Fischer Inception Job]]. The team needed a random series of numbers in order to create a password to access his subconscious.
Cobb: "''Give me the first six numbers that come into your head right now.''" Fischer: ''"I have no idea."'' Cobb: "''RIGHT NOW! I SAID RIGHT NOW! [points his gun at [[Peter Browning|Browning]]'s head] RIGHT NOW!''" Fischer: "''Five-two-eight-four-nine-one.''"
It is notably played in the climax of the film, when the Inception is planted on Fischer as he discovers his dying father's 'last will'. [[Category:Music]]

{{Infobox song | name = ''Mombasa'' | video = | album = ''[[Inception: Music from the Motion Picture]]'' | artist = [[Hans Zimmer]] | length = 4:54 | producer = | last = ''[[528491 (music)|528491]]'' | next = ''[[One Simple Idea]]'' }} '''''Mombasa''''' is the seventh track on the album ''[[Inception: Music from the Motion Picture]]''. It runs for 4:54 minutes. Its title refers to the city of Mombasa, Kenya, where [[Dom Cobb]] hires [[Eames]], and [[Yusuf]].
As suggested by the title, a variation of the song is heard in the Mombasa foot chase, and also in during the infamous 'Dream a little bigger' scene involving Arthur and Eames. [[Category:Music]]
#REDIRECT [[Mombasa (music)]]

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-66.91.109.152-20101010024527]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-66.91.109.152-20101010024527]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsoniu...
revision.text:
The ending was that it does not matter whether the top falls or not.
If it spins indefinitely, he is definitely in a dream. If it falls, it may not be a dream but it still could be.
The totem is the inception, the idea that infected Mal's mind to make her think the world is a dream. It could have been an idea that infected Cobb's mind to see if it is real. Whose to say the top won't fall the way he wants it to in a dream?
Throughout the movie, the lines are already blurred with Cobb not knowing reality from a dream any more. Things seem to manifest the way he wants it too. That's why he wished that he could not recreate things from memory to begin with. How can he not?
-holanz
PS weren't they supposed to be in level 1 for a week?

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-147.217.253.245-20101015190128]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-147.217.253.245-20101015190128]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Sams...
revision.text:
he was dreaming before the movie began. The architech and the Japanese guy (Saito) wore the same style shirts in 2 diffrent dreams, but never 'met' each other. They are charachters created by his subconscience. The chase scene where Cobb meets the Forger: The camera gives a shot of the city....it looks exactly like a maze....that the Architecht drew.
Cobb's mind can be splitting into diffrent personalites similar to MPS... His mind may be reacting to the sever and constant shock of dream sharing and extracting. The one thing that our bodies do to repair it's self is to maintain or achieve homeostasis. Some sort of balance. Like taking asprins over a long period of time is bad for you becasue it can give you a higher risk of a stroke. Why??? Asprins are blood thinners, your body will produce MORE platlets to maintain homeostatis.... too much platlets causes clots... clots in the brain can cause strokes... in the heart... heart attacks... etc....
His mind might be trying to fix itself (or understand what's happening) so it will split.... Sorta like going into shock.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-112.201.2.13-20101103121647]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-112.201.2.13-20101103121647]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsonius]...
revision.text:
watched the movie again and i am confident that the ending took place in the real world. im still sticking with my belief that Cobb's totem is not the spinning top but his wedding ring.. in the first scene where we saw cobb washed ashore then taken to saito we saw his wedding ring on his left hand.. same thing when they tried to infiltrate saito but failed because mal interfered. now we know these scenes took place in the dream world.. now compare it to the scene like cobb talking to ariadne before entering the dream or perhaps the scene inside the plane right before they entered the dream state there's no sign of cobb's wedding ring.. therefore our basis should be cobb's ring.. the entire time they infiltrated fischer's mind cobb was wearing a wedding ring down to cobb rescuing old man saito he was wearing a wedding ring.. but after they accomplished their mission and waking up there's no sign of cobb's wedding ring therefore the ending of the movie took place in the real world.
other hints would be the clothes of the children example before cobb left his children we saw philippa and james playing outside. philippa was wearing a red dress that's why we only see philippa thru the eyes of cobb wearing the same dress over and over again because they were merely projections of cobb.. but in the last scene wherein cobb is reunited with his children philippa was wearing a red dress with a white shirt under it..
it's just nolan playing mind rape on us that's all so we should pay attention down to the smallest detail..
i remember nolan's other movie memento.. guy pierce character keeps talking about his client who suffers amnesia and we often see that patient that chubby old man in the ward or something but there was a second that revealed it was guy pierce after all.. so you see the pattern..
-deadpool

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-112.201.2.13-20101103121647/@comment-112.201.2.13-20101103122231]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-112.201.2.13-20101103121647/@comment-112.201.2.13-20101103122231]]: Aut...
revision.text:
is there a way to post pictures/screencaps here? i just want to show my point re: the wedding ring and philippa's clothes
-deadpool

[[File:Inception-the-shooting-script1.jpg|thumb|Cover of ''Inception'': The Shooting Script]]
[[Inception: The Shooting Script]] is the screenplay of ''[[Inception (2010 film)|Inception]]'' by [[Christopher Nolan]] with a preface by his brother [[Jonathan Nolan]]. It was released on November 6, 2010 as a paperback book.
The shooting script includes notes on the [[PASIV Device]] and some of Christopher Nolan's notes when developing the script. Because of its status as the shooting script for the film, some details were excluded from the final cut of the film, while other details that do not exist in the shooting script appear in the film.
==Contents== * Preface :* Dreaming/Creating/Perceiving/Filmmaking by Christopher Nolan and Jonathan Nolan * ''Inception'' The Shooting Script * Appendices :* [[Instruction Manual MV-235A|PASIV Device Instruction Manual]] :* Film Credits
==Additional Information== *[http://books.google.com/books/about/Inception.html?id=PLtlf3DdFrkC ''Inception: The Shooting Script'' - Google Books] [[Category:Inception]] [[Category:Merchandise]]
