revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-99.253.94.42-20101109020716]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-99.253.94.42-20101109020716]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsonius]...
revision.text:
1. Something about the Ring(s) that people might have not noticed.
When Cobb is in the first level of Fischer's dream, he is talking to Adriane about how he and Mal spent about 50 years in Limbo. In a scene when they woke up from it, both Cobb and Mal are still wearing rings. In the next scene Mal is sitting at the table with a kitchen knife and a spinning top, Cobb comes up and takes Mal's hand with his left hand with a Ring on, Mal then drops a knife and holds Cobb's hand. Also on their anniversary, in the hotel room Cobb is still wearing the ring.
In other words Cobb doesn't have the ring only after his wife commits a suicide, there are still cases outside of the dream when Cobb is wearing his wedding ring. In my opinion wedding ring cannot be his totem, but rather a part of his subconscious, just like Mal, reminding him of his guilt.
2. A few things that I can't seem to understand.
According to the movie dieing in Limbo wakes you up not only from your current dream, but from dreams within the dreams, just like Mal and Cobb did, or Cobb and Saito at the end. If it is so, and if Cobb knew about it, then what was so scary about dieing in that last 3-level dream they've created for Fischer, they could all simply quit it when they wanted to by dieing in the first level which would throw them into Limbo and then dieing in Limbo, which would wake them up.
When Cobb and Mal took a freight train express out of Limbo they looked the same age they were as when they got in it, yet in the end of the movie when Mal's projection says something about growing old together, Cobb's response was "But we did, you don't remember?" which followed by a scene of them two being old and holding their hands together being in Limbo.
And finally, the scenes with old Saito at the beginning and the very end. The dialogue changes, at the end Cobb finishes Saito's line that was said in the beginning all by Saito himself, which only means those two events/dreams with old Saito occurred separately at different times.
These last three uncertainties makes me wonder if the main protagonist Dominic Cobb was ever awaken, or simply lost in the Limbo all by himself creating his own world looking for reconciliation through completing that last task.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-99.253.94.42-20101109020716/@comment-119.92.79.91-20101109160032]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-99.253.94.42-20101109020716/@comment-119.92.79.91-20101109160032]]: Aut...
revision.text:
there are 3 parts shown in the movie 1. the dream 2. the reality/present and 3. the flash back
what you saw there where mal and cobb both wore their wedding rings were flashbacks of cobb. it has nothing to do with entering the dream or living in reality/present because they were mere flashbacks. cobb reminiscing or recalling what he did to mal. so if you saw mal and cobb wearing their wedding ring of course you should coz they were married couples.
when you saw cobb and mal woke up after spending 50 years in limbo you saw cobb and mal wear their wedding ring, right? and the scene wherein mal was about to jump from the building you also saw cobb on the other side of the building wore his ring, right? that's because these were the time when mal was still alive and mal and cobb were still a couple. since they were a couple it is expected that they were their wedding rings..
now fast forward when mal is already dead.. that's the time wherein we never saw cobb wear his wedding ring.. when they visited yusuf, before cobb entered the dream to test yusuf's serum we can't see him wear his ring.. just like when they were practicing along with ariadne we never see cobb wear his ring like when he woke up and panicked he spun the totem just to check if he was still in a dream there was no sign of wedding ring from any of his finger.. and before they entered fischer's mind, inside the plane we saw cobb's left hand and there was no wedding ring..
now when they finally entered fischer's mind we get to see cobbs wedding ring..
this concludes that the wedding ring is cobb's totem not the spinning top

btw this is michael caine's theory
"[The spinning top] drops at the end, that's when I come back on," he says. "If I'm there it's real, because I'm never in the dream. I'm the guy who invented the dream."
-deadpool

{{Infobox song | name = ''One Simple Idea'' | video = <!-- <youtube width="200" height="25">CspFuuWpZkY</youtube> --> | album = ''[[Inception: Music from the Motion Picture]]'' | artist = [[Hans Zimmer]] | length = 2:28 | producer = | last = ''[[Mombasa (music)|Mombasa]]'' | next = ''[[Dream Within A Dream]]'' }} '''''[[One Simple Idea]]''''' is the eighth track on the album ''[[Inception: Music from the Motion Picture]]''. It runs for 2:28 minutes. Its name refers to the "one simple idea" that is implanted in a subject's mind by [[inception (tactic)|inception]].
As with some other tracks from the Inception soundtrack, this exact track is not heard. However, variations of it can be heard during the planning process of the film up to when the team first go under on the plane, and softly at the very end intermixed with another track. The introduction in the track is can be heard when Cobb draws Fischer's attention to the strangeness of the dream in the hotel. [[Category:Music]]

{{Infobox song | name = Dream Within A Dream | video = | album = [[Inception: Music from the Motion Picture]] | artist = [[Hans Zimmer]] | length = 5:04 | producer = | last = [[One Simple Idea]] | next = [[Waiting For A Train]] }} ''[[Dream Within A Dream]]'' is the ninth track on the album ''[[Inception: Music from the Motion Picture]]''. It runs for 5:04 minutes. The title refers to a subject having a dream while they're already in a dream.
Cobb: ''"I WILL SPLIT UP MY FATHER'S EMPIRE." An idea [[Robert Fischer]]'s conscious mind would never accept. We have to plant it deep in his subconscious.'' Arthur: ''How deep?'' Cobb: ''Three levels down.'' Arthur: ''A dream within a dream within a dream? Is that even possible?''
From 0:00 to 1:50, the track plays during Eames' attempt to lead the projections in the third level on a skiing chase. It should be noted that this track was loosely based on the music from the James Bond film ''On Her Majesty's Secret Service'', which prominently features a skiing chase and is one of Christopher Nolan's favourite films. ==References== [[Category:Music]]

{{Infobox song | name = ''Waiting For A Train'' | video = | album = ''[[Inception: Music from the Motion Picture]]'' | artist = [[Hans Zimmer]] | length = 9:03 | producer = | last = ''[[Dream Within A Dream]]'' | next = ''[[Paradox]]'' }} '''''[[Waiting For A Train]]''''' is the tenth track on the album ''[[Inception: Music from the Motion Picture]]''. It runs for 9:03 minutes. Its title refers to a phrase said by [[Dominic Cobb|Dom]] to [[Mallorie Cobb|Mal]] when they were experimenting in [[Limbo]].
Cobb: "''You're waiting for a train. A train that will take you far away. You know where you hope the train will take you, but you can't be sure. Yet it doesn't matter. Now, tell me why?''" Mal: "''Because we'll be together!''"
The track plays when Cobb is explaining to [[Ariadne]] how he and Mal got stuck down in Limbo and how Mal eventually killed herself, as well as when Cobb has to let her go while they're both (him and his projection of Mal) in Limbo, at the end of the operation. [[Category:Music]]

{{Infobox song | name = ''Paradox'' | video = | album = ''[[Inception: Music from the Motion Picture]]'' | artist = [[Hans Zimmer]] | length = 3:25 | producer = | last = ''[[Waiting For A Train]]'' | next = ''[[Time]]'' }} '''''[[Paradox]]''''' is the eleventh track on the album ''[[Inception: Music from the Motion Picture]]''. It runs for 3:25 minutes. The title refers to the use of impossible shapes in a dream, in this case, [[Penrose Stairs (dream)|Penrose steps]].
[[Arthur]]: "''In a dream you can cheat architecture into impossible shapes. That lets you create closed loops, like the Penrose steps. The infinite staircase. See...''" [The staircase he and [[Ariadne]] have been climbing up suddenly shifts up.] Arthur: "''...paradox. So a closed loop liked that will help you disguise the boundaries of the dream you create.''"
This track plays when [[Dominic Cobb|Cobb]] is in limbo with his projection of [[Mal]], after she was shot by Ariadne, and Cobb is reminding her that they ''did'' grow old together and that he has to let her go. It continues to the scene when the rest of the team awake in the van and swim out to shore. The track continues on to when Cobb washes up on the shore of the [[The Japanese Castle (limbo)|Japanese Castle]] and finds [[Saito]] there in his old age. ==References== [[Category:Music]]

{{Infobox song | name = ''Time | video = | album = ''[[Inception: Music from the Motion Picture]]'' | artist = [[Hans Zimmer]] | length = 4:35 | producer = | last = ''[[Paradox]]'' | next = }} '''''[[Time]]''''' is the twelfth and final non-bonus track on the album ''[[Inception: Music from the Motion Picture]]''. It runs for 4:35 minutes. The song describes life. Which is only as important as the dreams which make up our reality.
This track plays when [[Dominic Cobb|Cobb]] and [[Saito]] wake up in the airplane and Cobb finally gets to go home to see his children. [[Category:Music]]

{{Infobox song | name = ''Don't Think About Elephants'' | video = | album = | artist = [[Hans Zimmer]] | length = 5:36 | producer = | last = | next = }} ''[[Don't Think About Elephants]]'' is a bonus track from ''[[Inception|Inception's]]'' score, which was not included in ''[[Inception: Music from the Motion Picture]]''. It runs for 5:36 minutes. The title is referring to a phrase said by [[Arthur]] when he is talking to [[Saito]] in his helicopter:
Saito: "''If you can steal an idea from someone's mind, why can't you plant one there instead?''" Arthur: "''Okay, here's me planting an idea in your head. I say to you, don't think about elephants. What are you thinking about?''" Saito: "''Elephants.''"
The piece plays from the rotating hotel fight with Arthur up to when Fischer is shot by Mal as he is about enter the safe. [[Category:Music]]

{{Infobox song | name = ''Projections'' | video = | album = | artist = [[Hans Zimmer]] | length = 7:04 | producer = | last = | next = }} '''''[[Projections]]''''' is a bonus track from ''[[Inception|Inception's]]'' score, which was not included in ''[[Inception: Music from the Motion Picture]]''. It runs for 7:04 minutes. Its title refers to the [[projections]] in a dream.
This track plays in the beginning of the movie when [[Dominic Cobb|Cobb]] finds [[Saito]] in limbo at the [[The Japanese Castle (limbo)|Japanese Castle]] and when Cobb and [[Arthur]] are at the [[The Japanese Castle (dream)|Japanese Castle]] to find Saito's expansion plans.
[[es:Projections]] [[Category:Music]]

revision.comment: Created page with "Hi, my name is Klltr (and I do not intend to give you my real name). I enjoyed Inception very much. Here's my ending theory: ''Dom's mind has merged the dream world and real wor…"
revision.text:
Hi, my name is Klltr (and I do not intend to give you my real name). I enjoyed Inception very much. Here's my ending theory:
''Dom's mind has merged the dream world and real world, so while he is wake, his mind still thinks he is dreaming. ''
MY LIKES: The abillity to meet with other members of these communities and discuss things we like (eg. this movie)
MY DISLIKES: Red links and vandals! I hate them both.
KLLtR 06:18, November 16, 2010 (UTC)

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-Hendrixroxit-20101122071343]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-Hendrixroxit-20101122071343]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsonius]...
revision.text: The Top keeps spinning. Though we know that this is the writer's way of saying this is the dream world Cobb accepts, what if this was a dream world that Miles had fashioned? Why? Because it's Miles way of extracting information from Cobb. Specifically a confession that he had killed his daughter Mall by use of inception. So in essence the movie goer has been in a dream within a dream within a dream within a dream within a dream...

revision.comment: Created page with "The way I saw it was that Cobb had to actually venture through Limbo for some time after Ariadne and Fischer escaped. Fischer was rescued very quickly compared to Saito after mak…"
revision.text:
The way I saw it was that Cobb had to actually venture through Limbo for some time after Ariadne and Fischer escaped. Fischer was rescued very quickly compared to Saito after making their initial entrance into Limbo. Therefore, the aging pattern seems to be consistent, at least it does to me.
As Cobb makes his way through Limbo to rescue Saito it seems to take a toll on his outward appearance. When he finally finds Saito, Cobb seems older and weaker then when he originally entered Limbo to save Fischer. This being the case in seems likely that Saito, being lost, perceived his time in Limbo to be much longer than Cobb's time there. I believe Limbo is subjective to the person trapped there. Saito probably thought no one was coming for him and eventually gave up hope, while when Cobb and Mal were together there, their time was a little slower and they were able to grow old together because they wanted to. Also, Saito was in Limbo a little longer than Cobb was when coming to rescue him, so therefore it is logical to for him to be seen as old and frail. Of course this is a movie and we'll never know the truth, but this is my opinion for what happened in Limbo.

revision.text: This is definitely Caine's opinion, and I don't see how he can honestly say "He's the creator of the dream, therefore he's not in the dreams." He could have easily been a projection himself, unless this rule of him being the creator and whatnot was something he came up with himself to fill in the gaps or Nolan told him separately.

revision.text: Cobb's wedding ring is his totem, not Mal's top. Notice how multiple people spun the top. It wasn't reliable. Cobb is dreaming every time you see him wearing his wedding ring (maybe because he would see Mal only when he's dreaming, in which they would still be married/she would still be alive/etc.) The ending could most likely be real because he's not wearing his wedding ring.

revision.text: This page contains the levels that were used as part of [[the Saito Extraction Job]] [[Category:Jobs]]

[[File:Remember the stein job.png|thumb|300px|right|Arthur remembers the Stein Job...]] The '''Stein Extraction Job''' was a job undertaken by [[Arthur]] and [[Cobb]]. [[Cobb]] used the "[[Mr. Charles (tactic)|Mr. Charles]]" tactic, but it failed when the [[subject]] [[Lucid Dreaming|realized that he was dreaming]], and his subconscious tore the team to pieces.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-64.37.167.164-20101220195219]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-64.37.167.164-20101220195219]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsoniu...
revision.text: The top falls, but it doesn't matter. The story was never set in any reality. The top level story that is assumed to be reality is in fact the first level of Cobb's neverending dream. The idea of the top falling in reality was conceived by him in that level 1 dream. Therefore, the top falling means that Cobb is just in the first level of the dream. There are plenty of clues along the way to support this: - Whenever Cobb travels in "reality" he always is shown at his destination, never traveling to it. This fits with Cobb telling Ariadne that in the dream you never know how you got somewhere, you just are there. - When in Yusuf's shop, there are multiple hints that Cobb is well aware of the exact compound needed and has experience, and it's at least in my mind suggested that Cobb himself is one of the dreamers that go to that shop to "wake up". - When talking to Mal (I forget exactly where/when)she says "you promised me that we would grow old together". Cobb replies "we did". If there is any truth to that then that means that everything has to be a dream, because both Cobb and Mal are always seen as 30-somethings. - I think that Mal did jump off the building, but in the 1st level of the dream, which means she is now in reality, as an old woman. Her forays into Cobbs dreams are either attempts to get him out, or are merely guilty projections of Cobb's. The guilt comes from him unwillingness or inability to leave the dream.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-98.117.114.44-20101226084109]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-98.117.114.44-20101226084109]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsoniu...
revision.text: His wedding ring should not be considered a totem. multiple people have stated this already but there is too much evidence showing that the whole movie was in a dream. That through out the ENTIRE movie, we never saw reality. Remember the beginning, cobb visits an old saito. and remember near the end, cobb visits saito. without analysis, we see these two events being the same. but they aren't. the film makers added a subtle difference in the dialogue between cobb and saito that does not match the beginning of the film with the near-end of it. thus, his visit with saito was actually two separate visits. Thus, the beginning of the film was a separate event. He has visited old saito two times instead of what we first believe is once. and notice how in the very beginning of the film, it jumps from him talking to old saito to him in a completely other dream. like he said to ariadne, in dreams, you often jump from one place to another without even realizing it since your brain tries to piece everything together into something that looks like reality. and the many number of times when he went from one place of the world to another (like africa in that once chase scene) without any smooth transitions or plausible mode of travel. the spinning top is USELESS as a totem. mal (if it even is her) had the totem in "reality", but still killed herself (supposedly. remember. the whole movie could just be a dream). this means that the spinning top fails to assure the user that he or she is in reality or not. in other words, the spinning top has no power over dictating what should be perceived as reality or not. in fact, the spinning top could just be an entity of assurance used to prevent one from waking up from a dream by continuously convincing the person that he is not dreaming. When cobb spins the top and it falls, he thinks he's in reality. but for all we know, he could actually be obama.... sleeping in the white house having this dream where he is mr. cobb. and the whole concept of inception, dreaming extraction, totems, ariadne, the team, mal... EVERYTHING... is simply part of the dream. think about your own dreams folks. don't they often seem complicated to the point where you're surprised you dreamed about it? aren't you sometimes some one else in your dream.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-98.117.114.44-20101226084511]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-98.117.114.44-20101226084511]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsoniu...
revision.text: I agree. i believe the whole movie from beginning to end was a dream. reality was never shown. a lot of people believe that it's open ended, but I think the film makers left a treat for people who actually go through the trouble of analyzing the film. the treat being that there is sufficient evidence to show that the whole movie was a dream.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-76.20.93.107-20101227040309]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-76.20.93.107-20101227040309]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsonius]...
revision.text: Dom Cobb is awake. If you paid attention, he said "in my dreams we're still together", and he only wears his ring when in the dream. At the end he was not wearing his ring and he finally saw his children's faces. In the dream the top never wobbles, at all, it just continually spins.

revision.comment: Created page with "I have seen Inception 3 times And what i get is as under along with a question perhaps the most fundamental question. (after obviously this question that how 2 people can share a…"
revision.text:
I have seen Inception 3 times And what i get is as under along with a question perhaps the most fundamental question. (after obviously this question that how 2 people can share a dream?) Limbo was said to be an unconstructed dream space, where a person gets stuck forever (almost, as time at this state is almost infinite).Now if the team is heavily sedated, they wont wake by any means (because they r sedated).lets assume limbo was not level4 but something else ,the time duration for cobb & saito in limbo is beyond calculation (its definetely t>>100yrs) before the sedation wears out (even if we assume yusef was not sedated ,came out from level 1 when others arrived,stopped further sedation & kicked everybody up except the 2 because they wont wake).cobb`s & saito`s coming back to reality instantaneusly as they got shot in limbo doesnt add up).i believe even few minutes would turn into infinite time in limbo as limbo isnt supposed to follow timeX20 theory.ok if we assume limbo to be level 4, why it is given a complex name as limbo? if someone hasnt decided what to construct in level 1 & gets there then level 1 could also be called a limbo.It means there is something different in limbo which dosent follow normal dream & compound rules and possibly the time can be infinite.
Then HOW ANYONE GETS OUT OF A LIMBO?
sfg
xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx
sdfgsgsgsgsgsgss

<center>http://i842.photobucket.com/albums/zz341/trilby13/MLBanner2.png </center>
<center>{{Quote|'''Actually, know.'''}}</center>
'''This is your first test. Stay calm.''' Hello, I'm '''Minish Link''', your average, pretty much normal dude. Well, not really. I'm a guy and I like cake. 'Nuff said, am I right?
== About Me == Well, since you asked so kindly. Wiki editing is one of my favourite activities, and in general I like to make things look fancy and/or shmancy. Hence the banner and quote template above. I hail from the United States of America, but due to having a fondness for British/Canadian/whatever spellings I tend to use those most of the time instead. My favourite activities are playing videogames (''Metroid'', ''LittleBIGPlanet'', ''The Legend of Zelda'', ''Mario'', ''Pokemon'', etc.), writing (my own stories or ''Zelda'' fan fiction), drawing, spriting, and reading. My academic interests include anatomy, psychology, and architecture (I'd like to take physics, but unfortunately I'm unable to at the time). I'm homeschooled. So let's get to know eachother some more, shall we?
=== Random Facts About Yours Truly ===
* So, gaming. As mentioned previously, I like ''Metroid'', ''Zelda'', ''Pokemon'', ''LittleBIGPlanet'', ''Mario'', and a few other smaller franchises. I guess I like ''Sonic the Hedgehog'' too, but I'm more of a Mario guy myself. ** As for systems, I own a Playstation 3, a Playstation Portable, two Nintendo DS Lites (one is broken), a Nintendo DSi, two iPod Touches (one 2nd gen and one 4th gen), a Game Boy Advance, a Game Boy Advance SP, a Gamecube, and a Nintendo Wii. *** For iPod games, I like Cut the Rope, ''Infinity Blade'', ''Final Fantasy'', and ''Lego Harry Potter: Years 1 - 4''. There are also some other ones I play sometimes. * I like to write ''Zelda'' fan fiction with my best friend/girlfriend. * [[Inception (2010 film)|''Inception'']] wise, my favourite characters are [[Ariadne]] and [[Eames]]. The movie in its entirety fascinates me as I've always been interested in dreams; however, I've never yet managed to have a lucid dream or, for that matter, even experience a dream as it happens. I experience them only as memories that generally come to me later in the day. Occasionally I research dream information and the like. My favourite part of the movie is probably either the beginning in which Cobb gathers his team members or the rainy city part. ** Ariadne is one of my favourite characters because of her job as [[The Team|The Architect]]. * My favourite food is bacon. Go figure. Because of this I like Bacon Cheeseburgers and TGI Friday's potato skins. A lot. * I sprite often, sometimes splicing pokemon sprites or editing other sprites, but mostly just random scratch sprites of my own creation. * I often go on [[w:c:zelda|Zeldapedia]]. I'm a rollbacker there.
:''Page will be continued...at some point. I'm also a procrastinator. Bigtime. Maybe I'll procrastinate some more now...Nah, I'll do it tomorrow.''
== See also == * '''[http://www.flickr.com/photos/zeldaquest Me on Flickr]''': Mostly random crap. * '''[http://supersmashkart9.deviantart.com Me on devArt]''': Same as above. * '''[http://http://s842.photobucket.com/albums/zz341/trilby13/ Me on Photobucket]''': Usually random test stuff for wikis. * '''[http://zelda.wikia.com/wiki/User:Minish_Link Me on Zeldapedia]''': Me on Zeldapedia...just my userpage. * '''[http://dragcave.net/user/Gentleman-Thief Me on Dragcave]''': My dragons.

== Kick page ==
Do not discuss article content within the article itself. It should be pretty evident that that is not the purpose that an article is meant to serve. Please use the [[Talk:Kick|talk page]] for the article if you want to have a discussion. I will be forced to block you from the wiki if you wish to persist in these edit wars with administrators. {{Samsoniussig}} 05:34, December 30, 2010 (UTC)
:You may add those types of issues in the talk page, but other members should discuss it before you just go gung-ho and place it into the article. Besides that, it was not worded in accordance with the way that other articles on this wiki are written. Please post it on the talk page, and we'll see where it goes from there. {{Samsoniussig}} 07:12, December 30, 2010 (UTC)

==Welcome== Hi, welcome to Inception Wiki. Thanks for your edit to the '''Dream Within A Dream''' page.
'''[[Special:Userlogin|Please sign in and create a user name]]'''. It's an easy way to keep track of your contributions and helps you communicate with the rest of the community.
Please leave a message on [[User talk:Bastian964|my talk page]] if I can help with anything! -- [[User:Bastian964|Bastian964]] ([[User_talk:Bastian964|Talk]]) 14:04, December 31, 2010

Err, shouldn't this page be called "Dream" or "Dreams"? I'd move it myself but I don't want to start any arguments so I'll ask community opinion before I do anything. -'''[[User:Minish Link|<font color="#B0E0E6">Minish</font>]] [[User Talk: Minish Link|<font color="#003366">Link</font>]]''' 16:35, December 31, 2010 (UTC)
==Ability to manipulate the dream?== What basis is there for the comment that sleepers sharing the dream are able to manipulate the dream? I don't remember seeing direct evidence of this. [[Special:Contributions/78.157.124.160|78.157.124.160]] 23:58, January 13, 2011 (UTC)
Ariadne modifies the physics of the dream the second time she and Cobb share a dream. She folds a street on top of another street, and recreates a bridge that she crosses everday to get to college. She modifies the dream too much, so Dom's subconscious starts attacking her. Then Mal stabs her and she wakes up.--[[User:SilverBlade784|SilverBlade784]]<sup>[[User talk:SilverBlade784|Talk]]</sup> 01:19, January 14, 2011 (UTC)
But that is ''her'' dream. She is learning how to create the dream world so she can become their architect. This also lets Cobb demonstrate how the projections of a dream-sharer's subconscious will be alerted to the dreamer (and, by extension, other strangers in the dream) when he or she changes the dream too much. The dreamer is the only one who can change the reality of the dream, but I still don't remember directly seeing dream-sharers being able to affect the dream in any way. The only aspect of this that falls into a grey zone is to what extent a dream-sharer brings his or her own belongings into the dream - clothes, totems and weapons being the central examples. [[Special:Contributions/78.157.124.160|78.157.124.160]] 01:39, January 15, 2011 (UTC)
The sleepers aren't bringing their belongings into the dream. They create those belongings at will. If you noticed, Eames created his gun out of thin air. Furthermore, a more direct example of manipulation of the dream by sleepers is Eames's ability to change shape. [[Special:Contributions/68.160.130.16|68.160.130.16]] 15:35, January 15, 2011 (UTC)
Ah, yes, but I wouldn't call that manipulating the dream itself as much as having an influence on what's in it - if that makes any sense. Anyway, if they're able to create their belongings out of thin air (we must assume they do that subconsciously with their clothes as well, for example), it brings up a question about the totems: Totems are designed to be uncopyable by other dreamers, but if dream-sharers create their own belongings, wouldn't that mean they're in control of their own totems as well, even in other people's dreams? [[Special:Contributions/78.157.124.160|78.157.124.160]] 14:23, January 20, 2011 (UTC)
Totems aren't designed to be uncopyable, they are design to have a unique weight, balance, feel, etc. so that people who don't know the property of the totem can't recreate it perfectly in the dream. Also yes you can control your own totem in other people's dreams, that's how Cobb's totem works, in a dream he can force the totem to have an incorrect balance (ie spin forever). [[User:Bastian964|Bastian]][[User_talk:Bastian964|9]][[Special:Contributions/Bastian964|6]][[Special:Editcount/Bastian964|4]] 15:02, January 21, 2011 (UTC)
I see ... I hadn't thought about it that way. Thanks for clearing it up. [[Special:Contributions/78.157.124.160|78.157.124.160]] 19:36, January 22, 2011 (UTC)

The '''Wasteland''' is the dream [[Yusuf]] used to demonstrate his special sedative to Cobb.

[[File:workshop.jpg|thumb|right|350px|The Workshop]]
'''The Workshop''' is the place where [[The Team]] prepared for the [[The Fischer Inception Job]]. It is located in an abandoned warehouse in Paris, France.
It is here that [[Ariadne]] was taught to build dreams and the rest of the team prepared for their respective parts, including Yusuf creating a customized sedative that leaves the dreamer still able to wake by a [[Kick]].
==Gallery== <gallery> workshop.jpg|Arthur, Ariadne, and Cobb in the workshop Inception team.png|[[The Team]] at the workshop The Team Planning.jpg|Planning in the workshop </gallery>

== Unofficial name template == As you well know there are some pages that have names we create for them due to them not being named in the official storyline (i.e. [[Thin Man]]). This template would, if given a better description, be placed atop any page with an unofficial name.
{| style="border:1px solid #AAA; background-color:#333333; padding:5px; margin:1em auto 1em auto; width:100%;" |<center>'''{{PAGENAME}} does not have an official name.''' It may be referred to as such in the storyline, but it has not been officially named. Alternatively, it may be a name popular among fans. </center> |}

{{Infobox dream |image=japanese castle limbo.jpg |imagesize=250px |name=The Palace |level= |dreamer= |subject= |kick=Gunshots |sleepers=[[Dominic Cobb|Cobb]]
[[Saito]] }} '''The Palace''' is a large castle constructed by [[Saito]] in [[Limbo]] some point after his death in [[Snow-Covered Mountains (dream)|the Snow-Covered Mountains dream]] from a gunshot wound. It just above the shore of a large beach and seemingly is populated by [[projections]] of Japanese soldiers. Saito himself is seen in a large dining chamber, where the soldiers bring [[Dominic Cobb]], his totem, and a gun, after he washes up on the shore. It is here Saito remembers that Limbo is not his reality and Cobb convinces him to "come back, so they can be young men together again". Saito and Cobb then presumably kill themselves with Cobb's gun, and they then wake up again on the flight to Los Angeles with [[Robert Fischer]] and the rest of [[The Team|the team]]. This castle is virtually identical to [[The Japanese Castle (dream)|the one]] constructed by [[Arthur]] for [[The Saito Extraction Job]]. Unlike Arthur's castle, the limbo version is filled with Japanese millitary-like guards instead of party-goers and suited security guards. The limbo version is also during daytime. ==Gallery== limbo japanese castle interior.jpg|The dining hall [[Category:Places]]

[[File:limbo coast.jpg|thumb|right|250px|The Coast, in Limbo]]
'''The Coast''' is the area in [[Limbo]] in which [[Dominic Cobb|Dom]] and [[Mallorie Cobb|Mal]] constructed a city and spent much if not all of their time in. Dom and Mal washed up on the shore when they first entered Limbo. When Dom and [[Ariadne]] had to enter Limbo to rescue [[Robert Fischer]] from Dom's projection of Mal, they were washed up on the shore with crumbling buildings nearby. [[Category:Places]]

revision.comment: Created page with "You have hit upon a key discrepancy. Understanding this discrepancy is, in my view, the key to understanding the movie Inception. As the film tells us, Limbo is unconstructed dr…"
revision.text:
You have hit upon a key discrepancy. Understanding this discrepancy is, in my view, the key to understanding the movie Inception.
As the film tells us, Limbo is unconstructed dream space. It's dangerous to go there because it's easy to forget that you're dreaming--in other words, in Limbo you get disoriented. It doesn't operate like other dreams in that (a) there are no projections--only what you build, and (b) the dream won't collapse, at least not for decades. To get out of Limbo you have to remember that you are dreaming.
This is what the film tells us. It reinforces this through the story of Mal and Cobb--how they ended up in Limbo, and what it took to get out.
Given this, we should question whether what Cobb and Ariadne experience together is actually Limbo. I don't think it is--I think it is Cobb's dream of Limbo from when he was previously there with Mal. He believes it is Limbo, but it is not. In this dream level 4, Mal is a projection, as always, and Fischer is also a projection. That's how Cobb knows where Mal and Fischer will be. In other words, on this level Cobb and Ariadne are sharing a dream that appears to be the Limbo Cobb remembers but is not.
How do we know this? There are at least two clues. (1) Most importantly, this level is unstable. Buildings are collapsing into the ocean, the houses are dilapidated, and towards the end there is a huge storm and everything is falling apart. How could this possibly happen in Limbo, which is unconstructed ream space? It couldn't--everthing is collapsing because it is a dream. (2) Wouldn't it ruin Cobb's inception of Fischer to have Fischer bound and gagged by Cobb's dead wife? I think so. On this level Fischer is a projection of Cobb's, much like Browning is a projection of Fischer's on level 2. Note that Fischer is revived on level 3 by a defibrillator, so he does not need a kick on any deeper level necessarily.
The real Limbo is what Saito and Cobb experience. Saito is there because he died on level 3 from the gunshot on level 1. Cobb is there because he drowned on level 1 in the back of the van. Notice how disoriented Cobb and Saito are here. Cobb doesn't appear to know where he is as he eats his oatmeal. It is only through the shared memory of those lines of dialogue that Saito and Cobb are able to remember that they are dreaming and get themselves out of Limbo.
is this distinction important? Because there is a secret inception--Cobb's. Cobb thinks that he is in Limbo, he thinks Fischer is dead, and he thinks that his regret over what happened to Mal is what led to these catastrophes. This leads him down further, and it is at level 4 that he realizes that he has to let go. This is a positive idea planted deep into his mind that he thinks is his. It leads him to make radical changes in his life--he stops worrying about what is real and what is not and lives without regret with his kids.
But is it really his idea? If you watch the movie again, you should watch closely how Saito and Ariadne act towards Cobb. You'll notice repeat lines of dialogue and Ariadne's persistent fascination and interest in Cobb's thoughts. In my opinion, Saito and Ariadne were involved in an inception of Cobb. This inception might start in the real world--if what we are led to believe is reality actually is--but it must be masked by the mission to incept Fischer, or else Cobb won't venture further. Notice that Saito and Ariadne insist that they be brought along on Cobb's mission--Cobb didn't intend to take either originally. Notice how Saito repeatedly tells Cobb that he doesn't want to be "an old man filled with regret." Notice that it is Ariadne that convinces Cobb to enter the last dream level, and notice that Ariadne brought along the dream equipment in her backpack.
Whether the rest of the team was involved is unclear. Whether the Fischer inception was a ruse or real is also unclear--I lean towards real, but who knows. But the key o understanding the film is that Cobb is an untrustworthy narrator, just like Guy Pearce in Memento, and that he is actually being incepted during the film. Understand that, and you'll get much more from the movie.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-98.18.3.244-20110101014641/@comment-Dustpelts-20110101222729]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-98.18.3.244-20110101014641/@comment-Dustpelts-20110101222729]]: Automatical...
revision.text: Theres more to it than that.

This started as a response post, but I think it merits a page. Inception doesn't overtly explain how Cobb gets from "his limbo" to Saito's. It also doesn't explain notable differences between the two limbos (why is Fischer young and Saito old?) or why Cobb appears so disoriented in the latter but not the former. Understanding these differences is, in my view, the key to understanding the movie Inception.
As the film tells us, Limbo is unconstructed dream space. It's dangerous to go there because it's easy to forget that you're dreaming--in other words, in Limbo you get disoriented. It doesn't operate like other dreams in that (a) there are no projections--only what you build, and (b) the dream won't collapse, at least not for decades. To get out of Limbo you have to remember that you are dreaming.
This is what the film tells us. It reinforces this through the story of Mal and Cobb--how they ended up in Limbo, and what it took to get out.
Given this, we should question whether what Cobb and Ariadne experience together is actually Limbo. I don't think it is. I think it is Cobb's dream of Limbo from when he was previously there with Mal. He believes it is Limbo--much like Fischer believes that dream level 1 is reality--but it is not. In this dream level 4, Mal is a projection, as always, <u>and Fischer is also a projection</u>. That's how Cobb knows where Mal and Fischer will be. In other words, on this level Cobb and Ariadne are sharing a dream that appears to be the Limbo that Cobb remembers, but is not.
How do we know this? There are at least two clues. (1) Most importantly, this level is unstable. Buildings are collapsing into the ocean, the houses are dilapidated, and towards the end there is a huge storm and everything is falling apart. How could this possibly happen in Limbo, which is unconstructed dream space? It couldn't--everthing is collapsing because it is a dream. (2) Wouldn't it ruin Cobb's inception of Fischer to have Fischer bound and gagged by Cobb's dead wife? I think so. On this level Fischer is a projection of Cobb's, much like Browning is a projection of Fischer's on level 2. Note that Fischer is revived on level 3 by a defibrillator, so he does not need a kick on any deeper level necessarily.
The real Limbo is what Saito and Cobb experience. Saito is there because he died on level 3 from the gunshot on level 1. Cobb is there because he drowned on level 1 in the back of the van. Notice how disoriented Cobb and Saito are here. Cobb doesn't appear to know where he is as he eats his oatmeal. It is only through the shared memory of those lines of dialogue that Saito and Cobb are able to remember that they are dreaming and get themselves out of Limbo.
Why is this distinction important? Because there is a secret inception--Cobb's. Cobb thinks that he is in Limbo, he thinks Fischer is dead, and he thinks that his regret over what happened to Mal is what led to these catastrophes--as Ariadne says, Cobb's regret and guilt is what feeds and creates his projection of Mal. This realization leads him down further, and it is at level 4 that he realizes that he has to let go. He realizes that he fulfilled his marital committment to Mal and that he did what he could for her and has to let go. (Whether this is true or not, we don't know. It's possible that Cobb and Mal actually didn't "grow old together" in limbo--it could be merely a positive memory that Cobb convinces himself of, much like Fischer became convinced that his father was "disappointed" that he tried to emulate him, which ''wasn't actually true''.) This is a positive idea planted deep into his mind that he thinks is his idea. This idea leads Cobb to make radical changes in his life--he stops worrying about what is real and what is not (recall that he does not wait to see if the top drops) and lives without regret by returning to his kids. (Whether the ending is a dream or not is another question entirely.)
But is it really his idea? If you watch the movie again, you should closely watch how Saito and Ariadne act towards Cobb. You'll notice repeat lines of dialogue and Ariadne's persistent fascination and interest in Cobb's thoughts. In my opinion, Saito and Ariadne were involved in an inception of Cobb. This inception might start in the real world--if what we are led to believe is reality actually is reality--but it must be masked by the mission to incept Fischer, or else Cobb won't venture further. Notice that Saito and Ariadne insist that they be brought along on Cobb's mission--Cobb didn't intend to take either originally. Notice how Saito repeatedly tells Cobb that he doesn't want to be "an old man filled with regret, waiting to die alone." Notice the music that is used to signal the collapses of dreams means "regret nothing." Notice that it is Ariadne that convinces Cobb to enter the last dream level, and notice that Ariadne brought along the dream equipment in her backpack.
Whether the rest of the team was involved is unclear. Whether the Fischer inception was a ruse or real is also unclear--I lean towards real, but who knows. But the key to understanding the film is that Cobb is an untrustworthy narrator, just like Guy Pearce in Memento, and that <u>he is actually being incepted during the film</u>. Understand that, and you'll get much more from the movie.
Taking it a step further, I think that Cobb actually was not under suspicion for his wife's death. He merely convinced himself that he was so that he could avoid going back to his kids, to avoid experiencing the tremendous guilt that he feels. This is why he does not look at their faces--to avoid the guilt from having caused their mother's death. Michael Caine is Mal's father, and his scene early in the movie jives with this view. "Come back to reality, Dom." "A stuffed animal won't convince the kids that they still have a father."
Caine sets up Cobb with Ariadne, so it's entirely possible that he instructed her to perform an inception down below. This would mean that Saito would have to be in on it too because he agrees to make the phone call. [[Category:Blog posts]]

page.title: User blog comment:Wilis668/The Incepton of Cobb/@comment-Bastian964-20110101225738

revision.comment: Created page with "Okay, firstly the movie doesn't explain how he got through to Saito's limbo because there is no such thing as separate limbos. Limbo is one big space which is all connected. Also…"
revision.text:
Okay, firstly the movie doesn't explain how he got through to Saito's limbo because there is no such thing as separate limbos. Limbo is one big space which is all connected. Also age is controllable in Limbo if you know you are dreaming (Mal and Cobb changed age easily see movie). Saito is old because he lived until he was 90 years old in limbo (see the movie script) when he did not have control of his age. Fischer is young because he hasn't been in Limbo long. Cobb knows here Fischer and Mal was because he knows how his projection of Mal thinks and they used to live there. Why couldn't everything be collapsing, the people who formed the structures are gone and without that reinforcing presence Limbo begins to return to it's unconstructed state. It wouldn't ruin there inception to have Fischer bound and gagged because they used the Mr. Charles tactic to make it believe other people are attacking his mind and they are trying to defend it. Ariadne and Saito would have neither the skill nor any motives to commit inception on Cobb. Furthermore, both of them are so disorient because they have been there about fifty years (see the shooting script).
I'm sorry but your theory is founded on absolutely nothing.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-98.117.114.44-20101226084109/@comment-174.31.5.111-20110102015003]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-98.117.114.44-20101226084109/@comment-174.31.5.111-20110102015003]]: A...
revision.text: I've never dreamt I was someone else, ever before. Always myself, but always with different people. Yes, I see your points and I applaud you for your efforts, but I don't think I'm sold on this idea yet. I think we do see reality, and in the end Cobb is in reality. The wedding ring isn't a totem, it's just that Cobb said, "When i'm dreaming, we're still together." So in his dreams, his wedding ring is there on his finger. But in reality, it isn't there. Why in some dreams would he be wearing it, and other dreams he would not? And lets do say it is ALL a dream, Molly was right and she is alive. Don't you think she would have woken up Cobb? or re-entered his dream to prove this to him, that they have reality mixed up? Because you can enter a dream halfway though. As proven by Aiadne when she finds Cobb and goes under to see his dreams. And quickly: I don't think Obama is that creative:P Okay back to the topic; in all movies, they hardly ever show getting from one place to another. Especially long travel, so Africa is no difference. BUT when they finish the Fischer Inception, you clearly see them on the plan, then afterwards, everyone in the airport getting there things, finding their rides, and going home. (well at least for Cobb, though I did enjoy seeing the sign from Fischer's driver). So I still think that reality is preceived in this movie. And for the dialoge difference, that's just Hollywood. They almost always change one or two lines so it's not the exact same and you don't feel as if it's just repeating, you need to discover that for yourself if you payed attention. Please excuse any typos, or errors, I'm typing this in a hurry.

I'm sorry that you don't like it. I'll stick to my interpretation though, because it ties up all of the loose ends. It explains the "two limbos" problem. It explains the age discrepancy problem. It explains why Ariadne appears to know so much about dreams and dreaming. It explains why Cobb won't look at his kids' faces throughout the movie.
Above all, I find it the mot emotionally satisfying interpretation. Cobb is wracked with guilt and can't bear to see his kids. An inception is organized to convince Cobb to let Mal go, to convince him that her death is not his fault. The inception works, and he goes back to his kids and sees their faces.
m,ygfkmk,

revision.text: i think finally cobb reunites with his children,because if he doesn't it makes no sense.he accomplishes the job which he wanted to accomplish. i think nolan just made a trick at the end to scratch their minds it indeed falls.

revision.comment: Created page with "Right, I agree. But there's no denying that Cobb appears disoriented in the second limbo, but not the first. And there's also no explanation for how Cobb and Ariadne "dreamed" th…"
revision.text: Right, I agree. But there's no denying that Cobb appears disoriented in the second limbo, but not the first. And there's also no explanation for how Cobb and Ariadne "dreamed" their way into the first limbo while Fischer "died" his way there. These things troubled me initially, and my explanation accounts for them.

revision.comment: Created page with "Cobb is disorient because they have been in there so long that Saito is now 90 years old (see the script for proof that he is actually ninety). Before you ask why Cobb doesn't lo…"
revision.text: Cobb is disorient because they have been in there so long that Saito is now 90 years old (see the script for proof that he is actually ninety). Before you ask why Cobb doesn't look old, I've already told you that in Limbo your age can be manipulated, just like how in normal dreams your appearance can be manipulated (see the script for more proof).

revision.comment: Created page with "Then why isn't Fisher old in the "first limbo"? He died a good two minuted before Cobb and Ariadne entered this stage, yet he appears the same age. Saito dies ten minutes earlier…"
revision.text: Then why isn't Fisher old in the "first limbo"? He died a good two minuted before Cobb and Ariadne entered this stage, yet he appears the same age. Saito dies ten minutes earlier and looks ninety, shouldn't Fisher look 50 or so?
I don't edit this wiki often but I come here to see all the information. It's a great database.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-24.5.69.22-20110105042504]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-24.5.69.22-20110105042504]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsonius]]" t...
revision.text:
Just my thoughts here:
I believe that Cobb is most likely in reality at the very end of the movie.
As stated many times before, Cobb is seen with a wedding ring inside of a dream or before Mal's death. Cobb can easily be seen in multiple places without his ring that is implied to be before he enters a dream (for the duration of this post, I will commonly use this term, or a similar term, because I have no way of completely proving my point). I agree that Cobb's ring is in no way his totem, but rather subconscious guilt, as are all of the projections of Mal throughout any dream.
You must also be aware that Professor Miles is only seen in what is implied to be reality. Because Miles was seen at the end of the movie, in what Cobb thinks is reality, Cobb is likely not in a dream because of his lack of screen time when the characters are implied to be dreaming. I've noticed one commenter who believes Miles is using Inception to extract information about the death of Mal. Interesting thought, but the problem in that theory lies with Cobb's totem. The top, in any other person's dream, would never wobble because it never loses momentum. The top is seen wobbling at the end, and it is implied that the top is losing momentum and would soon come to a complete halt.
Interesting points that may be used against my theory:
#1. The dreams at the beginning and end differing.
Using this logic, it is implied that these two events happened separately. If it were so, then it is possible that Cobb is inside a dream throughout the movie. Even so, Cobb would still be in reality in the end, because dying in Limbo seems to send the dreamer, and anybody sharing the dream, back to reality (regardless of how many levels of dreams are being used). It could also be explained by stating that this is a movie, and maybe they got some of it wrong/changed it intentionally to make it not seem boring.
#2. Non-smooth transitions.
Of course these broken scenes are known to happen when implied dream, but of course I can use my "it was a dream all along" theory from earlier to explain this. Also, it can be argued that this was just movie magic (because a movie where half the time we saw the broken down events of them going somewhere around the world would be boring).
Another note:
You must also remember that if it was a dream, then every main character seen in dream would be projections, and would also attack Cobb if he changed the layout of the dream. It would be impossible for Ariadne to actually plan the layout another dream, considering that the projections know only as much as Cobb does (as seen in the level 3 dream during the Fischer Inception when Ariadne tells Cobb a secret entrance for their comrades to use, only to broadcast their location to the militarized projections). Also, it is unknown whether or not you can share a dream with projections, considering they are only the subconscious of the person (or people) sharing the dream. Using what is seen in the movie, I conclude that one cannot consciously bring a projection into a dream within a dream because the projection(s) have no conscious being.
-Splodeydope

page.title: User blog comment:Wilis668/The Incepton of Cobb/@comment-Lord David-20110105140755

revision.comment: Created page with "I think it is an easy problem to solve, though a bit odd, obviously Cobb had his own limbo to much linked with Mal, and when the projection of her realizes that she had gone mad,…"
revision.text: I think it is an easy problem to solve, though a bit odd, obviously Cobb had his own limbo to much linked with Mal, and when the projection of her realizes that she had gone mad, the limbo gets dark because of the effect causes because of the water on the truck in Level 1, and Cobb stays to find Saito, who had also been in the Limbo, but a longer time and so he had grown older. When Cobb tells Saito he's dreaming and that he's noth in reality, both come back to the real world, where the Fischer job had already been done.

==Cobb's totem vs. regular totems==
I propose it be added to the article that Cobb's totem works differently than the regular totems as explained by him to Ariadne. A regular totem is the owner's way of checking if he or she is in another person's dream (as only in the owner's own dream would the totem have the correct characteristics), but Cobb's totem plainly tells him if he's in a dream or not. I have yet to come upon a satisfactory explanation for this small, but significant difference in function, but as it is evident from the film itself that it is so, I believe it should be added to the article. [[Special:Contributions/78.157.124.160|78.157.124.160]] 23:09, January 5, 2011 (UTC)
No, it only tells him if he is in another person's dream like anyone else's totem. Anyone who knows the balance can recreate how it falls. Thus if he wants it to, in his dream it falls correctly. If he wants it to continue spinning, it will. This does not mean however that it works any differently from any other totem. Do not add such speculation to the article please. [[User:Bastian964|Bastian]][[User_talk:Bastian964|9]][[Special:Contributions/Bastian964|6]][[Special:Editcount/Bastian964|4]] 23:33, January 5, 2011 (UTC)
Having thought about it, I had misunderstood how a totem can not only be used to test if you're in another person's dream, but also if you're in your own dream. In another person's dream, the totem's characteristics will be off, and the owner will be unable to change them. In the owner's own dream, he or she will be able to change the characteristics at will. In the real world, the totem will simply have the correct characteristics. Thank you for clearing up that mistake for me. [[Special:Contributions/78.157.124.160|78.157.124.160]] 08:30, January 7, 2011 (UTC)
No problem. [[User:Bastian964|Bastian]][[User_talk:Bastian964|9]][[Special:Contributions/Bastian964|6]][[Special:Editcount/Bastian964|4]] 11:23, January 7, 2011 (UTC)
Yet it says if Cobbs totem does not fall. If Cobb is in my dream and he spins his totem it will fall. My subconcious knows that a top does not spin forever. It will make the top fall. However it will not fall how Cobb expects it to fall indicating to him he is in a dream and not in control. The issue then remains how will Cobb know if he is dreaming. He can not rely on his totem. As if he spins it it reacts the same in his dream as someone elses dream. The only way he can accuratly use the totem is to will it to do something other then what it is supposed to do. Like Spin forever. [[User:Aknot|Aknot]] 12:36, December 21, 2011 (UTC)
People can change small things in other people's dreams even if they aren't the architect, thus the totems works. Also it is specifically stated in the movie so unless you have a citation, don't change it. [[User:Bastian964|Bastian]][[User_talk:Bastian964|9]][[Special:Contributions/Bastian964|6]][[Special:Editcount/Bastian964|4]] 20:51, December 23, 2011 (UTC)
What is specifically cited in the movie? There is no indication in the movie what the properties of COBBS totem is. As a matter of fact there is notihng in the movie that indicates what special properties the top has so Cobb can designate if it is true acting or not.
Above post by me. [[User:Aknot|Aknot]] 21:20, December 23, 2011 (UTC)
I think that Cobb's totem is his wedding ring and not the spinning top. The spinning top is Mal's totem, so the top shouldn't work properly for him. Plus, in his dreams, he is still together with Mal, so he still wears his wedding ring. In reality, he isn't with Mal anymore, so he doesn't wear his wedding ring. [[Special:Contributions/68.231.26.200|68.231.26.200]] 18:35, August 14, 2012 (UTC)
As 68.231.26.200 said, Cobb's totem is actually his wedding ring. He says in the movie that whenever he is dreaming, he is still together with Mal, therefore, wearing his ring. On every dreaming scene that his left hand can be seen, he's wearing it, as of when he's not dreaming, you can't spot it. [[User:Gianlucabrancacci|Gianlucabrancacci]] ([[User talk:Gianlucabrancacci|talk]]) 21:05, January 17, 2013 (UTC)gianlucabrancacci
What if Cobb's totem is not actually his wedding ring. It was described in the movie that a totem helps the user distinguish reality from a dream. What if Cobb's actual totem was not the ring, but was actuall Mal. As it was said in previous posts, "whenever he is dreaming, he is still together with Mal". Maybe this is why Cobb did not want Ariadne butting into his thoughts about the past. Cobb could not get over Mal and therefore could not bear the thought of seeing his children. Seeing Mal meant that he was still dreaming. In the end of the movie, he finally got over Mal and, therefore, lost his ability to distinguish dream from reality, and was able to see his kid's faces.'''[[Special:Contributions/67.169.149.69|67.169.149.69]] 08:39, May 16, 2013 (UTC)'''

revision.comment: Created page with "I agree with the whole film being an inception on Cobb, but I'm not too sure there was a fourth dream level, and then Limbo. I think the place which Cobb and Ariadne enter to fin…"
revision.text:
I agree with the whole film being an inception on Cobb, but I'm not too sure there was a fourth dream level, and then Limbo. I think the place which Cobb and Ariadne enter to find Fischer is the same place where Cobb meets with the aged Saito: Limbo. The reason there were so many buildings, was because it was actually Limbo. I know the film says it's unconstructed dream space, but it also says, according to Arthur, that: "Nothing is down there! Except for whatever might have been left behind by anyone sharing the dream whose been trapped there before. Which in our case is just you." In the last sentence he refers to Cobb, who had been in Limbo with his wife before. Those two created the buildings, and when they left, they simply remained there. They may have started collapsing because they were old. Last time Cobb had been there was years ago.
I think the reason that Saito looked decades older, and Fischer looked the same, was because Saito was in Limbo for a longer time than Fischer. Remember that with the sedative they were using, time in a dream lasted 20 times longer than in real life, or than the previous dream. If the time that passed between Fischer's death, and Cobb's and Ariadne's entrance to Limbo was around two minutes, and if they were going down to another dream level and not Limbo, it would be 40 minutes that passed where Fischer was. That makes sense with the theory that it's actually another dream, and not Limbo, because Fischer didn't age (well, he'd be 40 minutes older). But I'm more convinced that it's actually Limbo. It is said in the film that time is stretched in Limbo a lot more than it is in dream levels, but it isn't said by how much. For all we know, Fischer could've been there for ten years. That wouldn't change his appearance by the time Cobb and Ariadne entered Limbo. Now, Saito was in the same Limbo as Cobb, Mal, Ariadne, and Fischer, but he must've been far away from them. After Ariadne and Fischer woke up from Limbo, Cobb took a long time to find Saito. Remember, Limbo is a huge space. During that time, he must've got lost, or forgotten about Saito. Saito's brain must've "turned to scrambled egg" and forgotten that he was in Limbo. That could've made him age faster. By the time Cobb got to him, he seemed to be decades older, but Cobb wasn't, perhaps because he entered Limbo manually, or remembered that he wasn't dreaming.
Either way, we'll never really know what happened. Unless Nolan decides to tell everyone, but I doubt he'll do it. He left the movie, especially the ending, to everyone's interpretation.

revision.comment: Created page with "I was mistaken in an earlier comment. Fischer actually died before Saito, if we posit that Fischer dies when Mal shoots him. Saito does not die until sometime later. So Fischer s…"
revision.text: I was mistaken in an earlier comment. Fischer actually died before Saito, if we posit that Fischer dies when Mal shoots him. Saito does not die until sometime later. So Fischer should have been in Limbo longer than Saito (unless Fischer somehow lived after being shot by Mal and died after Saito).

revision.comment: Created page with "Either way, it was likely that Cobb took a long time to find Saito in Limbo, which is why he aged a lot."
revision.text: Either way, it was likely that Cobb took a long time to find Saito in Limbo, which is why he aged a lot.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-24.5.69.22-20110114034021]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-24.5.69.22-20110114034021]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsonius]]" t...
revision.text:
I'm just gonna clear this all up.
The ending is unknown and never will be known. It's called an ambiguous ending, meaning that the movie's director ended it here on purpose. The idea of making your viewers uncertain makes them enjoy the movie more/tell others to watch the movie. If it is a dream world, and Nolan wanted you to think of it that way, he would have filmed the top falling. That wasn't an ending left up in the air for people to discuss, what you saw was the ending. Nolan wanted you to leave never knowing, because the main character himself doesn't know. That's the entire point.

revision.comment: Created page with "Hi Wilis668, enjoyed reading your theory but it doesn't make sense to me for one simple reason. There's no suggested relationship between Ariadne and Saito throughout the film. …"
revision.text:
Hi Wilis668, enjoyed reading your theory but it doesn't make sense to me for one simple reason. There's no suggested relationship between Ariadne and Saito throughout the film.
Some other inconsistencies - It's not that Cobb does not look at his children's faces. He's not able to in dream space. They're always out of reach and never turn around in his dreams about them. The script suggests that he has the option to look in the final scene with Mal in limbo, but looks away, probably cause he doesn't want to see their faces in the limbo dream space for obvious reasons.
When you say 'there are no projections--only what you build' do you mean there are no subconscious projected people in limbo? How do you explain Saito guards when he's in limbo?
Agree with other posters that Saito is old because as you pointed out 'Limbo is unconstructed dream space. It's dangerous to go there because it's easy to forget that you're dreaming'. Regardless of how Cobb got into limbo, ie. manually by sleeping in level 3 or by dying (drowning) in level 1 - Saito has very little experience of dream space unlike Cobb who has decades worth. Cobb was aware that he was in limbo, Saito wasn't.

revision.comment: Created page with "We are told the story from Cobb's perspective, and he is an untrustworthy narrator. It is entirely possible that Ariadne and Saito were in on it. You are taking a too literal vi…"
revision.text:
We are told the story from Cobb's perspective, and he is an untrustworthy narrator. It is entirely possible that Ariadne and Saito were in on it.
You are taking a too literal view of the movie. But that is your choice.

revision.comment: Created page with "Maybe the inception wasn't just performed by Saito and Ariadne, but by everyone. Maybe even Fischer. Obviously this is isn't canon. It's not literal. It's just an interpretation …"
revision.text: Maybe the inception wasn't just performed by Saito and Ariadne, but by everyone. Maybe even Fischer. Obviously this is isn't canon. It's not literal. It's just an interpretation of the movie.

revision.comment: Created page with "You are right (imo) to a degree. Cobb Incepted himself. In the real world he was never going to get back to his kids. (either real -it was made to look as though he killed his wi…"
revision.text:
You are right (imo) to a degree. Cobb Incepted himself. In the real world he was never going to get back to his kids. (either real -it was made to look as though he killed his wife, or fake he is living with the regret of what he did to his wife)
The only way for him to be able to be with his kids was to Incept himself. The whole movie was based on Cobb getting to his kids. He did not care what it took..... he was going to get there.
While he could dream it he needed to go deep to make sure his subconscious would allow him to substitute it for the real world. In order to go deep he would need to dream at different levels getting deeper so his subconscious would deteriorate to a point he could sub dream for RL.
In order to do that HE planted in his own mind this elaborate scheme to get himself back to his kids......
Remember he was supposedly the best Architect. So no one else could build what he could build as well as he could. So he had to (in his dream) find someone just as good if not better. The only place to get that person would be from the same person that introduced him to the dream state.
He made this whole thing up just so (in his mind) he could be happy with his kids.
IMO.

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-75.27.114.7-20110121182025]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-75.27.114.7-20110121182025]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsonius]]"...
revision.text: The purpose of this ending was to show how Inception can work. By showing the small uncertainty that Dom created in Limbo to escape with Mal, Nolan is injecting the same kind of feeling into us, the viewers. We never see the top fall, which leads us to questioning the reality Dom is in. It's that easy to give us the idea.

revision.text:
I have no idea for the first question , but I may be able to help for the second question .
For the second question , everybody who's subconscious is trained to defend itself , have different ways of doing it . And anyway , the army only formed when Fischer's subconscious was being tampered with . So I assume that the trained subconscious only takes action when a subconscious is being extracted , incepted , and etc ...
Just a thought . :)

revision.text: I think the reason that Cobb spins the top and walks off without looking for the outcome, was that Cobb decided that even if he is in Limbo ( and IMO , I don ' t think he is ) , he doesn't really care because he saw his children's faces . :)

revision.comment: Created page with "Arthur: So, once we've made the plant, how do we go out? Hope you have something more elegant in mind than shooting me in the head? Cobb: A kick. Ariadne: What's a kick? Eames: T..."
revision.text: Arthur: So, once we've made the plant, how do we go out? Hope you have something more elegant in mind than shooting me in the head? Cobb: A kick. Ariadne: What's a kick? Eames: This, Ariadne, would be a kick [kicks the leg of the chair Arthur's swinging at] ------------- Arthur: You couldn't have peed before you went under? ------------- Ariadne: You mind telling your subconscious to take it easy?

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-67.49.177.141-20110306094040]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-67.49.177.141-20110306094040]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsoniu...
revision.text: I believe that their is the possibility that Cobb got lost in Limbo and now thinks Limbo is reality and that reality is now the dream state/Limbo. The reason I think this is because on the page for the totem information on this website it says that"A Totem is an object that is used to test if oneself is in one's own reality (dream or non-dream) and not in another person's dream."If this is true then if in the end the top does fall over it proves that Cobb can be in one of two places. 1. His own dream state 2. Reality It could also be that Cobb does not realise that he is in his own dream state and all the people could be projections. The other theorie that Cobb was in a dream the whole movie is relevent because when Cobb was in Limbo the first time he may have also gotten lost in Limbo along with Mal. Also I believe that maybe dreams are realities in their own right and their is no true reality.

During a Rome press conference for ''[[Inception (2010 film)|Inception]]'', [[Christopher Nolan]] expressed the idea of creating a video game spinoff. "One thing we are looking at doing is developing a videogame based on the world of the film, which has all kinds of ideas that you can't fit into a feature film," he said. "That's something we've been talking about and are looking at doing long term, in a couple of years."<ref>[http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118024429.html?categoryid=19&cs=1]</ref>
Lack of development since Nolan's statements have suggested that the project is unlikely.

revision.comment: Created page with "In response to this comment by Willis668 it could have been that because Dom told Fischer that he would go into Limbo if he died back in level 2 (Dom acting as Mr.Charles) so wit..."
revision.text: In response to this comment by Willis668 it could have been that because Dom told Fischer that he would go into Limbo if he died back in level 2 (Dom acting as Mr.Charles) so with Fischer remembering that, he might have not gotten lost in Limbo.

revision.comment: Created page with "One of the problems with this theory and any theory including Saito's death is that we do not know exactly when Saito died. If Saito died when Yusuf parked the van on the bridge..."
revision.text: One of the problems with this theory and any theory including Saito's death is that we do not know exactly when Saito died. If Saito died when Yusuf parked the van on the bridge then that would mean that Saito would be in Limbo a much longer time than Fischer because Fischer was shown to have died when the van was falling to the water. I didn;t do any of the time dialation math but if Saito died even seconds before Fischer died in level 3 then that could mean years for Saito. Also if we include that Cobb had to look for Saito in Limbo then it could have taken years for Cobb to find Saito adding to Saito's age.

revision.comment: Created page with "I think that the whole thing was real, I mean, look at the facts. HE implants Inception on Mal. HE tells her that their reality in Limbo isn't real. HE tries to convince her that..."
revision.text: I think that the whole thing was real, I mean, look at the facts. HE implants Inception on Mal. HE tells her that their reality in Limbo isn't real. HE tries to convince her that the reality they are from is reality, when she is thinking it is not. Could someone really go that deep? And for him being disoriented in Saito's Limbo and not Fisher's, Ariadne, a real person, was with him. When he went to Saito's no one was with him, and he had just let go of Mal, which had made him easy to confuse in the first place. With Ariadne he had the sense of reality, something he could hold onto. He was alone in Saito's. As for how did he get to Saito's limbo, would he have to kill himself a second time to go a level lower into Limbo? Saito died first, if I'm not mistaken. It only makes sense that his Limbo would be lower than Fisher's, OR they are both in the same Limbo, which makes a bit more sense but may not be true. They could go into Fisher's because they did not kill themselves, they just used the dream machine thing. Although, wouldn't they go just a level deeper? It's all very confusing but I think that reality was reality. How could his totem have fallen if it weren't? I mean I guess it could be like Mal's when she believed Limbo was real, but I still believe he was in reality. How could he just make up all of that stuff?

revision.comment: moved [[User blog comment:Samsonius/End Theories/@comment-Threeche-20110407211718]] to [[User blog comment:Azaelius/End Theories/@comment-Threeche-20110407211718]]: Automatically moved page while renaming the user "[[User:Samsonius|Samsonius]]" to "[...
revision.text:
This is a subtle thing I noticed but Mal is French and her name translates to "bad". I was looking at the Hans Zimmer's score and the title theme is a modification of a French song from 1960 by the name of "Non, je ne regrette rien" which roughly translates to "I will live with no regret". I went and looked into the lyrics/meaning of the song and was surprised to find an apt metaphor for the movie. It is a song about moving on from a lost love. It also directly addresses "mal", through the singer's perception of good and bad as only relative. The bulk of the song is about ridding oneself of the haunting memories of that lost love. I think Hans Zimmer deliberately chose this song not only for its tune, but for its metaphorical content. The track is played unchanged in reality scenes and slowed down in dream scenes, thus representing the (seemingly) dualistic nature of his relationship with Mal. In the end, I believe he finally achieves self-Inception, such that he is able to successfully psychologically integrate both the "good" and "evil" aspects of Mal and his relationship with her, relieving him of his guilt. The process required he remain in the dream world, but the point of cut-away from the wobbling top is that the nature of being is subjective, and ultimately that it did not matter whether the top fell or not, but that he overcomes the angst resulting from his existential attachment to Mal. Here are the lyrics to "Non, je ne regrette rien"
No, nothing at all, I regret nothing at all Not the good, nor the bad. It is all the same. No, nothing at all, I have no regrets about anything. It is paid, wiped away, forgotten. I am not concerned with the past, with my memories. I set fire to my pains and pleasures, I don't need them anymore. I have wiped away my loves, and my troubles. Swept them all away. I am starting again from zero.
No, nothing at all, I have no regrets Because from today, my life, my happiness, everything, Starts with you!
I have many more pages of essay and analysis of the movie from various philosophical and psychological approaches if anyone is interested in more rigorous discussion of these aspects of the film, I would be interested in starting up dialogue. You can reach me at daveballon@gmail.com
