“The wisteria meaning deals with: Honor, Memory, Patience, Endurance, Longevity, Exploration, Creative expansion, Releasing burdens, The duality of love, Victory over hardship.

As [http://www.whats-your-sign.com/love-symbols.html symbols of love] we see the wisteria in the 1820s Japanese kabuki drama ''Fuji Musume'' (Wisteria Maiden). The Wisteria Maiden is depicted in a painting holding a wisteria branch, until one day she becomes smitten with a young man and '''steps out''' of the painting in an effort to capture his attention. Unfortunately, her attempts are futile. Her loves goes unrequited, and she sorrowfully steps back into the two-dimensional world of her lonely painting still holding her weeping wisteria.

Here the wisteria meaning and symbolism speaks of love lost, but also of the ability for the '''heart to endure''' in spite of rejection. In other words, here the weeping wisteria expresses sorrow, but it is also an ''incredibly durable'' vine, able to live (even flourish) through mistreatment and harsh conditions.”

To me, Saito represents for Cobb the ability to “correct” or “purify” himself of the torment of regret though the ability of his heart to endure in spite of rejection, unrequited love, or love lost. How or why does that work? There’s no rational reason to think it will. That’s why Arthur instructs Cobb to walk away. But Cobb takes the leap of faith, and it does work. Indeed, once Cobb accepts (or steals) that idea from Saito, or, through inception, the idea is successfully implanted in Cobb’s mind – the idea that through Saito he can avoid becoming an old man, filled with regret, waiting to die alone – Cobb appears to dream up how it will work.

One of my favorite, though very subtle, moments in ''Inception'' is when Ariadne walks out on Cobb and the whole Fischer enterprise. (BTW, in ancient Greek mythology, Ariadne is the woman who helps guide Theseus through the Minotaur’s labyrinth.) Cobb says she will be back and you can almost see him dreaming up the reason why she will return as he says it. All of the main characters are under Cobb’s direction after he accepts Saito’s idea, including Fischer; everyone except Mal. Mal is quite explicitly the personification of his regret, the thing he must overcome and release to change the quality of his life.

Perhaps ironically, Mal is the only character in ''Inception ''who is unambiguously not real and yet keeps Cobb grounded in the one unambiguous truth of the movie – that Cobb feels regret ''and guilt''. It doesn’t matter if Cobb’s feeling of guilt is rational or deserved or imagined. It doesn’t even matter if they’re ever was a woman named Mal “in the real world” or if Cobb is still young and looks like Leonardo DiCaprio. The guilt Mal represents is real to Cobb.

And Cobb’s struggle to confront that guilt is what makes ''Inception ''ring true to me. Cobb scrappily, imaginatively, and courageously finds a way to confront guilt so powerful it won’t even allow him to imagine the faces of his own children. When he faces Mal, his guilt, it confronts him with great irrational intensity: “You killed me.” “You infected my mind.” “You betrayed me.” '''''But you can make amends by living with your guilt – by living in the world you built together with your guilt! ''' ''

Once Cobb confronts this terrible assault of guilt, Saito dies, which signifies to me that the need for Cobb to purify his guilt through enduring the pain of love lost is over. Saito is dead and Cobb knows it. Now that Cobb has confronted Mal, Mal’s ability to control Cobb is over. Mal is infuriated by this and stabs at Cobb. Ariadne is ready to kill Mal but Cobb orders Ariadne to stop. Cobb is in complete control of events now and he wants to say goodbye to Mal. Cobb can now see the way out of Cobb’s – Mal’s – guilt’s labyrinth without Ariadne.

Cobb tells Mal that “we had our time together and now I have to let go.” I believe, on some level, Cobb may mean by this that: ''I’ve lived with my guilt long enough. It’s time to let it go.''

Then Cobb dies. He drowns in the van driven by Yusuf. At this point, both Cobb and Saito have died and are in limbo. Limbo: “The abode of unbaptized but innocent or righteous souls, as those of infants or virtuous individuals who lived before the coming of Christ (salvation); an intermediate state (of being)” (@http://www.thefreedictionary.com/limbo).

Cobb is ready to be reborn into another state of being, a state of being without Mal, without guilt.

In limbo, Cobb is bearded, disheveled and appears world-weary. He hunches over his food and holds his spoon like an old man, or a baby – slopping up the kind of soft food you serve very old people or babies without teeth.

Now, shockingly and inexplicably to me, Saito is an old man, alone, filled with regret, waiting to die alone. Why would Saito’s limbo life be the destiny that was awaiting Cobb if he did not change the quality of his being and release guilt? Saito had a wife and a mistress. Why didn’t they join him, or rather, why didn’t Saito imagine them with him in limbo?

I believe it’s because Saito was nothing more than the personification of Cobb’s ability to endure lost love and overcome regret and guilt. Once untethered from that task, Saito had no immediate usefulness for Cobb. Cobb had to decide to return, to be reborn, with Saito. It did not necessarily follow that Cobb would be willing to endure the heartache associated with love after overcoming his regret and guilt. On the contrary, many people whom overcome great feelings of loss and pain associated with lost love decide never to love again.

Cobb does not choose that path. Cobb chooses to be reborn with his ability to love, and the possibility of having to endure love lost, in tact. This time, Cobb has to tell Saito to take a leap of faith – to tell that part of himself capable of love to risk love again, however unreasonable a risk that may seem to be given what Cobb just had to overcome.

Really? I must be kidding myself. Cobb has to get Saito so Saito can honor their arrangement and Cobb can see his children again. That’s it, plain and simple, correct? This “purification wisteria” Saito as ability to love personified is a figment of my imagination – my own projection onto the movie, right?

Perhaps. Yet when Cobb finds Saito he goes beyond telling Saito it is a dream. When Saito remembers it’s a dream and asks Cobb if he came so that Saito will honor their arrangement, Cobb answers yes '''''and to take a leap of faith. ''''' Earlier in their conversation, Saito recalls that he and Cobb were young men together. At best, that seems to mischaracterize and exaggerate the brief interaction Saito and Cobb have had to date. But, strangely, it seems to be exactly the right characterization of their relationship to Cobb. Cobb tells Saito: “Come back and we'll be young men together again.”

'''''Come back and we’ll be young men together again? '''''Absolutely nothing in ''Inception ''suggests that Saito and Cobb will return to a world where they will be young men together again. It makes sense though if Saito is the personification of Cobb’s ability to love and endure love’s pains and losses. At least, that’s the way I see it. ''' '''

Irrespective of who or what Saito is, Cobb is in fact reborn without guilt and with his ability to love and endure its pains in tact. To me, this is confirmed by Saito’s awakening on the plane and Cobb’s ability to “return home” and look into the faces of his children – in his mind’s eye or otherwise. This rather happy ending in my opinion does not depend on Cobb’s literal return home, or his ability to look into the “real world” faces of his children.

Cobb’s change, his transformation, his rebirth, into a man without guilt who can love again is a more important reality, a more inspiring and emotionally satisfying ending, than his ability to skirt the law and hug his children again (assuming Cobb really even has any children) in my view. I’d '''''rather''''' imagine Cobb waking up from ''the dream'' of looking into his children’s faces again – waking up without guilt and with the ability to love again.

Listening to myself, it’s hard to believe I really believe what I just said. Doesn’t it make more sense to believe that returning to my own children would be more important to me than my feelings or state of being with respect to guilt and the ability to love? This doesn’t sound like me.

What would I need to think, believe, and feel – to deal with fictional matters and real matters with equal appreciation and respect for their importance to me? To, in a sense, not care if the top falls or endlessly spins. I don’t know, but I think I may find out. And I blame Dom Cobb.

By the way, “Dom” is a Roman Catholic Church title used before the names of Benedictine monks. One of the major vows these monks take is the ''conversatio moru, ''which is idiomatic Latin that has been translated to mean "conversion of life." “Cobb” is a variation of Jacob, which is a name that has been interpreted to mean “he who supplants” – that is, “someone who usurps the place of, especially through intrigue or underhanded tactics,” or “someone who displaces or substitutes for (another)” (@http://www.thefreedictionary.com/supplants).

Call me paranoid, but I suspect Christopher Nolan sent Cobb to perform inception on '''''me!''''' Cobb was sent to supplant some idea I had with another. I can’t trace the idea planted yet but I am already seeing evidence that it has taken root – not the least of which is my weird willingness to spend my valuable time trying to analyze ''Inception. ''

revision.comment: Created page with "I wasn't sure about where to post this, so I'll just leave it as a comment here. I have a few ideas about the movie as a whole. 1. The whole job could have been a way for Cobb t..."
revision.text:
I wasn't sure about where to post this, so I'll just leave it as a comment here. I have a few ideas about the movie as a whole. 1. The whole job could have been a way for Cobb to learn to come to terms with Mal's death. This could have been made by Arthur. Therefore Ariadne could have been recruited by Arthur or a projection of Cobb's mind.
Ariadne the Projection:
1.Eames could have used her to plant an idea in Cobb the same way Browning was used.
2.Cobb's subconscious used Ariadne to give him a way of explaining himself.
I'm thinking number Projection idea number 1 is more possible, because Cobb's subconscious seemed to prefer him being in the dream. ( Proof: With all of Mal's pleading to get him to stay and believe in the dream whenever he is under.)
With idea number 1 , Arthur most likely wanted to save Cobb, or the team eventually all did, and they were all in Cobb's mind the whole time, convincing him that he wasn't at fault for Mal's death. In the scenario, they left Cobb in the dream, believing he was proved innocent and able to see his kids. ( A problem comes in with Saito though, since he wouldn't have a motive for wanting this, unless it was just to prevent Cobb or his team from ever entering his mind or being used against him again { which would be extremely presumptuous on my part and would make Saito an extremely paranoid character})
In the End , this is what I've come up with, and your free to go Yea or Neigh on this long explanation :
1. Cobb never left the dream. 2.Arthur, Ariadne, Eames, (and the rest?) left him there because it was a nicer 'reality' to Cobb .
A kind of mix of the Happy Ending and the Sad Ending , right?

revision.comment: Created page with "In response to "The Top Falls; Evidence Refuting," we actually see the top fall TWICE in the movie: We see the top fall in the beginning shortly after the failed attempt to extr..."
revision.text:
In response to "The Top Falls; Evidence Refuting," we actually see the top fall TWICE in the movie:
We see the top fall in the beginning shortly after the failed attempt to extract information from Saito, when Cobb holds his pistol as he watches the top spin and places it back down once he sees the top fall.
We see the top fall once more directly after Cobb and Ariadne's run-in with Cobb's projection of Mal when Ariadne is in "training" with Cobb. After Ariadne is stabbed by Mal in her and Cobb's shared dream, Cobb runs to the back while mentioning that Ariadne requires a totem. While in the back of the workshop, Cobb spins the top and we see it fall once again.

revision.text: The song isn't slowed down in the dream scenes because of a metaphor. Time is slower in dreams. Since the song is not just background music but being played through headphones in the level above, it would be perceived slower in the dreams.

revision.comment: Created page with "Okay so here my take. If you consider it to be a typical Hollywood film, the scale at which Nolan wanted the film to be, Cobb is out the dream implying he is back to reality. Ho..."
revision.text:
Okay so here my take. If you consider it to be a typical Hollywood film, the scale at which Nolan wanted the film to be, Cobb is out the dream implying he is back to reality.
However this film is 10 years of research and effort, Nolan wanted to wait to reach this scale of working, implying this is a very personal script, which means story is what drives the film implying Cobb is in limbo.

== Dominic Cobb ==
Why did you change the spelling of Cobb's first name back to "Dominic?" His official name, as seen on his airline ticket, is Dominick with a "k." Watch the DVD or Blu-ray and pause it when Cobb looks at this airline ticket in his penthouse kitchen. This is the only place where we see the spelling of Cobb's full first name. [[Special:Contributions/24.6.246.132|24.6.246.132]] 04:19, October 10, 2011 (UTC)

revision.comment: Created page with "The top is actually inconsequential to him being in reality or not as it is only a test to see if he is in someone else's dream. He knows exactly what it is supposed to do so if ..."
revision.text: The top is actually inconsequential to him being in reality or not as it is only a test to see if he is in someone else's dream. He knows exactly what it is supposed to do so if he believes he is in reality, it will fall and if he doesn't, it wont. Let's also not forget the fact that it wasn't his totem to begin with but Mal's. So for all intents and purposes, even he doesn't know what it's supposed to do.

Please leave a message on [[User talk:Ozzyjalo94|my talk page]] if I can help with anything! -- [[User:Ozzyjalo94|Ozzyjalo94]] ([[User_talk:Ozzyjalo94|Talk]]) 23:02, November 4, 2011

revision.comment: Created page with "I like your ideas here but I would also like to add that Cobb isn't exactly the picture perfect example of mental health and stability. If the entire movie is not in reality (all..."
revision.text: I like your ideas here but I would also like to add that Cobb isn't exactly the picture perfect example of mental health and stability. If the entire movie is not in reality (all dream), my idea here would be that all of his team are his own projections and he could have a form of multiple personality disorder with each of them being a fully developed "person" within him, all helping him to cope with the loss of his wife who either committed suicide or woke up.

revision.comment: Created page with "Theryanhollis: The train is from Cobb and Mal's time in limbo. It was the way they killed themselves to wake up. It is the same train. Even Ariadne says she didn't put a train cr..."
revision.text: Theryanhollis: The train is from Cobb and Mal's time in limbo. It was the way they killed themselves to wake up. It is the same train. Even Ariadne says she didn't put a train crossing in the middle of down town. Fisher's militarized subconscious are the people shooting at the team and has nothing to do with the train.

revision.comment: Created page with "Saying "it was just a movie" requires no thought on anyone's part. I'm sure we all know that it was a movie as we paid for the movie ticket to see it, bought the DVD, waited for ..."
revision.text: Saying "it was just a movie" requires no thought on anyone's part. I'm sure we all know that it was a movie as we paid for the movie ticket to see it, bought the DVD, waited for it to show on cable or illegally downloaded it. Yes, it's open ended to get pages just like this one to spring up and keep the momentum alive and push sales. But I believe Nolan is far too detailed to leave this "master piece" of his to chance. He didn't even have a second director. He shot every scene himself. I wouldn't be surprised if he supervised the editor every chance he could. But as you said, it's open ended but not for the story but for the fans. If he wanted us to have an answer, he'd give us one.

revision.comment: Created page with "Rotating hallway fight were awesome. In fact, entire Hotel dream was."
revision.text: Rotating hallway fight were awesome. In fact, entire Hotel dream was.

revision.comment: Created page with "Arthur: It would have to be a 747. Cobb: Why is that? Arthur: Because in a 747, the pilot's up top, and the first class cabin's in the nose, so no one would walk through. But y..."
revision.text: Arthur: It would have to be a 747. Cobb: Why is that? Arthur: Because in a 747, the pilot's up top, and the first class cabin's in the nose, so no one would walk through. But you'd have to buy out the entire cabin. And the first class flight attendant... Saito: I bought the airline. [Everybody turns and stares at him. Saito just shrugs] Saito: It seemed neater.

revision.comment: Created page with "[repeated line] Arthur: Paradox. "
revision.text: [repeated line] Arthur: Paradox.

revision.comment: Created page with "Saito: Don't you want to take a leap of faith? Or become an old man, filled with regret, waiting to die alone!"
revision.text: Saito: Don't you want to take a leap of faith? Or become an old man, filled with regret, waiting to die alone!

revision.comment: Created page with "Cobb: They say we only use a fraction of our brain's true potential. Now that's when we're awake. When we're asleep, we can do almost anything. "
revision.text: Cobb: They say we only use a fraction of our brain's true potential. Now that's when we're awake. When we're asleep, we can do almost anything.

revision.comment: Created page with "Maurice Fischer: [Robert opens the vault to see Maurice on his death bed struggling to say something] Disa... disap... disappointed Fischer: I know, Dad. I know you were disappo..."
revision.text: Maurice Fischer: [Robert opens the vault to see Maurice on his death bed struggling to say something] Disa... disap... disappointed Fischer: I know, Dad. I know you were disappointed I couldn't be you. Maurice Fischer: No. No, no. I was disappointed... that you tried. [Robert opens the safe to find the new Last Will and Testament along with the pinwheel from when he was a kid. The inception has worked]

revision.comment: Created page with "Arthur: Eames, I am impressed. Eames: Your condescension, as always, is much appreciated, Arthur. Thank you. "
revision.text: Arthur: Eames, I am impressed. Eames: Your condescension, as always, is much appreciated, Arthur. Thank you.

revision.comment: moved [[Talk:Dominic Cobb]] to [[Talk:Dominick Cobb]] over redirect
revision.text: #REDIRECT [[Talk:Dominick Cobb]]

{{quote|An idea can transform the world and rewrite all the rules.}}
{{Infobox character |image=Dom_Cobb_Infobox.png |imagesize=250px |name=Dominick Cobb |born= |died= |lives=United States of America |gender=Male |status=Alive |eye=Blue |family=*[[Mallorie Cobb]] (wife) *[[Stephen Miles]] (father-in-law) *[[Marie]] (mother-in-law) *[[Phillipa Cobb]] (daughter) *[[James Cobb]] (son) |occupation=Extractor |loyalties= |portrayed=*Leonardo DiCaprio (Young Dom) *Jack Gilroy (Old Dom) |first=''[[Inception: The Cobol Job]]'' |last=}} '''Dominick Cobb'''The airline ticket given to Dom when he is escaping America displays his full name, spelling it with an additional 'k'., also known as '''Dom''', is the main protagonist of the film, [[Inception_(2010_film)|Inception]]. Cobb is well known in the black market because of his level of expertise in the field of [[extraction]], which consists of stealing his mark's ideas by infiltrating their [[dreams]] and stealing valuable information from them. Cobb was implicated by his wife [[Mal]] in her death in a letter she filed with their attorney; as a consequence he's a wanted fugitive who can never return to his home. He is portrayed by [[Leonardo DiCaprio]]. His [[Totem]] is his wedding ring. He uses a Beretta Px4 Storm consistently throughout the film, also using a suppressed Blaser R93 LRS2 sniper rifle during the [[Snow-Covered Mountains (dream)|third level]] of [[The Fischer Inception Job]]. ==Background== Dominick Cobb was once a gifted [[Architect]] under the mentorship of Miles. The two were close friends and Miles did not object when Dom became involved with his daughter, Mal. Mal and Dom loved each other dearly and, after having a dream of the couple growing old together, Dom asked her to marry him. The two had two children. Mal was also fascinated by Dream-Sharing and the power of the subconscious, but it appears she also was among the first to realize the inherent danger of it. It was for this reason she invented the use of totems to determine dreams and reality, using a metal spinning top. During an experiment in Dream-Sharing, Dom insisted on going deeper into the different layers of dreams. This resulted in the two becoming trapped in Limbo, unconstructed dream space. The two spent around fifty years building a city around them, with many buildings created from memories of their past. At first complacent with their position as gods, Dom’s patience with Limbo waned over the decades and he soon sought a way to escape. Mal, however, found the only way she could stand Limbo was to forget about reality. She placed her totem in a hidden safe, symbolizing her locking away the memory that Limbo was not real. In desperation, Dom broke into her hidden safe and performed inception, the artificial implantation of an idea into another’s subconscious. He spun the spinning top, knowing that in the dream world it would not topple. This became a subconscious reminder to Mal of the truth: Limbo was not real and death was the only escape. Together, Dom led Mal to a set of train tracks and waited, with their heads on the tracks, till a train came and killed them. The two woke up, having spent only a short amount of time asleep. But the damage of Dom’s actions eventually caught up with him. Even in the real world, Mal continued to believe she was sleeping. She saw her children as projections and rejected Dom’s reasoning. She began harboring suicidal thoughts as she sought to free herself from her dream, but was unable to do it alone. In her mind she felt it would be cowardly to leave Dom behind in the dream world and loved him too dearly to move on without him. Despite her beliefs, three separate psychiatrists declared her sane. On the anniversary of their wedding, Dom came to their traditional hotel room to find it in a disheveled state. Noticing an open window, Dom looked outside to see Mal ready to jump off the opposite ledge. Dom attempts to calm Mal and convince her to come inside, but Mal replies that Dom has to jump or will be arrested for her murder because Mal had left evidence falsely accusing Dom of being abusive and making death threats against her. She admitted her actions were made so that he would be more willing to jump with her and less guilty for leaving behind their children, as they would be taken into foster care if he lived anyway. Growing increasingly desperate, Dom begged Mal to accept her reality, but was unable to convince her. She dropped peacefully from the roof and her evidence made Dom the prime suspect in her apparent murder. On the advice of his lawyer, Dom fled the United States, regretfully leaving behind his children who taken in by their grandparents. He would be haunted by the memory of that day from then on, regretting that he did not say goodbye or even see their faces before leaving. In exile, Dom found the only available work for someone of his skills was illegal. He became a professional extractor, partnering extensively with point man Arthur and forging a competent reputation and large network of allies in the criminal world. His work became hindered, however, as Dom's projection of Mal began acting in increasingly unpredictable ways. This projection was a manifestation of Dom's perception of Mal in her final years: vengeful, violent yet loving, that was empowered by his intense feelings of guilt and self-hatred: his own subconscious wish to be punished. She became Dom’s tormentor, reminding him of his lost wife, dearly missed children, playing on his growing doubts about reality and foiling his extractions. As Mal grew more powerful, her actions grew more bold and violent, forcing herself into Dom’s plans and becoming impossible for him to ignore or control. As Mal’s power grew, Dom began feeling it was too dangerous for him to design dreams anymore, as Mal would undoubtedly know the dream as well, making it easier for her to find them and foil the plan. This required him to rely on other Architects, severely limiting his flexibility. ==Personality== ﻿Cobb is a disturbed man, shaken by the death of his wife and the events that led him to leave his children. Cobb struggles to leave his dark and tortured past behind him, which is why he accepts Saito's offer. As the movie progresses, Cobb is forced to deal with Mal's projection until he is able to fully overcome her death. ==Abilities== Cobb excels at his job for many reasons, the greatest of which is the ease in which he reads people, most notably his marks. He is a skilled extractor. He is also quite a conversationalist, and laces his speech and actions with deceptive gambits. An example of this is when he twists the truth of the team's reason for drawing Fischer deeper into the dream levels, and again when he draws Ariadne into the world of shared dreaming without her knowledge. Like Eames and Arthur, Cobb also can be seen to be highly proficient in hand-to-hand combat, evasive tactics, and sharpshooting. He managed to disable multiple projections in the Hotel bathroom and in the mountains. He also seems to have advanced intrusion and stealth training, as evidenced by his expert navigation of Saito's complex in the beginning of the film, as well as the silent neutralization of the projections in that complex. ==Development and Summary of Profession== “At the beginning of the film,” [[Christopher Nolan]] says, “we learn that Cobb is the best extractor in the game. He is hired by corporations to steal secrets they would otherwise never have access to. It’s all based on the persistence of an idea, the notion that any concept will stay fixed in the subconscious. It’s impossible to unlearn something, and that forms the basis for what an extractor is able to do in terms of retrieving information.” ==Reception== The performance of DiCaprio has been widely acclaimed, but was not nominated for the Oscar for Best Actor, though heavily considered by many critics who have reviewed the film. ==Quotes== *"''Those kids, your grandchildren, they're waiting for their father to come back home - that's their reality. This job, this last job, that's how I get there."'' *"''You create the world of the dream. You bring the subject into the dream and they fill it with their sub-conscious."'' *"''Well, dreams, they feel real while we're in them, right? It's only when we wake up that we realize that something was actually strange."'' *"''Building a dream from memory is the easiest way to lose your grasp on what's real and what is a dream."'' *Cobb: ''"They think I killed her."''
Ariadne: ''[silence]''
Cobb: ''"Thank you."''
Ariadne: ''"For what?"''
Cobb: ''"For not asking whether or not I did."'' ==Trivia== *He was known as The Extractor in some promotional material. ==Read more== *[[Eames]] *[[Ariadne]] *[[Arthur]] ==References== {{DEFAULTSORT:Cobb}} [[Category:Characters]] [[Category:Citations needed]] [[Category:The Team]] [[Category:Stub]]

revision.comment: Created page with "Arthur rigged the spinning top to make Cobb think he was in the real world, but this only works in 1 dreamspace, this dreamspace is what we see as 'real'."
revision.text: Arthur rigged the spinning top to make Cobb think he was in the real world, but this only works in 1 dreamspace, this dreamspace is what we see as 'real'.

revision.comment: Created page with "Arthur: What about his security? It's gonna get worse as we go deeper. Cobb: I think we run with Mr. Charles. Arthur: No. Eames: Who's Mr. Charles? Arthur: Bad idea. Cobb: T..."
revision.text: Arthur: What about his security? It's gonna get worse as we go deeper. Cobb: I think we run with Mr. Charles. Arthur: No. Eames: Who's Mr. Charles? Arthur: Bad idea. Cobb: The second we get in that hotel with Fischer, his security is gonna be all over us. We run with Mr. Charles like we did on the Stein job. Eames: So you've done it before? Arthur: Yeah, and it didn't work. The subject realized he was dreaming and his subconscious tore us to pieces. Eames: Excellent. But you learned a lot, right?

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contributions/190.60.209.12|190.60.209.12]] ([[User talk:190.60.209.12|talk]] | [[Special:Block/190.60.209.12|block]]) to last version by [[User:Bastian964|Bastian964]]
revision.text: ==Drug Injection Information== http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drug_injection http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intravenous_therapy#Risks_of_intravenous_therapy So far overdose are prevented with the machine. However how did they prevent collapsing veins and/or atery damage? and also do they change the needles? The place that Yusuf runs might be" '''Increased chance of addiction''' — The heightened effect of administering drugs intravenously can make the chances of addiction more likely" [[User:Blix1ms0ns|Blix1ms0ns]] 03:16, February 28, 2012 (UTC) It would be speculating to say that any of that applies to the PASIV device and/or Somnacin. Please do not add this to the article. [[User:Bastian964|Bastian]][[User_talk:Bastian964|9]][[Special:Contributions/Bastian964|6]][[Special:Editcount/Bastian964|4]] 21:45, March 1, 2012 (UTC)

==Name Question== Is there any expanded universe material to cite to that lists this as the "New York Dream"? Because the city in the dream, while of course including imaginary elements put in by Ariadne and Yusuf, bears absolutely no resemblance to New York (where I've lived and which does not have any drawbridges). The city DOES look a lot like Los Angeles, where they filmed it, including the bridge-falling sequence, which took place in the Port of Los Angeles according to the shooting locations lists that I've found. Also, my roommate who lives in LA states that it does indeed rain in L.A. from time to time. Los Angeles would also be the more appropriate guess in-story, because when Robert wakes up, he expects to be arriving in Los Angeles.
[[Special:Contributions/99.73.225.187|99.73.225.187]] 23:25, February 29, 2012 (UTC)Morag
It is stated in the script. [[User:Bastian964|Bastian]][[User_talk:Bastian964|9]][[Special:Contributions/Bastian964|6]][[Special:Editcount/Bastian964|4]] 21:41, March 1, 2012 (UTC)

revision.comment: Created page with "He is back in reality in the end. The wedding ring proves it. The argument that maybe, "he's come to terms with his dead wife, that's why the ring isn't there," is false, becau..."
revision.text: He is back in reality in the end. The wedding ring proves it. The argument that maybe, "he's come to terms with his dead wife, that's why the ring isn't there," is false, because at the end of the film when he gets saito back, he is STILL wearing the ring. This is after the fact he came to terms with his dead wife. If it were true, we wouldn't see the ringing the end scene with old man saito. Done.

revision.comment: Created page with "There is this part where Mal says that Cobb maybe dreaming as he is followed by police and many other people, like projections do when a dreamer affects the subjects dream. There..."
revision.text: There is this part where Mal says that Cobb maybe dreaming as he is followed by police and many other people, like projections do when a dreamer affects the subjects dream. There could be a chance that the whole movie had taken place in a dream because if we go back to Cobb and Mal's story, they were living in limbo (dream within a dream). So when they woke up from limbo, they still weren't in reality but in a dream. And the children not aging maybe the decisive point, added to the fact that the totem keeps spinning. This would mean that Mal is in reality and Cobb is still in one of the dreams they once got into with Mal, before going into limbo.

revision.text:
For it to be possible to create there own worlds, you need to be in a dream within a dream.
Dom and Mal were in their own dream world for 50 years until they decided that is was enough. they lied on the train tracks and got hit by the train. Then... they were in reality. But, it could only mean that they were in the 1st dream layer when they woke up from the 2nd layer, Mal was right?

'''Great responses by everyone and hopefully I can add to it.''' I think Cobb entered Limbo with Mal, but never returned with the team. It was too dangerous for them to enter or rescue someone from. That kinda goes against what was seen in the movie but let's follow what lead up to the ending. In the beginning, Cobb’s team was being tested by Saito to extract information from his mind for a future mission. This was Saito dream designed by the first architect. Before Cobb used Mal's chair to scale down, he looked out the window and saw military personnel outside standing by the beach shore. Saito's subconscious was militarized to protect his thoughts. Now here is where things get sticky. Remember when Cobb was cracking the safe and Saito, Mal and Arthur enter the room? That means Saito knows who Mal was and probably asked Arthur who she was. This leads to the theory that not only Saito wanted to use Inception on Fischer, but also on Cobb. Saito in my opinion used dual Inception. Saito somehow made it possible for everything to go as planned, from buying the airline to guaranteeing that Cobb will be able to return home. Arthur was kicked/awakened with a gunshot to the head and Cobb was kicked with water. Saito and Cobb exists the second dream level and returns to the first level. In the next scene on the first level, the dream of the architect, when they look outside this time, there's a mob. Now in the real world, the architect supposedly tells the location of Cobb and Arthur to Saito, and then Saito gives Cobb the option to kill him, but he doesn't. The architect is taken away by Saito guards but never know what happened to him. Why would Saito turn over a person with the talent to construct dreams over to Cobalt Engineering? Remember, he wanted Inception and will do anything for it. In the helicopter scene where Arthur and Cobb are exiting, Saito plants the idea of going home in exchange for planting Inception in Fischer. Interesting, because in the first scene, only Cobb, Saito and Arthur knew of Mal. When Arthur said they should walk away from the job, and Cobb continues on and accepts the job, Saito and Arthur knew the idea was planted in Cobb. Success. Ariadne, the second architect, was the third person to see Mal in Cobbs dream. She also saw the inside Cobbs home when she infiltrated his dream. She knew Mal was a problem and wanted to solve the issue. She told Cobb that he need to inform the others, but I think she went behind his back to do so. When they were testing the kicks before boarding the plane, Arthur and Ariadne shared dreams. Which tells me when they devised and constructed the plan for Cobb to let go of Mal. Mal was indeed dead, as Authur also confirmed to Ariadne. Some may think when he visited Yusuf, he never awoke from the dream. He did. How? If you look closely, the dreams/memories Cobbs saw were his own, not of a architect which wasn't present. These were the same dreams/memories of Ariadne saw "after" this scene. It was kind of weird when I saw Saito show up in South Africa, I was sure he didn't wake up, until I remember Arthur knew Cobb could be killed/captured there. I think Arthur informed Saito of this and he flew there to "protect his investment." When Cobb realized the Fischer subconscious was militarized, where in the movie did we know that? The only subconscious we knew was militarized was Saito's in the beginning. Saito's subconscious were guards, but not aggressive attackers like these. This is where I believe the first dream level was Cobbs. Cobbs never fights or is attacked by the militarized projections, he only helps the team in the cab(Yusuf was the dreamer). On the plane, Cobb also drinks water before going under which caused the rain storm! His water could have also been spiked, and then the others reorganized the dream sequence. We see Cobbs hand drop, but not sure of the others going under at the same time. Cobb is extremely skilled in marksmanship so it's plausible from him to have skilled militarized projections. Cobbs is shocked by the Train and may realize it was his dream at that point because that never happened. The only other person to see the train was Ariadne, who was in the car with him. The train also appears again after the van hits the water, under the bridge. Second level down was Arthur's dream, and the third level down was Fischer's dream. '''When did Ariadne dream? Like others here have "already" pointed out, after Fischer "supposedly" died, Ariadne convinced Cobbs to enter Limbo, but it was in fact the 4th dream level down which was very unstable.''' Ariadne knew how to redesign Limbo and the interior of Cobbs home. How? Remember when Ariadne saw the train in Cobbs elevator of memories? That was Cobbs recreation of the Limbo world he created with Mal, so I'm assuming that is where she found the design. Just like Eames lead Fischer to the vault of his father, Ariadne lead Cobbs to Mal. They both let go at the sametime. Now, when Cobbs stayed behind to find Saito, the 4th dream world collapsed and Cobb ended up in Saito's dream. We don't know when Saito actually left the dream world and it's not certain when he died. But I think he had help. Remember the first architect? He designed that level where Cobb initially cracked Saito safe. The same place was redesigned by the architect, this time is was during the day to simulate Limbo, but it wasn't. The same military guards outside by the shore that was in Saito first dream were also in the last scene, and they found cobb there. Saito's age was either a projection of Cobb, deception by Saito or a forgery by Eames, which I'm not sure. But for certain, they never went to Limbo in my opinion. That's why Saito knew the arrangement and there were people(guards) there. In Limbo, a person can't create other projections. When Saito presented the gun, they shot themselves in Saito's dream and the timer ran out on the device in the first dream level or on the plane, bringing them back to reality. If you notice, everyone else is up, but Saito and Cobbs wakes up last, and team members are smiling knowing they accomplished Inception on Cobb. This tells me that Saito being rescued by Cobb and honoring the arrangement was key for the idea for Cobb to let go of Mal. Artur asked what happened to Cobb on the shore of the first dream level, Ariadne said he will be OK. She knew that Cobb and Saito were still connected to the device and now sharing a dream built by the first architect. This is unclear how, but in my opinion purposefully done by the director. How do I know when Cobb wakes up on the plane is reality? When in the real world, Cobb was always on a plane or helicopter. The plane represented reality. The top did fall, because in Limbo, the top didn't wobble, only in reality it wobbled. When Cobb was on the phone with his kids in the beginning, they sounded like their age, not older. Though subtle, they were wearing different clothes at the end. The girl had one white sleeves and the little boy's shirt pattern was different. Hope I added something to the discussion. I loved this film, a true work of art.

revision.comment: Created page with "Inception (2010) is a movie within a movie within a movie. The number appearing as 528-491 (the blond having written it on a bar napkin) is an equation resulting in 37. Go to pag..."
revision.text:
Inception (2010) is a movie within a movie within a movie. The number appearing as 528-491 (the blond having written it on a bar napkin) is an equation resulting in 37. Go to page 37 of Godel, Escher, Bach and you will find the following sentence within the section, Jumping Out of the System (maybe you prefer Nolan’s, Kicking Up/Out of the Dream).
“Of course, there are cases where only a rare individual will have the vision to perceive a system which governs many people’s lives, a system which had never before even been recognized as a system; then such people often devote their lives to convincing other people that the system really is there, and that it ought to be exited from!” (p. 528-491=37 of Godel, Escher, Bach: An Eternal Golden Braid written 1979 by Douglas Hofstadter for which he won the Pulitzer Prize in 1980).
Inside the safe – the safe within the safe within the safe (the guarded compound possibly representing the Principia Mathematica by Russell & Whitehead) we find the Last Will and Testament of Christianity and the Pinwheel of Buddhism. Nolan’s film is a meta-communication.
Mark

revision.comment: Created page with "WHITELIST * Inception Movie - Video Review * Inception Movie Trailer - Teaser Trailer * Inception Movie Trailer - Trailer 2 * Inception Bluray Clip Nolan on Dreams * Inceptio..."
revision.text:
WHITELIST
* Inception Movie - Video Review * Inception Movie Trailer - Teaser Trailer * Inception Movie Trailer - Trailer 2 * Inception Bluray Clip Nolan on Dreams * Inception DVD Blu-ray Clip - The Mountain Fortress * Inception (2010) - Clip I need an architect * Inception (2010) - Featurette Behind the scenes * Inception (2010) - Featurette Character * Inception (2010) - Clip I am the most skilled extractor * Inception (2010) - Clip This is your first lesson in shared dreaming * Inception (2010) - Clip Don't be afraid to dream a little bigger * Inception (2010) - Open-ended Trailer for this action film * Inception (2010) - Second trailer for this mind bending thriller * Inception (2010) - TV spot trailer Real 30 * Inception (2010) - TV spot trailer Chance * Inception (2010) - TV spot trailer The beginning * Inception (2010) - Interview Ellen Page "On her character" * Inception (2010) - Interview Marion Cotillard "On her character's depth" * Inception (2010) - TV spot trailer The dream is real * Inception (2010) - Interview Cillian Murphy "On dreams" * Inception (2010) - Interview Leonardo DiCaprio "On the moving sets" * Inception (2010) - Open-ended Trailer for this thriller about the power of the mind * Inception (2010) - Open-ended Trailer for this thriller about a man who specializes in subconscious security * Inception (2010) - Gravity defying trailer starring Leonardo DiCaprio * Inception (2010) - Interview Christopher Nolan "On dreams as potential of the human mind" * Inception (2010) - Interview Joseph Gordon-Levitt "On Christopher Nolan and his cast members"
Bryan Fotino is an intelligent teenager from New Jersey. His favorite movie of all time is ''Inception'', with his favorite character being Cobb.

revision.comment: Created page with "i reaguys, Christopher Nolqn said thqt thwle entire movie wasnt a dream and that there were still parts in reality so at least up part of the movie takes placein the reql worl..."
revision.text: i reaguys, Christopher Nolqn said thqt thwle entire movie wasnt a dream and that there were still parts in reality so at least up part of the movie takes placein the reql world i personally believe he woke up he knows how he got to his house (from the airport to the airplane to the us through imigrations abd to his house with alfred... i mean miles) his children were played by slightly older actors, tge turned around, their clothes were indeed different and he wasnt wearing his ring which he wears in all dream sequenses finally, the top qobbles however slight it may be, this wouldnt happen in a dream where the laws of physics dont apply thats my take on it i believe it to be backed up by a lot of evidence and much less confusing than ones with all those multiple dream levels we dont know about and the like

revision.comment: Created page with "i have just one reason why they may still be in a dream at the end, or a dream throughout the whole movie and that is to do with totems. Arthur tells Adrianne why totems are i..."
revision.text: i have just one reason why they may still be in a dream at the end, or a dream throughout the whole movie and that is to do with totems. Arthur tells Adrianne why totems are important, he also prevents her from touching his weighted dice as he says this will remove the totems power to reflect the dream/reality state, yet Cobbs totem is not his, it belonged to Mal, she also created the idea of totems, if Cobb used Mals totem to plant inception on her in limbo then surely the totem stops having the power to reflect reality? and therefore Cobbs perception of dreams and reality becomes even more obscured.

[[File:Placeholder|thumb|220px]]
This is your user page. Please edit this page to tell the community about yourself!
==My favorite pages==
* Add links to your favorite pages on the wiki here! * Favorite page #2 * Favorite page #3

I am rewatching "Inception" about once a week, sometimes more in the last month. I am either trapped by the music or the visuals, or maybe a little bit of both.
I recently discovered the Edith Piaf song "Non, Je Ne Regrette Rien" and listen to it a few times during the day. I joke myself thinking that I'm waiting for "the kick" that will bring me back to the new reality. Is it strange that it never happens? Probably not. :-) I probably am a bit sick of grad school, work and everything else dragging me down a bit for right now. It's only another month and things return to relative normalcy.
For now, watch "Inception" often and hoping that I will here Edith's singing voice somewhere out in the ether. [[Category:Blog posts]]

revision.comment:
Created page with "Arthur: "It would have to be a 747."
Cobb: "Why is that?"
Arthur: "Because in a 747, the pilot's up top, and the first class cabin's in the nose, so no one would wal..."
revision.text:
Arthur: "It would have to be a 747."
Cobb: "Why is that?"
Arthur: "Because in a 747, the pilot's up top, and the first class cabin's in the nose, so no one would walk through. But you'd have to buy out the entire cabin. And the first class flight attendant..."
Saito: "I bought the airline."
[Everybody turns and stares at him. Saito just shrugs]
Saito: "It seemed neater." that or Saito: "''Inception. Is it possible?''"
Arthur: "''Of course not.''"
Saito: "''If you can steal an idea from someone's mind, why can't you plant one there instead?''"
Arthur: "''Okay, here's me planting an idea in your head. I say to you, don't think about elephants. What are you thinking about?''"
Saito: "''Elephants."''

revision.comment: Created page with "I think we are missing the point and the only true answer is to ask the director himself. But this is what I think: <b><span style="color:yellow;">It is not about if the top ..."
revision.text: I think we are missing the point and the only true answer is to ask the director himself. But this is what I think: It is not about if the top fell or continue spinning. Focus on the emotional concept behind all those dreams. You see... at the end of the movie, it did not matter to Cobb anymore if the top fell or not. What is his greatest desire in the whole movie? It is to see his children... Watch the movie again and again...you still won`t fully understand it. But I believe that was Leonardo`s(the director) advise, focus on the emotional concept.

revision.comment: Created page with "the top falls. obviously. if you pay attention hearing the sound of the totem on the wooden table, it's going to fall. and also, when he's in dream, the totem spins SHARPLY ST..."
revision.text: the top falls. obviously. if you pay attention hearing the sound of the totem on the wooden table, it's going to fall. and also, when he's in dream, the totem spins SHARPLY STABLE AT CENTER. and also, cobb's daughter in the end wears a different dress with white inset at arms, and that time is the only time in which she dresses that skirt (in dream the skirt is always completely fucsia). pay attention on it.

#REDIRECT [[Lucid Dreaming]]
#REDIRECT [[Dream-Sharing]]
#REDIRECT [[Dream-Sharing]]

[[File:Chemist.png|thumb|right|350px|Chemists develop chemical compounds for dream-sharing]] {{Quote|[[Yusuf]]: ''...I rarely go into the field, Mr. Cobb.''
[[Cobb]]: ''We'd need you there to tailor the compounds specific to our needs.''|}} The '''Chemist''' is the specialist responsible for developing chemical compounds required to achieve [[Dream-Sharing]] via the [[Portable Automated Somnacin IntraVenous Device|PASIV device]]. As the chemicals are administered to human subjects, a chemist requires a considerable understanding of pharmacology and how the chemicals will affect the biological state of the sleeper. More skilled chemists will be able to compose compounds to attain different effects in a sleeper's dream.
While the primary chemical compound required for dream-sharing is a standard formula of [[somnacin]], some chemists are capable of developing more complex compounds to ensure [[dreamer]]s will experience more lucid dreams. Other compounds formulated by chemists may include sedatives to increase stability in dreams, while preventing the sleeper from waking immediately except when [[Kick|induced to experience physically falling]].
As with the [[Architect]], a chemist may fulfill the role of a dreamer during a heist, particularly to provide the knowledge of specific compounds to be administered to induce dreamers in a dream into another dream layer. However, it is not necessary for a chemist to enter a dream.
==References== <references/> [[Category:Dream Mechanics]]
